b"b' No response to write if server is using SslHandler and client is not'"
b'b" [Originally posted on Stackoverflow]url  Happens in the inverse as well
column11: the client is using SslHander but the server isn\'t.  I wanted to have a graceful failure for both cases to let the client to that they need to enable
column12: or disable
column13: SSL to connect to the server.  But when the two are out of sync
column14: the communications go awry. Part of the issue I observed was that in the SslHander decode
column15: it was possible that the response from the other end of the connection could look like SSLv2 when it really was not.  The payload happened to look like it was SSLv2
column16: major version 8
column17: but contained no data so the handshake never completed.  I found if I forced the major version to be 2 or 3
column18: I could get an error correctly claiming it was not a valid SSL error
column19: but that only worked when the SslHandler was on the server only.  I could not find a workaround for when it was on the client only. I did experiment with dynamically inserting a ReadTimeoutHandler for the write of the handshake to see if I could at least timeout the handshake and get the connection to fail that way.  This almost worked
column20: the timeout did fire appropriately
column21: but when the server got the event
column22: it could not transmit the information about closing the channel back to the client.  I did not understand why that was
column23: that seemed to go into the SslHandler and just never come out. Ultimately
column24: I\'d like to have a clean way to know of there is a mismatch on the SSL; both sides should be using it
column25: or neither
column26: and if that\'s not the case
column27: I want to cleanly exit with a reasonable error message.  Right now someone just ends up waiting forever for the handhake response

b'b" Hello Norman
column11: OrderedDownstreamThreadPoolExecutor needs to handle channel state events to be able to release child executors when closing a thread. Thus
column12: ODTPE should be wrapped with DownstreamExecutionHandler and should not reject ChannelUpstreamEventRunnable. To prevent upstream events being handled by ODTPE
column13: we use this downstream execution handler: url  With these modifications
column14: we were able to get it running on our development environment.I\'ll let you know if we have other problems."'

column10: b"b' I think thats a better way to handle this... Could you checkout if it works for you ?'"
b'b" Looks nice
column11: but we still need some changes. Upstream events should not reach ODTPE
column12: because they will be rejected and thus can\'t advance in the pipeline. I suggest a modification to ExecutionHandler to make it available for downstream-only usage. Currently it can be used as upstream or upstream+downstream. If the ExecutionHandler is downstream-only
column13: it should pass-through the event instead of executing
column14: like:  "'

b"b' IdleStateHandler and ReadTimeoutHandler starts two timers'"

b'b" I am using Netty 3.3.1 with Sun JRE 6u31. () is supposed to be called by channelOpen() unless the event has already occurred in which case beforeAdd() makes the call (according to the comments). This seems to work fine for outbound TCP connections. However
column11: when using inbound TCP (accepted) connections
column12: initialize() is called by both methods. The call to () used by beforeAdd() to decide whether to defer initialisation to channelOpen()
column13: returns true
column14: even before channelOpen(). The result is that duplicate timeouts are regsitered in the Timer
column15: and the events fire twice every time. In my application this then leads to additional network activity. One aspect of my application which \'might\' be contributing is that the (child) channel handlers (including the IdleStateHandler) are added to the pipeline by the childChannelOpen() event handler of the server channel. (This was necessary as some of my handlers need a reference to an object which can\'t be created until the Channel object is available)."'

column10: b'b" Not sure if this is the right place to ask this but I\'m trying to understand the impact of the recent changes as it seems to have resulted in a lot more frequent dropped connections in my app and it can no longer complete an apachebench properly in high connection scenarios. Correct me if I\'m wrong
column11: but previously according to the old docs
column12: the boss thread would simply sit idle and accept connections
column13: then free worker threads would come and pick up an opened connection (up to a max indicated by workerCount). If worker threads are occupied the boss thread would still open connections but connections sits idle waiting for a worker to pick it up. How does this new model work? How does the connections get established and what sort of connection timeouts do we have to be aware of? What happens to connections when all worker threads are occupied?"'

column10: b'b" @ronaldslc the impact is that now everything is handled by the worker. So you must be sure that you don\'t block it in all cases. Before when you blocked the worker thread you were still be able to accept connections. Thats not the case anymore.. So do you by any chance have blocking or slow code in your handlers ?"'
b"b' Not sure to understand (since I did not test or read the code)
column11: but according to various comments here
column12: it seems the new behaviour could be a blocking point. Let me explain my understanding:Before
column13: if more connections occur than workers
column14: they were stille accepted but in idle waiting mode.Now
column15: they will just be refused (time out ?). I can imagine that on heavy load (heavy numbers of connection)
column16: this can present a serious different behaviour
column17: even if the workers are doing almost nothing slow. What is better ? To refuse new connections
column18: thus limitating the number of connections
column19: or to not limit this
column20: even if the thread model is a bit more complex ?I may be totally wrong
column21: but I think that accepting new connections is probably more interesting than simplifying code
column22: except if there are some true reasons behind and a way to not have this issue as Ronald say.And the model of NIO and in particular Netty is pretty interesting for such scenario (contrary to old models as Apache for instance way of using thread). Norman
column23: could you explain what could be the model with the new behaviour to not have such issue ?It may be obvious...'"

column10: b"b' @ronaldslc would it be possible to share your test code and how you run the benchmark ? @jestan yeah that could be problematic. And to be honest I did not think of this impact before. I guess thats the burden we have to take if we want to have only the workers to handle everything. If the user expect this behavoir he prolly have to adjust the worker count.'"
b'b\' @fredericBregier sorry for the delay
column11: I was busy with other stuff. Let me try to answer your questions / concerns... In 3.x we used a different thread to accept connections and hand them over to the workers. This way the connection was "accepted" even if the workers are busy. It was still possible to mess this open by having slow code in the "channelOpen(...)" method as this was executed in the accepting thread. In 4.x we wanted to have only the worker threads (we will prolly call it eventLoop here). The workers now handle the accepting + the other tasks like write / read etc. So to have it accept the connection you must take care that you have enough workers to handle it in a timely manner.  Your are right this behavior is really different
column12: but thats why we wanted to not change it before a next major release... Like I said to @jestan I did not think of this "effect" before and we may need to thing about the changes again in more detail to make sure we don\\\'t make it worth then what we have in 3.3.x. Be sure we will take your feedback serious and are very happy to get it. Thanks!\''

column23: a new "available" thread is created such that it can accept new connections and being used to take care of new oneswhen a thread is finished (no more work)
column24: according to the job in queue (or whatever way) the thread is either released
column25: either keep to be used to accept new connections or new workmaybe having the possibility however to limit this number of active threads if the use want to do so My main concern is that it is not always possible to know how many connections a program will have. For instance
column26: you can have 100 connections
column27: turning out to 100 000 in some other conditions. I have such software (ok they are more limited to 10 000 in some rare conditions
column28: but it happens). So I do not want to create all the time let say 10 000 threads for that in worker thread pool. What I like in the Netty model is the "adaptative" number of threads really active
column29: not depending on current number of connections
column30: but depending on real activities (no activity = no thread except some fix number of threads around). Again
column32: but I try to think about a way to merge both improvements
column33: the thread model and the easy way of programming for developpers...I may be totally wrong
column34: so please forgive me in advance ;-)\''

column10: b'b\' To add to my example
column11: I prefer personnaly to be able to accept a new connection and then pending until I can handle this new ones
column12: instead of refusing the connection
column13: which will turn in a few seconds to a new try from the opposite end
column14: but then will never be accepted probably...So if my proposal (which I do not know if it is possible to implement) is ok
column15: then I would probably however limit the number of worker threads to not have "too many" worker or executionHandler threads at a time (to not reach upper limit of the JVM or server below).... but to a high limit that I could guess from configuration and changed if we find out this is not enoug... However being adaptative is more flexible and more easy to give a try to a limit... My 2 cents ;-)\''

column10: b'b" @fredericBregier first of writes can happy from any thread...  You don\'t need to have one thread per connection. You just need enough to handle concurrent connection attempts + handler code. That a way different from one thread per connection which is true for OIO and not for NIO. The problem with the adaptive way is that it would again remove our simplification as we would again not handle everything for a channel with the same thread.  I\'m also not think you need an ExecutionHandler all the time with 4.x now. Only if your handler code is to slow ;) I think I may have to think again a bit more in detail about all the problems and write some benchmark which show us how we perform compared to the logic in 3.x (this is what we need todo anyway to make sure we not make things a way slower in 4.x)."'
b'b" I understand Norman. By the way
column11: what generally I\'m programming is time consuming (cpu / IO on files) so I need to have ExecutionHandler...Today
column12: I do not have the limitation on connections side
column13: and I populate generally double than core numbers as number of worker threads to be able to scale as much as possible on the underlying server. On the write
column14: ok that was I understood previously (only read coming into those worker threads).On the NIO model
column15: that is what I like
column16: contrary to other models. OK
column17: I let then try to expose through a benchmark the behaviour (probably a simple http benchmark or so could be more simpler on protocol -) could make the trick.I do not know if I will have time to make my own test
column18: but if I found some
column19: I will ;-)"'

column10: b'b" @normanmaurer an easier example to test it out would be to use the Snoop Server example and add a empty loop to the handler. I used: for (long i=0;i < 5000000; i++) {} This increases the latency when I do apache bench to a more realistic level for my application. Then test it with: ab -k -n 20000 -c 1000 url  Under the new model. It would display connection reset by peer by (in my case) 1542 connections. I\'m running the environment in Ubuntu VM with 4Gb ram on a home desktop i7 920 processor. Under the old March 1st snapshot
column11: the benchmark would fail at first on 4500 connections
column12: then once the VM optimises
column13: it will be able to complete the benchmark without problems. (I will add as well that Netty\'s ability to handle concurrent connections quickly under the old model is one of the best in class) I think it should be a given that when Netty is used as a HTTP Server environment
column14: handlers will be slow
column15: but under the old model it would work extremely well in those instances without us \'users\' having to understand all the internal of Netty. Under the new model
column16: I now need to understand how Netty\'s connection handlers work. If I understand the reasoning for the simplification correctly
column17: which is to make it faster to handle requests because it would negate the overhead of thread jumping. In the end
column18: in my particular use case as a HTTP Server. I would think my ideal scenario is to be able to set a min and max or fixed thread count on Netty worker pool
column19: then if the worker pool is all \'in use\' a \'backup\' thread will be used to put aside (accept) connections to give to the worker pool later (and NOT open up unlimited threads as it would be detrimental to performance) This is a simplification of the model with a conditional break-off point
column20: and of course it is actually an increase in complexity in code. However this would give me the best of both worlds. i.e. I can handle most request faster if load is light
column21: but if load increases I will not so easily lose connections.  I don\'t expect this to make it into Netty as everybody\'s use case is so broad and different
column22: but it would be great if you can somehow open up the \'API\' so that I can implement something like I described without going into the heart of Netty. One last thing I have noticed in the new code is that even though my \'worker pool\' uses an unbounded (). The worker thread count never goes up more than 1
column23: but the VM has been allocated 4 virtual cores
column24: so I\'m not sure how Netty decides to increase worker thread count. Regards"'

column10: b'b" One thing I\'d like to add is that
column11: theoretically
column12: I could achieve what my ideal solution is by using a ExecutionHandler as the first handler
column13: but I have tried that and you can test it yourself with the Snoop Server example as well
column14: the performance of Netty under high concurrent load is still nowhere near the old model (it actually cannot complete the benchmark) even if you have an OrderedMemoryAwareThreadPoolExecutor with 8 or more core threads. (under the old model the worker pool would increase to around 8 threads when I run ab -k -n 20000 -c 1000 with the Snoop server example) My guess is that the \'mere\' process from it accepting the channel to it getting to the ExecutionHandler is still considered \'blocked\' hence a lot of connections could not be accepted still. Regards"'

b"b' Connection problems with IPv6 link-local addresses and jdk < 7'"
b"b' Because of a jdk bug its not possible to connect to an endpoint via IPv6 link-local addresses when using a jdk version < 7. We should apply a workaround for this. For more details see:url url '"
b"b' I have bad news. I have tested the workaround this patch uses against a few linux distros and can confirm that it only appears to work for older distributions. It also will break MacOSX
column11: since it requires the connect address to contain the % zone specifier. I recommend reverting the workaround (or at least selectively enabling it for just Linux
column12: and letting users know not all distros are covered).'"

column10: b"b' Thats really bad.. I tested it with fedora 16. Maybe we should then allow to enable this workaround with a System Property . WDYT?'"
b'b\' Ah it appears this was not the complete "hack". The problem with _just_ stripping the zone id is that it will prevent its purpose
column11: which is to distinguish between multiple NICs that have the same link-local address. The full "hack" was to set the source binding address to use the non-stripped version
column12: and the destination to use the stripped version. This hack fails on Fedora 16
column14: and updated 14
column15: but it works on all versions of RHEL
column16: and some versions of debian I had tested. Unfortunately the hack also breaks  (you need the scope in the link local)
column17: and it probably breaks other platforms. A system property is a good idea
column18: although you might want to do the full hack. I\\\'m not sure its worth it though. There might be other workarounds but it would take quite a bit of research
column19: and you would have to selectively enable them per platform combination.\''

column10: b'b" Isn\'t that what we do? We only use the stripped version for the remote address ."'
b'b\' For the "hack" to work you have to strip AND you have to use the unstripped version as the bind address (another way to tell the OS which network interface to use when sending the packets)
column11: otherwise the OS will pick an ambigous interface or throw a routing error. Said another way
column12: the whole reason to use a zoneid is to solve the ambiguity
column13: so if you only strip it
column14: you leave the ambiguity and defeat the purpose of it (intention of the user). They could just as easily not specify it if its not going to work anyway.\''

column10: b"b' Yeah I know and that is what we do..  See for the bind:url  And this for the connect:url '"
b'b" Maybe I am missing something. I don\'t see anything in the above commits that calls bind with the zone id."'

b"b' It calls bind with the given InetSocketAddress which will contain the zone id / scope id. The zone id / scope id will only get stripped of when it gets passed to the SocketUtil (which is only be used in the connect(..) method.'"
b"b' Ah ok reading the entire file I see that now. Any chance you were using openjdk on F16
column11: that one seems to work with (and without) the workaround?'"

column10: b"b' Yes I was using openjdk ;)'"
b"b' Ah now try the evil proprietary oracle sun jdk :)'"

b'b\' I see... So I guess we should just make it configurable via System property or maybe remove the "workaround" all together and tell people to use java7 if they want to use ipv6 link-local addresses. \''
b'b" Yeah I think either approach is fine. I\'ll leave it to you to decide whats best. I only wanted to warn you that we were wrong about the workaround :("'
b"b' I guess removing is the best. What will you do for jboss-as ? Will removing work for you ?'"
b'b" Yeah we are removing it everywhere we have it elsewhere and are just going to tell our users about the jdk bug

column10: b"b' This breaks the build so reopen'"
b'b" It\'s not a POM problem but an M2E problem.  M2E makes an assumption that a project use JDK 1.6 is source level is 1.6
column11: which is not the case for Netty."'

column10: b'b\' Trustin:  M2E reads settings from the "" and applies them to eclipse ".project"\''
b"b' Yeah
column11: we ensure we use JDK 7 to build Netty by using the enforcer plugin but M2E does not respect it.  It only respects the compiler options
column12: which is not correct.  We are using JDK7 for only small portion of our code and we support Java 5 and 6 at the same time.  Therefore
column13: it makes no sense to set -source 1.7 or -target 1.7 option for us.'"

column10: b"b'  100% CPU Usage'"
b'b" Hi
column11: I believe I have an issue similar to #302 but on Linux (Ubuntu 10.04) with JDK (1.6.0u30) and JDK(1.7.0u4) using Netty-4.0.0 (Revision: 52a7d28cb59e3806fda322aecf7a85a6adaeb305) The app is proxying connections to backend systems.  The proxy has a pool of channels that it can use to send requests to the backend systems.  If the pool is low on channels
column12: new channels are spawned and put into the pool so that requests sent to the proxy can be serviced.  The pools get populated on app startup
column13: so that is why it doesn\'t take long at all for the CPU to spike through the roof (22 seconds into the app lifecycle). The test box has two CPUs

b"b' @trustin I think this is because of an epoll bug which still is not fixed or was fixed and is now present again. Please review the following workaround:url  So basically we do the following here:check if (timeout) returns 0 and complete before the timeoutif so we increment a counterif the counter == 10 we create a new selector and register all the Channels from the old one to the new one and close the old Selector. After that we reset the counter.if the counter < 10 we just processif (timeout) returns The fix is kind of the same as jetty
column11: grizzly and mina do :) WDYT ?'"

b'b" We had the same issue on a solaris x86 platform and jdk 1.7.0_09 on multiple applications using the NIO api. Netty 3.5.11 was also flawed. We ended enabling the system property
column11: this fixed the 100% cpu problem and we had 3-4 warnings a day saying the epoll bug was detected and selector recreated. I\'ve decided to look a the next sun jvm release (1.7.0_10) and saw that they have fixed a similar bug : url  The good news is that after upgrading our softwares to jdk 1.7.0_11 the 100% cpu bug has disappeared. We are now running netty 3.5.11 without the  system props fine. So upgrade your JDK."'

b'b" @adjsnlxx What exact version of the JDK are you using? Curious because we ran into a very similar issue
column11: not with Netty but with Oracle Coherence
column12: and turned out to be JDK bug. Our instances would lock up
column13: hit max server threads and stop responding. What drew me to this thread was the epollWait calls in the thread dumps. Here was our thread stack trace:: RUNNABLE  at (Native Method)  at (:269)  at (:79)  at (:86)  locked  (a $2)  locked  (a $UnmodifiableSet)  locked  (a )  at (:97)  at $(:484) Thread analysis showed a thread trying to lock an object (DatagramPacket) that no other thread has locked. This is a soft reference so it is not cleaned up until full GC. Again
column14: this was Coherence
column15: not Netty. Why I mention this is because the issue is similar and turned out to be a bug in the JDK. [Coherence team has filed a bug]url  but Java team closed as they couldn\'t reproduce it. (We were able to reproduce it with sufficient load.) Therefore
column16: Coherence team resolved the issue. Some details on this bug: This behavior observed in JDK 1.7.0_80 or later and JDK_1.8.0_45 or later (though as early as JDK1.8.0_25 but not as frequent).  Therefore it would be interesting to know the exact version of JDK you see this issue with."'

column10: b"b' Fixed a WebSocket client bug which led to the first frame being discarded'"

b'b" When switching to WebSockets over straight HTTP the first WebSocket frame is discarded by HttpResponseDecoder instead of being forwarded on to the WebSocketFrameXXDecoder. This behaviour isn\'t present when communicating via SSL
column11: I believe(??) this is due to time spent encrypting data before sending which puts a bit of separation between the switching protocols response and the first frame. I have fixed the issue by checking to see if the message is WebSocket switching protocols response based on traits similar to all WebSocket versions and if this is the case the message plus the raw buffer is forwarded on to WebSocketFrameDecoder. Another solution that worked in practice was adding: to the start of callDecode in ReplayingDecoder
column12: but this approach fails in cases like HttpClientCodec. I have also modified the git exclusions to be a bit more permissive."'

column10: b'b\' Silly github won\\\'t let me attach a file to the pull request comment so I have uploaded it to Google Docs here url  To replicate:1. Run TestServer2. Run TestClient
column11: the final message you will see in the console is "CLIENT: Message received o"3. Run TestClient again
column12: this time you won\\\'t see "CLIENT: Message received o" as the message is discarded\''

column10: b'b" Thanks. This makes sense now. Running the example netty ws client against the example netty ws server does not have this problem because the server echo\'s the client\'s frames.  Hence
column11: the client only sends a frame AFTER the HttpMessageDecoder has been swapped out. In your example
column12: the server sends a message immediate after it sends a successful handshake hence the test client has not had the time to swap out the HttpMessageDecoder. Another proposed solution is to try to add a slight delay on the server side. Maybe be try using the HashedWheelTimer? Not sure if other non-netty ws clients may have a similar problem. @trustin @normanmaurer Can you please help review the changes to HttpMessageDecoder.  I\'m not sure if the changes affect other areas to Netty."'

b'b" @normanmaurer In the test app setHandshakeComplete() needs to be called before replacing the handlers so when () is called if the handshake is complete the WebSocketFrame decoded after replacing the handler is passed on. Otherwise a mis-cast occurs
column11: TextWebSocketFrame as HttpResposnse
column12: and if that didn\'t happen finishHandshake() would loop. You could probably do away with marking the handshake as complete by taking a WebSocketFrame as an indication as the handshake being completed successfully. Currently in WebSocketClientHandler there is: this could be: Though this may be a silly move as it is less intuitive to someone writing a client WebSocketHandler
column13: at the end of the day WebSocketClientHandler is just example code after all. Anyway I have committed code in 65361e4 that will ensure that the existing example WebSocketClientHandler will still work."'

b"b' @normanmaurer  @trustin Hi
column11: I met a similar bug in the Websockect Example (Netty 3.6 Final ): after websocket client handshake()
column12: send a message to websocket server immediately
column13: and isHandshakeComplete() is false
column14: so the bug happens. In other word
column15: when the websocket server handling handshake(not done)
column16: the client sends a message to server
column17: then server will use HttpRequestDecoder to decode the message
column18: bug happens.Now
column19: I fix it by checking whether the isHandshakeComplete() returns true before sending message .This bug will not always happen
column20: I have tested the example demo
column21: the first is ok
column22: but the rest always report bugs.Thanks!'"

column10: b"b' Using channel Local : : await*() in I/O thread causes a dead lock or sudden performance drop. Use addListener() instead or call await*() from a different thread.'"
b"b' Hi
column11: Between version 3.5.0.beta and 3.5.0 final
column12: a change occurs concerning Local Channel. This brings issue in my project. Previously
column13: there were no issue to have an await*() in such channel
column14: since it is in thread only.Now
column15: it always sends the following error : : await_() in I/O thread causes a dead lock or sudden performance drop. Use addListener() instead or call await_() from a different thread. My point of view is that for Channel Local
column16: it should not be necessary to add in addition a new thread layer between the channel handling and the work to be done. It could have IMHO some huge impact in performance to be obliged to add in addition such a thread. Most of the time
column17: those Channel Local are already within a thread (and for me always) that is separated from a real Channel interface (networked one). Is there any reason for this change ? Not to say it will have a huge impact in my code
column18: but if there is a real reason
column19: ok I will do the necessary changes on my side
column20: but I do think it seems unecessary for such Local Channel handling...'"

I even try to use a very different Executor

column10: b'b\' Small correction on the behavior
column11: here is the scenario I found out: 1) A network channel received a message (before the handler is an OrderedMemoryAwareThreadPoolExecutor)2) It forwards it to a local channel3) the local channel server (before the handler is an OrderedMemoryAwareThreadPoolExecutor) ()4) then decide to send back a message to the remote client (network channel) (writeAbstractLocalPacket) 5) and to wait for the message to be sent (same writeAbstractLocalPacket)Then the "checkDeadLock" is raizing an error. But there is an OMATPE in each step
column12: so why ?I believe the check if checkDeadLock is not ok then ? Here is the exception trace: So the exception is raized while the wait is really not called from an IO thread (see the stack trace)...\''

column10: b'b\' Finally by making step by step
column11: it seems it is more in ChannelEventRunnable that the issue is.When it set the "(executor);"
column12: the stack trace is the following: and later on when the wait occurs: So
column13: have you any idea ?I know this code is very new in the 3.5
column14: but I do not know the impact of it...\''

b"b' And to finish with this from my analysis part: I double check
column11: and the Executor that is set in ChannelEventRunnable and checked later on is my Local OrderedMemoryAwareThreadPoolExecutor
column12: not an Executor from Netty on IO thread part...'"

column10: b'b" No real solution
column11: but a few more observations. Waiting a bit before releasing the resources usually help preventing triggering the issue.So
column12: taking into account the stacktrace and the principle of netty
column13: I did some more tests. And I wonder now if there may be some kind of race condition (or maybe a bad ordering in actions taken) between the connection timeout handling and the resource releasing
column14: maybe coupled with a specificity in Oracle JVM implementation on Windows. Netty 3.5.5.Final stacktrace: As one can see in the stacktrace
column15: at some point the timeout handling triggers the issue notification to listeners. That\'s when the obtained from the completes: for example attaching a listener to it and printing the current stacktrace gives So since the future is completed my code just goes on to release the resources before leaving.But it seems (see the original netty stacktrace) there is a listener that was also automatically attached:  And it appears this listener is somehow notified (ordering of listeners ?) or executed (race condition ?) after my client is notified of the connection failure. And at some point this listener sends the exception upstream in the channel pipeline (actually this is how I receive and log in  ) ... while my code is releasing the resources. So now maybe there is a specificity due to the Oracle JVM implementation on windows
column16: but when releasing the resources
column17: a signal interrupts what may be happening inside the channel pipeline. For example if I add a long enough with catching and trashing any throwable in
column18: I get the following interrupt
column19: and does not get the issue deep inside netty: So
column20: is there a way in netty to wait for any pending action inside the channel pipeline (before releasing the resources) ?Or actually
column21: is the channel pipeline expected to still work (and not get interrupts)  releasing the resources ?"'

column10: b"b' Tested with OpenJDK 6 under Ubuntu: waiting inside also get the interrupt when resources are released. So it would look like the netty stacktrace under Windows is a side effect (Oracle implementation that does something that can be interrupted
column11: unlike OpenJDK ?)
column12: and that the real issue is that the connection timeout actions can take place while the application has already been notified of the connection failure: hence a possible race condition with resource cleanup.'"

b'b" My 2 cents. I think this would be a good idea. I played around with this before
column11: based on their talk @ url  From their talk I gathered that the circular buffer was key to acheiving the speeds they do
column12: that and a few other optimizations. When I saw their talk I did a very naive implementation based on the talk
column13: it is largely experimental see url and url  At what stage in Netty would this be integrated if it were considered seriously. The biggest downside to the disruptor\'s approach is also its strongest point
column14: the circular buffer. If it isn\'t tuned to the application it is very easy for messages to be lost obviously because by its nature a circular buffer wraps when it\'s full.+ allocating too large of an array for the buffer results in potentially unnecessary memory usage. I didn\'t make a note of any numbers that I could share but using the circular buffer made a clearly noticeable difference when I tested. The JavaDoc comments on the class at url  explains a bit more about my findings when I experimented.I left these in because I intend to explore it further and do a better & more optimized implementation. If going forward Netty integrates something like this from what I\'ve found the most important thing will be to let users know the risk associated with using the approach and making it as configurable as possible."'

column10: b"b' @trustin +1'"
b"b' Race condition in NioWorker in Netty 3.5.x results in NullPointerException'"

b"b' There is a race condition in  in Netty 3.5.x resulting in a NullPointerException on line 146 (v3.5.2) in the register method from time to time.  I believe what happens is as follows:0) app happily running doing some work1) register method is called2) start() method is called from register
column11: started == true
column12: so nothing to do
column13: returns to register3) (in another thread) shutdown set to true in run() method as there has been no activity for 1 second4) run() checks in a synchronized block to see whether the queue is empty
column14: closes the selector and sets selector = null5) register method now reaches the line where it adds the item to the queue 6) register method now reaches the () call and throws a NullPointerException because selector == null Please add a fix for this to netty 3.5.3 as it results in random NullPointerExceptions happening from time to time. Fixing this issues should be a simple matter of wrapping more of the code in the register method in a synchronized block (using the same object for locking as the start() method). Register() is adding an element to a queue outside a synchronized block while run() is checking the length of the queue in a synchronized block
column15: resulting in a race condition
column16: which leads to a NPE.'"

column10: b"b' @Joe12345 could you post the stacktrace here ?'"
b"b' @Joe12345 fixed .. thanks for reporting!'"
b"b' Thanks! Is there an estimate for when 3.5.3 is to be released(GA)?'"

b'b" I\'ve taken a look at the code change. While I believe the change will reduce the probability of the bug being hit I don\'t think it fully resolves the issue. What happens if the selector field is set to null
column11: or closed
column12: by another thread between the null check being performed in register() and the call to () ?  I think more of the register() code should be synchronized using the same mutex as the code which is closing and setting the value to null. The performance impact should be small as register already needs to acquire that lock when it calls open()"'

column10: b'b" OK. Taking a closer look it seems that you\'ve partially solved the issue by caching the value of selector before doing the null check (neat trick). Unfortunately it doesn\'t account for what happens when the other thread calls close() while we are working / about to work with the selector."'

b'b" It doesn\'t look like it actually caches the value in a local variable. Either way having a null check is simply going to result in register() failing silently and won\'t defend against the selector being closed by another thread. Without additional synchronization the null check only serves to suppress the exception when the race condition occurs."'
b"b' @Joe12345 I think you are right... could you please review the latest commit.. Thanks!'"
b"b' @Joe12345 and to answer you question.. 3.5.3.Final should be released today or tomorrow'"

b"b' The synchronized block would need to be expanded all the way up to just before the following line:Selector selector = start(); Without this wider synchronization block the run() method can close the selector while register is in progress.  I believe there is also another more subtle race condition present in the run() method. run() performs shutdown if the register queue is empty and ().isEmpty(). Both of these conditions is true between processRegisterTaskQueue pulling the register task off the queue and actually registering keys with the selector.'"
b"b' @Joe12345 hmm.. I see.. BTW any proposal for a fix as pull requests is welcome ;)'"
b'b" @Joe12345 I think if we put the (registerTask); in the synchronized(startStopLock) block also
column11: it should be ok. Don\'t you think ?"'

column10: b"b' If the run() method closes the selector between Selector selector = start(); and boolean offered = (registerTask); it will break. Synchronizing all the way up to above selector = start() solves this. The race with processRegisterTaskQueue will be trickier to solve.'"
b'b" @Joe12345 to be honest I don\'t get why there would be still a race.. Can you give some details or explaintation ?"'

b"b' There are two race conditions. If you are referring to the first one we could have the following scenario: url  register() method starts (line 136)Selector selector = start() (line 139)...In another thread in run():conditions in lines 264 269 are all met and (() && ().isEmpty()) are both satisfiedSelector is closed and set to null (lines 271 to 278)...in register()  the following lines now execute: boolean offered = (registerTask);    assert offered;  '"

b"b' I just committed latest code so we have the same code-base to look at.. url  I think we have no race anymore as the close() and everything else is guarded by the startStopLock. Maybe I miss something and need more coffee ?'"

b'b\' @Joe12345 Also I think it would make sense to set "allowShutdownOnIdle" to false when using it at client mode. As I think its really common to use the same NioClientSocketChannelFactory for many client connections. WDYT ?\''

b'b\' OK awesome. In the latest link the synchronized block extends all the way to above the start() call. First race condition solved :) The second race condition we have involves the following check in run():if (() && ().isEmpty()) {.()..} Both of these conditions are satisfied during the very short window between a register task being taken off the queue and the registration with the selector being performed. I\\\'ve indicated this window of vulnerability below: private void processRegisterTaskQueue() throws IOException {    for (;;) {    final Runnable task = ();    if (task == null) {      break;    }    //At this point the queue is empty and the selector has no registered keys. this means that selector can be "safely" (not!) be closed    ();    cleanUpCancelledKeys();    }  }\''
b'b" @Joe12345 but processRegisterTaskQueue() is only called from within the same run() method. So I don\'t see how this could lead to a race"'

b'b\' You are correct. I didn\\\'t notice that the processRegisterTaskQueue method was "private". I thought it had default access like register (and therefore could be called externally). This means that the (only) race condition has been resolved! :) BTW is there currently an easy way to set allowShutdownOnIdle = false from client code (from outside of the netty lib)?\''
b'b\' @Joe12345 yes there is: the "false" param is the one you need.\''
b"b' Nice. I can use that as a workaround in 3.5.2 then :)'"

column10: b"b' I believe because each event executor thread wakes up every 6 milliseconds
column11: which is roughly about 170 wake-ups per second per thread.  Each thread wakes up to check if there is any scheduled tasks and to add them to the task queue.  Probably 6 ms is way too low and we need better ways to handle this issue. To confirm my assumption
column12: could you please increase to a larger value and see if it makes any difference?'"

column10: b'b\' Ok that is the problem.. ChannelFactory instances should not be created per client but shared across them. As otherwise you will use one Thread per Channel which is not what you want if you use NIO. The whole point of NIO is to reduce the number of Threads you use.... The "problem" you see is because of this "anti-pattern". This was not a problem before
column11: but could become one.. Let me explain why:Before we lazy created the Selector on the first channel that was registered. So you did not see any threads until the first channel was opened. This was a problem as it came with quite some overhead later and also needed some extra synchronization and so slowed down thingsNow we create the selectors directly once the ChannelFactory is created. This allows use to handle registration etc in a much faster way.  The thread count is the same in both cases
column12: as once one channel was registered the Selector is also started before. So to fix this make sure you only use on ChannelFactory (or at least some sane amount of them). \''

column10: b"b' ok
column11: thanks for letting me know the solution. What version was this change put in?'"

column11: but we create multiple ChannelPipelineFactory objects. overall the code is simple just a HttpClient
column12: but when we close the client
column13: which does happen in the handler\'s messageReceived function the thread is leaked"'

column10: b'b\' Ok that is ok then.. Just make sure you not use to many ChannelFactory instances.. what you mean with thread is leaked ? It\\\'s normal that the thread will not get "released" and keeps running. Or do you say that it should be destroyed ?\''

column11: it was the ChannelFactory. A configuration setting was making the Client create a new "ChannelFactory" for every new client. We have been running the same code for a loooong but we upgraded Netty recently and saw this issue.\''

column10: b"b' Its correct as it need to notify any pending write that it has failed to complete. And it also fire the exceptionCaught so you know about this.'"

column11: then I get a
column12: otherwise I get nothing?  That doesn\'t make a lot of sense to me...  Especially because I\'m already handling an uncaught exception for this channel."'

column10: b'b\' Yeah that is exactly how it works... The problem is that we not know that you "close" the channel because of an exception so we need to keep it generic. What you could do is check if the cause of the exceptionCaught event is of type ClosedChannelException and if you closed the Channel by yourself before. If this is the case just ignore the exception and swallow it.\''
b'b" I did this instead: (@d964469b030ebd8aac61c95ec677073e4bec2f76) What still doesn\'t make sense to me is that the channel is already closed
column11: so whether or not there is still data in the buffer is irrelevant at this point
column12: it\'s too late anyway.  Not sure what the benefit of getting an extra is."'

column11: If I understood correctly
column12: the problem here is that is invoked with as well as the of the corresponding write attempt (i.e. double notifications.)  Is it correct? If so
column13: I agree with you that the exception that is local to a certain outbound request (e.g. close / write / setReadable) should not trigger event
column14: and I\'m going to change this behavior in Netty 4. However
column15: I\'m inclined to sticking to the odd behavior for Netty 3 due to backward compatibility reasons.  What do you think?"'

column10: b"b' So what do you think @trustin?'"
b"b' This should be fixed by #798'"
b"b' Fix exception handling'"
b'b" Previously
column11: if an exception is thrown in the handler\'s messageReceived method
column12: the same handlers exceptionCaught would not get called. This fixes that problem. It also fixes a bug in the WebSocketServerProtocolHandshakeHandler which was closing the socket without sending an error response when an exception was thrown. Instead
column13: the exception should propagate to the WebSocketServerProtocolHandler. (At least
column14: that\'s what the tests are expecting and that\'s what the tests were getting previously because of the exceptionCaught bug.)"'

column10: b"b' @mheath merged.. thanks!'"

b"b' This pull request does not address all cases.  Exceptions raised by a handler should be caught by a pipeline and the pipeline should trigger an exceptionCaught event for a proper handler.  The current behavior is to notify the next handler in the pipeline
column11: just like other inbound events.  It might be better notify the current handler as an exception.'"

column10: b"b' The patch itself looks fine though.  We just need more work. Reopened so that it is tracked.'"

column10: b"b' Add a line-based frame decoder with good performance.'"
b'b\' Using with has quadratic performance in the size of the input buffer.  Needless to say
column11: the performance degrades pretty quickly as the size of the buffer increases.  Larger MTUs or loopback connections can make it so bad that it appears that the code is "busy waiting"
column12: when in fact it\\\'s spending almost 100% of the CPU time in  . Add a new that decodes line-delimited frames in O(n) instead of  \\\'s O(n^2) implementation. In OpenTSDB\\\'s telnet-style protocol decoder this resulted in **throughput increases of an order of magnitude**. Change to automatically detect when the frames are delimited by line endings
column13: and automatically switch to using under the hood.  This means that all Netty applications out there that using the combo with will automatically benefit from the better performance of
column14: without requiring a code change.\''

column10: b'b\' A few notes:I couldn\\\'t test this change.  When I I get this error: " failed with message: Detected JDK Version: 1.6.0-37 is not in the allowed range [1.7.0
column11: )." \\xe2\\x80\\x93 is it really not possible to build 3.x with Java 6?!The relevant issue with OpenTSDB is #120The code change made to OpenTSDB that improved throughput by 10x to 20x is @9687ae9613c70849d669e9284694ee2abb2b2138 \\xe2\\x80\\x93 the performance difference is really dramatic.I thought it would be nice to automagically "transform" into a so that all apps doing line-delimited framing can immediately benefit from the faster code
column12: even if they don\\\'t update their code to use the new frame decoder.  I did not test that part of the code as I mentioned above.If this change is accepted
column13: it would be nice to update the documentation
column14: as line-delimited framing seems to be pretty common and used throughout Netty examples
column15: which people regularly copy-paste from.I already filed the copyright assignment with Netty but changed employer since then
column16: let me know if I need to re-sign it.\''

I think the default should be to "pass" the  to the next handler in chain. In the case of replace it would be the new. On remove it would just be the next. column11: we might see different behaviors between: vs  How about just raising an exception when  a handler if its  buffer is not empty?"'

column10: b'b\' Hmm.. yeah we could also raise an exception but I think this still makes it "hard" for the user to-do the right thing. So I still prefer what I suggest.  And yes the two examples will behave different but this is aspected.\''
b'b" I thought a little bit more about this and I think it can also make a handler malfunction because it will modify the indexes of a buffer.  For example
column11: the inbound data of the handler being removed will be prepended to the next handler\'s inbound buffer.  If the readerIndex of the next handler\'s inbound buffer is 0
column12: the next handler\'s inbound buffer\'s content must be moved to prepend the previous handler\'s data.  If the next handler has an index variable that keeps track of buffer position
column13: the next handler\'s internal state is messed up. We should not make an assumption that a user always knows what the next handler is
column14: so making it as the default behavior sounds unsafe."'

b"b' Now that we have a dedicated inbound buffer for all inbound handlers
column11: we can keep track of the number of readable bytes (or messages) in the inbound buffer.  Based on this information
column12: we can control the inbound traffic automatically to reduce the chance of dramatically. For dynamic control
column13: we could define a new interface like the following: and add property. The default implementation could be the one based on  watermark.'"

column10: b"b' This is actually only useful for the handler being executed in a non-I/O-thread (i.e. a user specified an EventExecutor when adding the handler to a pipeline).  It means only one or two handler(s) will need to set the traffic controller.  Then
column11: does it worth adding this property? Could we just provide a handler?'"

column10: b"b' Why is it only useful for non-I/O-Threads ?'"
b'b" My bad explanation.  It\'s also useful for the first handler in I/O thread.  However
column11: this whole issue might be of dubious value if bounded inbound buffer is supported correctly."'

column10: b"b' @trustin I agree ... If we have support for bounded inbound buffers we not need it anymore'"

column11: this feature could be employed to support bounded inbound buffers because can suspend traffic when the buffer becomes full.'"

column10: b"b' I think this should rather be implemented as a handler. Closing.'"
b'b" Let\'s say we have a pipeline like this (All handlers run in the same thread.) Usually
column11: an inbound handler is supposed to feed the next inbound buffer only when it was fed by its previous handler.  That is
column12: it produces only as much as it consumes.  It means determines the maximum possible capacity of the inbound buffer of B
column13: C
column14: and D.  Because an EventLoop does not push data beyond
column15: all handlers get softly bounded buffers only if A
column16: the first inbound handler
column17: has a bounded inbound buffer. Therefore
column18: I don\'t think we need this feature at all to implement soft-bounded inbound buffers; we already implemented it. Now
column19: let\'s think about the case where more than one are involved in the pipeline. Because B runs in a different thread than the thread that A runs in
column20: if B is busy doing a job taking longer than A
column21: it is possible that the capacity of B increases boundlessly.  Same problem applies when C feeds D.  We don\'t have this kind of problem when B feeds C because they run in the same thread. #### Solution has to suspend feeding A until the data it produced is consumed by B to some degree (completely ideally).  B also has to suspend feeding C until the data B (and C) produced is consumed by D. Also
column22: when B suspends feeding C
column23: also has to suspend feeding A
column24: because will grow boundlessly otherwise.  However
column25: B doesn\'t necessarily have to suspend feeding C/D when suspends feeding A. #### Implementation It is relatively simple to implement this feature. We can check if the closest bridge buffer is empty.  The bridge buffers are created only in B and D where the execution thread changes.  can check if the closest inbound bridge buffer (i.e.  ) is empty. If so
column26: it reads. Otherwise
column27: it reads later when the bridge buffer gets empty. Similarly
column28: B can check if the closest inbound bridge buffer (i.e.  ) is empty.  If so
column30: it leaves as-is and consumes it later when becomes empty. With this implementation
column31: A and B\'s are never invoked until B and D
column33: pulls the data from its inbound bridge
column34: effectively preventing B and D\'s inbound buffer capacity from growing boundlessly. #### Challenges We need to modify so that we can access the most adjacent inbound bridge at O(1).  Otherwise
column36: a pipeline has to iterate over all handlers
column37: even if all handlers run in the same thread."'

column10: b'b" Alternative way to implement: check if there\'s already a scheduled event in the pending task queue of B and D\'s  .  If so
column11: A and B don\'t no need to issue for B and D
column12: and A and B\'s shouldn\'t be invoked."'

b"b' Poor Oio performance'"

b"b' After observing sample socksproxy cpu usage when testing speed test using url  or url  I noticed that Nio utilises all bandwidth of my uplink channel 15Mbit/s up 15 Mbit/s down and Oio implementation only shows 160Kbit/s down and 2Mbit/s up'"
b"b' BTW when i switched on TCP_NODELAY on Oio version it speeds up upload nearly twice. Test speed for oio above is is already with switched on TCP_NODELAY'"
b"b' @bk1te I think the problem is the share of the same EventLoop for OIO. As one Channel may block the other.'"
b"b' why then sharing same eventloop does not affect nio implementation?'"

b"b' @bk1te because NIO is non blocking and so not block the EventLoop at all. In OIO every Channel has its own dedicated EventLoop exactly because of this. Anyway with the changes introduces in #965 you can see how adjusting the SO_TIMEOUT (this is the max time an IO operation will block in OIO) can affect performance. With latest master and the following changes I get nearly the same speed with NIO and OIO.  '"

column10: b"b' Encoders and Decoders may throw Exception after removed itself from ChannelPipeline'"

b"b' In our Encoders and Decoders we often poll from the MessageBuf to process messages one after each other. This is fine as long as the users implementation does not remove itself from the ChannelPipeline as this will free the MessageBuf and so () will throw an IllegalBufferAccessException.'"
b"b' Reopening to find less intrusive solution.'"

b"b' @trustin what about this idea: For every remove and replace method in ChannelPipeline we add another one that takes a boolean parameter which tells if the remaining bytes or messages should be dropped or forwarded to the next handler in the pipeline.  This way we can either clear the buf or transfer it contents to the next in the pipeline on removal /replace. So we not need  to take any extra steps on removal in the handler itself as after the  call we are sure the actual buffer of the handler is empty. We could discard the content of the buf by default ( when a method without the boolean argument is used). This will also fix #858 and so give the user less surprises.  I think I would go even futher and change all remove / replace methods to just  return the ChannelPipeline. WDYT?'"
b'b" also one think to keep in mind is how to handle the forwarding of the elemnts if we have a bounded buffer and it can\'t take all of them. Maybe a throwing a special exception is good enough?"'
b"b' As I commented in the commit
column11: I think we can just allow a user access the discarded data so that the user can forward it to the next buffer.  The question would be: how do we provide an access to the discarded data?  How about adding a parameter to so that the pipeline can flush the discarded data into the specified buffer?'"

column10: b'b\' This would work.. But I think we should also provide a shortcut for this with a boolean flag to just "forward" to the next handler.\''
b"b' Without shortcut: I guess this seems short enough
column11: no?'"

column10: b'b\' Maybe... Let just go with that and if we need something else we can process from here.. @trustin you want to "take it" or should I do later today ?\''
b'b" Please take this.  I\'ll review bounded buffer pull request.  :-)"'

b"b' Move exceptionCaught(..) and userEventTriggered(..) to ChannelStateHandler'"

b"b' While I was working on the Netty in Action book I notice something I would like to change in our current ChannelHandler hierarchy. So here we go. I think we should exceptionCaught(..) and userEventTriggered(..) to ChannelStateHandler (currently in ChannelHandler).  The main reasons are:1) These two callbacks will be called as result of ChannelInboundInvoker.\\\\* methods. All others callbacks that are called because of it are already part of ChannelStateHandler. So it is more consistent2) exceptionCaught(..) should never be called because of an outbound operation. For these the ChannelPromise must be failed if an error happens. So it is missleading to have it part of  ChannelHandler as ChannelOperationHandler and ChannelOutboundHandler extend it and so expose it.'"
b"b' @trustin wdyt ?'"
b'b\'  to moving those from "base" ChannelHandler to the "upstream" ChannelHandler
column11: that sounds find by me since they are "upstream" messages sry about the netty3 syntax
column12: not going to try to context swap this early in the morning :) Not sure I agree with the second statement you made though. exceptionCaught(..) can be called because of an outband operation and some Netty handlers rely on this -WriteTimeoutHandler for example\''

column10: b'b" I\'ve just applied to proposed fix to master via 0f8fbac9f8a57ee2a57b186f575652d66e2b4979.  We are not going to have a race condition you mentioned because Netty 4 makes sure the invocations on the same handler instance do not overlap."'
b"b' Codecs must not cache next buffer during processing'"

b"b' At the moment in our codec abstract base classes we cache the next buffer to write to during processing. This is bad as the user may modify the ChannelPipeline while we loop. So we must not cache it for this reason and as the read is non-valotile for the next buffer this change will not affect performance.'"
b'b" It\'s obviously a volatile read?"'
b"b' What exactly does the scenario / use case look like?  Why does a decoder modify the pipeline?'"

b'b\' Yeah sorry it is a volatile read I guess I need more  ;) The problem arise here: In this case the encodedMsg will be added not to the "new next handler" but the one that was present when flush(..) was called. Another way to fix this would to define a special Signal that could be used to notify the encoder that the pipeline was changed and only then update the cached one. WDYT ?\''

b"b' @trustin on the other hand we may just say that codecs should not do such a thing and make it clear in the javadocs. But I think I would prefer to make it work like expected (from the point of the user)'"
b"b' Can you also answer [this question]url '"
b'b" I\'m not sure why an encoder has to modify a pipeline.  It\'s simply beyond its role. This change doesn\'t really fix the problem either.  That is
column11: however often we check what the next outbound buffer is
column12: we will always face a race condition because the modification of a pipeline can occur in a different thread. I think the problem is that we do not prevent a user from modifying a pipeline at anytime and it keeps a handler from making any assumption about pipeline configuration at all
column13: which is too distracting from a handler implementor\'s standpoint.  We rather need to make pipeline behave in more predictable manner from a handler implementor\'s standpoint.  Let me try to come up with a better solution."'

column10: b'b" To support a bounded buffer everywhere
column11: a handler that fills the buffer must ensure there will be no overflow.  If the handler has to write more than the writable bytes of the destination buffer
column12: the handler must keep the unwritten bytes somewhere and continue filling the buffer when the buffer has a room (i.e. state management).  Rather than making most handlers\' code more complex
column13: I decided to make the buffer unbounded. Surely
column14: there must be a case where bounded buffers work fine
column15: and I\'d love to know what it exactly is and to see what I can do about it."'

column10: b'b" In my pipeline
column11: most handlers deal with message objects
column12: but the bytetomessage codecs have bounded buffers. Users can override the allocator which can return a buffer with a finite max capacity -even in the unbounded case
column13: the max capacity is really 2^31 since you use an int to represent the writer offset
column14: so the handlers that the user does not have control over should gracefully deal with bounded buffers. I\'m not sure if this means a shim in the API or modifications to Netty\'s default handlers
column15: but I don\'t think throwing an exception on ensureWritable is the right thing."'

column10: b'b\' Thanks for looking into this. Actually there is another potential issue. It\\\'s easier to work around it
column11: but still... The multipart encoder always adds a line to all simple attribute fields
column12: like this: Note that there is no real contentspecified (or necessary). Only the (default) encoding is provided.Many 3rd party web applications can handle this
column13: they are probably ignoring the Content-Type line. But some are not
column14: they complain about invalid content. The only way to avoid the rendering of the "Content-Type" line is by setting the charset property of the HttpData element to null. Unfortunately
column15: the standard setter doen\\\'t allow this. And the multipart decoder will always set the charset property to the default value (UTF-8). So by first reading and then writing a POST multipart message
column16: there is no straight forward way to avoid the "Content-Type" line in the rendered output.\''

Not giving this information could lead to misdecoding part on  side. This is not an option

column11: I run (V3 only since V4 is not functional for another issue) the upload test. And guess what? It does not work anymore because of the lack of URI encoding. How could it be? Well
column12: you pass as argument a value with "not legal" characters as in HTML unescaped
column13: then the parser will be broken on the opposite side. The example could be seen in "secondinfo" parameter ending with an extra \\\'&\\\'
column14: which is ok if URIencoded
column15: but not if not escaped. So what could be done is to allow name only to be "as is"
column16: but not value. Therefore
column17: the filename of a file transmitted through HTTP should be escaped (as it is a value) and unescaped on the opposite side. Did I missed something?\''

column11: I must admit not many handlers require a promise to handle a operation. An idea that comes out of my mind is:1. If a user specify as a promise
column12: Netty silently replaces it with a fake singleton promise.2. The fake singleton promise does nothing if not invoked by a user
column13: but if a user invokes a meaningful operation on it
column14: the fake singleton creates a new promise and store it in the thread-local variable
column15: and delegates all user requests to the new promise.3. The context implementation checks the thread-local variable if the current promise is the fake singleton
column16: replaces the fake with the newly created promise by the fake
column17: and remove the new promise from the thread-local variable..'"

Using it incurs instantiating the relevant wrapping  s which is expensive and would likely be redundant in many searches. Iterating over an array of and then over the actual bytes is bad encapsulation and terrible API (especially with those 2 abstract methods of the interface). What I\'m suggesting is an internal  over the bytes in  . The method would look like: It would receive an instance of the ( whatever) that would look something along the lines of: This is akin to Trove\'s [forEach]url  and [TIntProcedure]url  which are designed to save on Iterators instantiations in its highly efficient primitive collections (Trove of course has a variation of these TProcedure types for each primitive type). Trove also sports a for reverse order traversing which would also be a nice touch here (either via an alternative method or by using a boolean for the distinction). This would allow a fast iteration over the bytes with only checking for accessibility and boundaries once at the beginning

b'b" @trustin I thinks that\'s a very problematic suggestion. I can appreciate the economy of methods in this highly ubiquitous and already crowded interface
column11: however I think that the element of least surprise should prevail in this situation. In many cases these indices will be variables. Resolving the direction of the iteration based on a relation between the values of 2 variables will be very confusing. To repeat
column12: it\'s 2 fundamentally different behaviors based on variables and their sometimes unanticipated values. The _intent_ would certainly not be evident by reading the code (I\'d argue that in some cases would be deduced in a debugging session). Furthermore
column13: it would make it harder to receive these indices as parameters and raise the level of abstraction since guarding against illegal arguments becomes more subtle.the implicit constraint of the relationship between the values themselves breaks encapsulation. I\'d prefer any of the following:another methodanother direction argument (preferably an enum)another method that receives the aforementioned argument (having the original method going the obvious direction
column14: forward)giving up on backward traversal altogether"'

column10: b"b' The spec of  does not allow implementing it for composite byte buffer'"
b'b" In order for to be efficient when used on a composite byte buffer it needs to be implemented in  . The current spec
column11: however
column12: does not allow a correct implementation.An implementation of in  would find the component buffers matching the range that is requested to be scanned and then call on these component buffers. Assuming the did not throw the signal
column13: each call to on the component buffers will return -1. If you take into consideration the the can return values that are different than 1
column14: It is impossible to know how to proceed after the first call
column15: since it is not known what it is the next requested byte to process. For a  implementation that always returns 1
column16: the next byte to process will be the 1st byte of the following component
column17: but it in other cases it is not necessarily the case. I can think of few options to fix this:1. Change to return and not let the processor control the scanning. I don\'t like that because I think there can be very interesting use cases where the processor controls the scanning.2. return value is changed to be as follows: If the scanning stops by signal
column18: the last scanned index is returned otherwise the last index the processor requested to scan is returned. This could be either a negative number if exceeded the range from the \'left\' side or a number that is greater or equals to the length if it exceeded to the right. In this option you get to keep the existing functionality
column19: but is less usable because its users need to make two comparisons rather than just one
column20: and they need to use the length in this comparison.3. Similar to number 2
column21: but if the iteration exceeds the range the return value will be always negative (not necessarily -1). The usability of the method is not hurt
column22: the users just check for negative value rather than comparing to -1. Like in number 2
column23: if the scanning stops by signal
column24: the last scanned index is returned. Otherwise
column25: the returned value is a negative value that indicates the offset by which the scan exceeded the scanned range and whether it exceeded on the \'left\' side or the \'right\' side. The odd numbers indicate the scan exceeded on the \'right\' side
column26: and even numbers are used for exceeding on the \'left\' side\'. This option is a bit tricky for someone who wants to implement the interface
column27: but for users of the method it is as simple as the existing spec. Similar usage with negative return values is done in []url  T

column11: SSLHandler read the SSL packet length and aggregated the data until the entire packet had been received: if (() < packetLength) {  return null;} In Netty 4
column12: SSLHandler computes the packet length
column13: but then calls unwrap without aggregating the data. If the engine reads the available data and aggregates internally
column14: it will consume the header
column15: and on receiving the rest of the packet
column16: SSLHandler will try to compute the packet length again and throw an exception. SSLHandler should either aggregate the data as it did in Netty 3
column17: or track the packetLength and the bytesConsumed and only try to compute the packet length after completely consuming the previous packet.'"

column10: b"b' @jpinner I think the problem is that it is not removed yet when call writeAndFlush(...) and so the unwrapLater(...) will trigger another read and the handler is still in the pipeline. So the behavior of throwing the exception is correct
column11: I think what we need todo is to check if we are currently in the channelRead(...) of SslHandler and only then directly trigger a fireChannelRead(...). If not it need to execute it via the eventloop. The same is true for write(...) and wrapLater.'"

column10: b"b' I think the issue is in netty 3.x
column11: wrapNonAppData was not allowed to call unwrap if it was called by unwrap. This check has been removed in the Netty 4.'"

column10: b"b' Also in flush
column11: unwrap later was moved inside the try-catch-finally block which changes the order of writes and reads. In Netty 3 any writes were flushed before unwrap was called. In Netty 4 unwrap is called before the flush. Maybe the best thing to do is re-port SSLHandler now that the APIs for 3 and 4 are more similar?'"

column10: b'b\' @jpinner or maybe better idea... We could detect if the ChannelHandlerContext is still in the same method as the one that should be called and if so execute the "new" call via (...). This should guard also from the problem in other impls\''
b"b' BTW
column11: a bigger issue is that the above changes mean that the channelRead(msg) calls can get out of order. So at the handler that writes
column12: it sees channelRead(msg1)
column13: write(resp)
column14: which triggers channelRead(msg2)
column15: which now bypasses the removed handler so reaches the next one
column16: and now channelRead(msg1). Reordering.'"

b"b' Composite Buffer ignoring byte order'"

b'b" I ran into a problem with netty4: apparently the byte order gets ignored if you write a composite buffer down the channel handler. This results in sending **0070 000000FF** to the client instead of **7000 FF000000** I made a gist which illustrates the problem:url  Let me know if I can provide anything else
column11: this bug (?) won\'t let me continue to work on my server :( Regards!"'

column10: b'b" Seems like you have to write to the little endian view of a ByteBuf to get the expected behaviour. Writing to a default (big endian) ByteBuf and then using an acquired little endian view doesn\'t work
column11: see updated gist. This results in the expected behaviour **7000 FF000000** Is this expected? If so I think this should be documented! New gist: url  Edit: No clue what happened
column12: must have pressed some keys and closed the issue on accident."'

column10: b"b' Ok this is stupid... Creating a big endian buffer first and writing its bytes to a little endian buffer results in big endian byte order: Result: **0070 000000FF**'"

column10: b"b' Interrogation and suggestion on HTTP Multipart Body Codec'"
b'b" Hi
column11: I\'m currently trying to understand REST interface
column12: and it appears that lot of REST implementation using HTTP protocol are using body with more than just PUT
column13: POST
column14: PATCH requests. For instance
column15: some implementations are using GET with a multipart body
column16: while it is not largely implemented. But according to what I\'ve read
column17: it is allowed to have a BODY (and therefore a multipart request) for all type of HTTP requests excepting HEAD request. So my interrogation and suggestion are around to change the Multipart Codec to allow all type of HTTP requests
column18: excepting HEAD.But as I\'m not 100% sure of the correctness of this idea
column19: I\'m asking you guys what you think?"'

column10: b"b' Can you clarify -you would like to change the codec so that the response to all methods could have a body? or that the requests can have a body?'"
b'b\' I was talking about request only
column11: since response could have all a body (except HEAD). On request side
column12: according to what I\\\'ve read
column13: all requests are allowed to have a body (while HEAD restriction is in fact only on response as for 1xx
column14: 204 and 304 response code
column15: see 4.3 and 4.4 and 9 in RFC 2616
column16: also in RFC 1945 section 7.2).A form can be done using get or post (maybe also put) as method name. I read that GET request could use the body to send arguments instead of only URI (for instance when the URI length is too long
column17: the request is then chunked using body as for a POST request
column18: turning the GET into an "almost" POST request
column19: except the semantic of the action -idempotent-). Therefore
column20: I was thinking that a request could have a body to decode (multipart body)
column21: as for POST or PUT or PATCH currently in the codec. But it could be also necessary for GET (as form allows the Get as format)
column22: but maybe also DELETE. For instance
column23: in HttpPostRequestDecoder
column24: we have: It might be needed to only test if method is not equal to  (except that HEAD request can have a body
column25: while HEAD response cannot...). Same for HttpPostRequestEncoder: I\\\'ve read a lot of REST documentation
column26: and it seems they allow to use a BODY part in the request in order to send information along with the request (so in addition to the URI request arguments). Some ideas:The detection should be done checking the presence of the Content-Length or Transfer-Encoding header field in the request\\\'s message-headers for instance.Of course
column27: this change could imply to change the class name
column29: like creating a parent class HttpBodyRequestDecoder
column30: from which HttpPostRequestDecoder will be an extension (might be an empty extension) to preserve compatibility. I might be totally wrong
column31: I\\\'m more in a thinking process
column32: and therefore try to understand what is correct or not...\''

column10: b'b" According to RFC2616 Sec 4.3
column11: a message body MUST NOT be included in a request if the method does not allow sending an entityOPTIONS
column12: POST
column13: and PUT are mentioned in Sec. 9 to have origin-bodies and lots of software (proxies
column14: gateways
column15: etc.) reject GET
column16: HEAD
column17: and DELETE when message bodies are included -an example: telnet  80Trying 74.125.239.128...Connected to .Escape character is \'^]\'. GET / Host: Content-Length: 1  400 Bad RequestContent-Type: ; charset=UTF-8Content-Length: 925Date: Mon
