Your client has issued a malformed or illegal request.  That\\xe2\\x80\\x99s all we know.Connection closed by foreign host."'

column10: b'b\' I agree that most of the Web servers do not allow such methods. But according to RFC 2616: So the web servers should not answer 400 or whatever
column11: but ignoring such body. However
column12: can you give me the exact place where GET
column13: HEAD and DELETE do not accept entity body? I\\\'m pretty sure there is no such place where it is defined.In chapter 5
column14: nothing is written to say wheter GET
column15: HEAD or DELETE do not allow such Body. On the opposite
column16: it is written is is allowed for all requests: On the same side
column17: can you give me any reference where PUT
column18: POST
column19: PATCH must have a body? The only place where I saw something is: Section 9.2 for OPTIONS "If the OPTIONS request includes an entity-body (as indicated by the presence of Content-Length or Transfer-Encoding)
column20: ..." And in the REST model
column21: GET and POST (or PUT) have not the same meaning. To make a READ data request
column22: we might need to pass more arguments than GET URI length allow
column23: and therefore using BODY and POST
column24: is against the correct meaning of POST in REST mode and only because HTTP servers does not allow Body in GET?And by the way
column25: it seems Apache and PHP accept BODY in GET requests... So I reopen the request
column26: not to force the change but to still get more advices... since I\\\'m not convince.\''

column10: b"b' There are references to request-bodies in Sec 9 for only OPTIONS
column11: POST
column12: and PUT. Unfortunately this has meant inconsistent behaving for handling message bodies on other methods. While HTTPbis is trying to clarify this (see url  and require that the indication for message bodies are independent of the method
column13: interoperability is poor. Not all servers accept them
column14: but more critically
column15: some intermediaries (including transparent ones) drop or fail to forward to the body. So not only is their acceptance unreliable
column16: but you may not be able to consistently send bodies to servers that do accept them if you are on an unencrypted connection (or a network with monitored traffic).'"

column10: b'b\' This might be a good reason: transparent intermediaries that failed or removed those body parts. Reading again and again the 2616 or the current draft of ietf
column11: no mention is made at all on request-bodies
column12: except only for OPTIONS... Neither POST or PUT or GET or DELETE or PATCH... I read also a lot of blogs saying the same
column13: that HTTP is not wel defined on this point and in fact allows those ways
column14: even if not implemented everywehere (except in Apache and PHP). So the only reason to keep POST and PUT and OPTIONS would be to ensure that "incorrect implementation" outside will not break the correct behavior? Is this not a little bit a wrong argument ? Because others are doing less
column15: we need to do also less...? Well
column16: in this case
column17: I believe we would have never moved to HTTP 1.1... In the Netty decoder
column18: we do have PATCH (which is not part of  right) and we do not have OPTIONS? Why?In the Netty coder
column19: we only allow POST
column20: while PUT and PATCH are allowed in decoder. Why?I\\\'m probably the root cause of this limitations since when I first wrote the very initial version of this codec
column21: I was believing that only POST was allowed to have body request. But now
column22: I\\\'m not anymore so sure... I\\\'m not asking that everyone is making GET or DELETE with Body request
column23: but if it could be interesting that Netty allows it
column24: since it seems not forbidden.After all
column25: Netty is a programming library
column26: and we may add something like "allowedMethods" in the constructor of the Codecs such that anyone could use as  wants? Sorry to push a little bit more further the discussion
column27: but I believe we need to ensure the reason why we allow or not such or such part in our codecs. Intermediaries could be a correct argument
column28: but maybe not enough.And at least
column29: we will need to ensure that Encoder and Decoder are following the same idea (which is not yet). WDYT?\''

column10: b'b\' Don\\\'t worry about pushing -I\\\'m happy to have the discussion. The relevant statement in the RFC is: "A message-body MUST NOT be included in a request if the specification of the request method (section 5.1.1) does not allow sending an entity-body in requests. A server SHOULD read and forward a message-body on any request; if the request method does not include defined semantics for an entity-body
column11: then the message-body SHOULD be ignored when handling the request." Unfortunately the only parts of section 9 that mention an entity-body are OPTIONs in sec 9.2 and POSTs and PUTs that refer to the "enclosed entity" in sections 9.5 and 9.6. The result has been that intermediates that are not fully compliant (that do not implement all SHOULDs) have been known to drop these and treat the bodies as a pipelined request. It might be useful to separate this into what the decoder should accept vs what the encoder should emit. I could understand making an argument that the decoder should be prepared to accept more methods with a body than POST
column12: but I believe this is separate from whether or not the encoder should emit a body for any method.\''

column10: b"b' Ok
column11: just to fix some ideas
column12: I propose the smallest change I can think of.The idea is that by default
column13: only POST
column14: PUT
column15: PATCH and OPTIONS are allowed (now in both Encoder and Decoder).And one must call the excplicit constructor with True for unlimitedMethod to allow any kind of Methods. I believe that doing this way might be a good compromise. WDYT?'"

column10: b"b' Of course
column11: same change should be done in V3 if this is the right way...I pause to know what all you guys think about this...'"

b'b\' @trustin @normanmaurer After investigating the problem better
column11: I find out that SslEngine (always?) outputs an 1 byte "message" after the first unwrap call for a  package. That is
column12: it returns the following HandshakeStatus: "Status = OK HandshakeStatus = NOT_HANDSHAKING bytesConsumed = 37 bytesProduced = 1". I don\\\'t know if they () can change this SslEngine behavior. In order to achieve this behavior I had to change the SslHandler#decode method as it explicitly "splits" the  package processing after computing its length with getEncryptedPacketLength method. What do I suggest? Instead of notify immediately the next handler (after an SslEngine#unwrap call)
column13: wait until the input buffer is processed (as much as possible) by the SslEngine (i.e. call SslEngine#unwrap multiple times before sending an message). I am not sure how difficult this change is because SslHandler is an complex class
column14: but I believe it can be done introducing a loop inside SslHandler#unwrap (right now the loop is on FrameDecoder#callDecode). I believe this change will increase SshHandler efficiency. If you deliberate it is not a simple change
column15: maybe it can be done on Netty 4/5.\''

column10: b'b" I took a close look on this issue today and found the following:SSLEngine always split data into two (or more) SSL records into 1 byte + (N-1) bytes records due to CBC vulnerabilitySometimes the two records are not read into a single buffer
column11: especially when the second buffer is large enough.In such a case
column12: doesn\'t have other choices than just decoding the first record and then waiting for the second record arrives fully.  This triggers a event with a single byte message. But
column13: it the length of the message you send isn\'t really large
column14: why is this happening at the early stage of the connection?  It\'s because Netty starts with small receive buffer and then increases or decreases the capacity of the receive buffer dynamically.  If you generate traffic continuously
column15: you will see that this problem disappears by itself
column16: because Netty will automatically increase the capacity of the buffer. If you have some estimates on the minimum length of your messages
column17: you could raise the initial capacity of the receive buffer by providing a new when you configure a channel. e.g. In Netty 4: For instance
column18: if I set RCVBUF_ALLOCATOR to new AdaptiveRecvByteBufAllocator(32768
column21: I don\'t see the split anymore."'

column10: b"b' Optimize ByteBuf implementations'"

b'b\' Our ByteBuf implementations have some great potential for improvements by reduce the sub-classing etc of them and remove abstract methods and so on.  This allows for better inlining. At the moment even if we are able to inline such an abstract method as in AbstractByteBuf offered we have the overhead of typechecks on each call. As ByteBuf is one of the "key" players we should make sure it is as fast as possible. This also includes to optimize methods for common pattern so they are small enough for inline.\''

b"b' Another issue is the hierarchy. We have a too many implementations to allow for optimal inlining. Seems like the JIT can handle classes with 2 impls the best (when it comes to more then one impl). See also: url '"
b"b' Let me close this...'"

b"b' Allow (optional) notification when reading with no data available'"
b'b" Would it make sense to add something like a option that would cause to be called after _any_ read attempts complete
column11: regardless of whether any data was actually available? Some background: [APNs]url  is Apple\'s push notification service. They use their own protocol
column12: and the gist is that successful writes go unacknowledged
column13: but if something goes wrong
column14: the APNs server will write an error code than immediately close the connection. I\'m writing an APNs client with Netty
column15: and a [race condition]url  was discovered where writing to the remotely-closed channel could cause the bytes on the inbound buffer to be lost (see #1952). The resolution to #1952 was to add an option (see c7b66545). That is
column16: I think
column17: necessary to resolve the issue
column18: but perhaps not sufficient to resolve it completely. As [discussed on Stack Overflow]url  we think there\'s still a race condition. If we turn off and do this: \\xe2\\x80\\xa6it appears that there\'s no guarantee that the read operation will be completed before the channel is closed. As @trustin pointed out in that thread
column19: we can rely on the method to let us know when we pulled data from the buffer. Unfortunately
column20: it doesn\'t appear that there\'s any mechanism for indicating that a read attempt has completed if there\'s no data in the inbound buffer."'

column10: b'b" Sending nothing to acknowledge the reception of a message sounds quiet weird to me.  How long should you wait until you are sure you did not read anything?  You could wait for 1 second to say yes
column11: but the APNS server might notify you the failure in 1.01 second.  Theoretically
column12: there is no guaranteed way to tell if the APNS received the messages. It\'s very likely Netty will attempt to read from the channel before APNS sends anything and almost always report there was nothing to read
column13: considering the latency between your application and the APNS server.  Therefore
column14: adding the proposed notification mechanism will never solve the problem.  One practical way to handle this is to keep the list of the sent messages for N seconds
column15: and if an APNS server tells you one of them were not processed successfully
column16: you could re-send the failed message and update the timestamp of the message in the list.  Until the message expires after the N seconds
column17: you could say the message is \'probably\' sent successfully."'

column10: b'b\' No contest there ;)Well
column11: that\\\'s mostly true*. But that\\\'s not actually the problem we\\\'re trying to solve here. The proximate issue goes something like this: we\\\'re happily sending messages to the APNs gateway
column12: and message 1 of 3 has some problem. The APNs gateway writes a 6-byte explanation of the problem and then closes the connection. On our end
column13: we keep writing. Message 2 of 3 goes out the door before the APNs  reaches us
column14: and then the timing works out that we write message 3 of 3 after the connection has been closed
column15: but before we\\\'ve read the response from the APNs gateway. This triggers an on write
column16: which
column17: prior to the introduction of the option in c7b6654
column18: would mean that the connection would close immediately and we\\\'d lose the response from the APNs gateway. (EDIT: To clarify
column19: the consequence would be that we\\\'d think there was just some temporary I/O problem sending message 3 of 3
column20: but the reality is that message 1 was rejected for a specific reason and message 2 was never handled by the gateway.) Now
column21: the thing gets us most of the way there
column22: which is great. What we want to do now when we get an on write is to read from the connection
column23: then close the connection once we\\\'re sure we\\\'ve got everything. The challenge at this point is that channel reading and channel closure are not guaranteed to happen serially. In cases where the APNs gateway rejects a message
column24: we\\\'ll always have data in the inbound buffer when we try to read
column25: and can count on to fire and then use that as the signal to close connection. There are no issues here; we can just wait for to happen to guarantee an order of operations. The problem arises because we could have received an for another reason. In those cases
column26: we will _not_ have any data in the inbound buffer. Calling doesn\\\'t call any method if no data is read. In the no-data case
column27: we have no way to guarantee the order of operations. We can\\\'t tell if there\\\'s no data because the buffer is empty or because we just haven\\\'t read it yet. So that\\\'s the issue. I\\\'m not suggesting that we use empty-read notifications as a mechanism for determining that there\\\'s no data (which I agree is completely bonkers)
column28: but I AM suggesting that the change trades one race condition for another
column29: and I\\\'m looking for a way to guarantee an order of operations. Forgive me if this particular suggestion is overly prescriptive; I\\\'m very open to other ways of doing it. I respectfully request that you re-open the issue (perhaps with a different summary)
column30: because I think this is (a) an actual issue in Netty and (b) an issue that can be solved. Even though it\\\'s the unorthodox design of APNs that has brought the issue to my attention
column31: I have to imagine that there other applications out there that need to make sure an inbound buffer is empty before cleaning up after an  . Thanks kindly! (\\\\* For the curious
column32: one thing we can do to figure out what\\\'s been processed is to send a known-bad message to the APNs gateway and wait for the gateway to complain and close the connection. That way
column33: we can be reasonably confident that everything sent before that message was "good" because the gateway didn\\\'t complain and everything after wasn\\\'t processed. We do indeed maintain a buffer of previously-sent messages.)\''

column10: b"b' The problem in general is that when a write exception occurs we want to read from the socket and then close it. As of right now
column11: netty cannot guarantee that auto read will fire before the close happens.  The following code does exactly what we want but it requires using the unsafe object (which from the netty docs is ill advised): When the writeFuture fires the operationComplete method and an exception occurred
column12: we read from the unsafe object and then close the channel. How do we implement the above without touching the unsafe object?'"

column10: b'b" If I understood correctly
column11: the problem is: there\'s no way to tell Netty to perform at least one read() operation on a channel before closing a channel.  If there\'s something left in the socket buffer
column12: you can ensure that by waiting for a event
column13: but if there\'s nothing left in the socket buffer
column14: there\'s no way to ensure read() operation is performed before the channel is closed.  Is this correct?"'

column10: b'b" From Netty\'s perspective
column11: it doesn\'t necessarily have to perform operation
column12: but just need to call to see if there\'s anything to read before  .  Unfortunately
column13: there\'s no way to enforce this because is always immediate in Netty (except for the workaround that uses the unsafe API.)"'

column10: b'b" Possible solutions:Ensure the channel is closed always after selecting channels and processing the selected channels at least once. This will introduce a little bit of latency and some users might not want to read anything before closing the channel.Provide a functionality that allows a user to schedule an arbitrary task _after_ at least one I prefer this solution but not sure yet how to expose this via the EventExecutor interface. Both solutions will not trigger a event when there\'s nothing to read
column11: but they all will ensure that Netty checks if there\'s something to read _before_ closing the channel. Would this work for you?"'

column10: b'b" That\'s exactly what we need.  I\'m not too concerned about the channelReadComplete. Just to confirm (with either solution):  1.) if we\'re waiting on a closeFuture
column11: and there is something to read
column12: our  will be called
column13: and once it finishes
column14: the closeFuture will be marked as complete2.) If we\'re waiting on a closeFuture
column15: and there is nothing to read
column16: the closeFuture will be marked as complete (and the decoder will obviously not be called)."'

b'b\' I\\\'m currently using netty-3.8.0.final. I\\\'m not sure whether this is a bug or a result of strict protocol validation. I\\\'m using Apache httpmime library for Http multipart request. It works fine when sending files named in English; however
column11: my netty-based Http API server keeps throwing an exception with "Needs a boundary value" message when sending files named in Korean. I looked over the source code and I figured out where the exception came from: getMultipartDataBoundary method. When I set the charset value for the MultipartEntity in the client program
column12: the length of the boundary array in getMultipartDataBoundary method was bigger than 2; the contentType argument contained a charset value after a boundary value. (i.e. contentType: "content-type=.... ; boundary=...; charset=utf-8") I modified the source code and it worked fine. Here\\\'s the original implementation: // Check if Post using "-data; boundary=89421926422648"String[] headerContentType = splitHeaderContentType(contentType);if (headerContentType[0].toLowerCase().startsWith()    && headerContentType[1].toLowerCase().startsWith()) {  String[] boundary = (headerContentType[1]
column13: \\\'=\\\');  if ( != 2) {    throw new ErrorDataDecoderException("Needs a boundary value");  }  return "" + boundary[1];} else {  return null;} Here\\\'s my implementation: // Check if Post using "-data; boundary=89421926422648"String[] headerContentType = splitHeaderContentType(contentType);if (headerContentType[0].toLowerCase().startsWith()    && headerContentType[1].toLowerCase().startsWith()) { } else {  return null;} As mentioned earlier
column14: it might be because of the strict implementation of the standard specification or something. Please take a look and comment on this issue :)\''

b"b' CastClassException when using ().addListener()'"
b'b\' I was doing this one day: Then: For reasons
column11: the listenChannel might be null
column12: so I do a little trick here.  Once both callbacks run
column13: then I will call \\\'notifyStopped\\\' and all will be well. This compiles without problems
column14: but fails in a mysterious way with this stack trace::  cannot be cast to   at c5$7$1.operationComplete(:577)  at (:621)  at $4.run(:610)  at (:354)  at (:348)  at $2.run(:101)  at (:744) So looking at it
column15: turns out that the second call:      ().addListener(listener); Is a mistake! () returns "ChannelGroupFuture"
column16: but addListener() has the type signature of GenericFutureListener>.  This leads the compiler to think you can use a ChannelFutureListener
column17: but this isn\\\'t true
column18: since at runtime there is a cast that is failing.  As an aside
column19: the listener confuses java8 a bit
column20: and you cant use lambdas
column21: because the resulting type isnt ChannelFuture
column22: its this GenericFutureListener and requires casting before we can call channel() or whatnot.\''

b"b' Sending 100 Continue response for request with Expect: 100-continue'"

b'b\' Netty version: 5.0.0.Alpha2 Context:Working on a project that uses LittleProxy (see url  and url  which is in turn based on Netty. By default LittleProxy creates a pipeline where all inbound handlers come first
column11: then all outbound handlers
column12: e.g.:BytesReadMonitorHttpRequestDecoderRequestReadMonitorHttpObjectAggregatorResponseWrittenMonitorHttpResponseEncoderBytesWrittenMonitor This works fine for both incoming and outgoing messages. Except the case of "Expect: 100-continue"  request. The "Expect: 100-continue" request is processed in HttpObjectAggregator handler
column13: and to send back the "100 Continue" response it searches for outbound handler backwards from current element (i.e. from HttpObjectAggregator)
column14: not from end of the list
column15: as done for all other responses. The search falls through the beginning of the pipeline
column16: and causes an exception and dropped client connection. I believe
column17: HttpObjectAggregator should follow the same handler lookup procedure for "100 Continue" response as for any other responses i.e. check all outbound handlers backward from the end of pipeline. I\\\'m not listing the steps two reproduce the issue that would involve setting up LittleProxy (or equivalent proxy-like service) on top of Netty
column18: which is tedious. For minimal Netty-specific use case see the added unit test. JDK version
column19: Operating system
column20: Network configuration not relevant.\''

column10: b"b' No I think you just need to put the HttpResponseEncoder before the HttpObjectAggregator'"
b"b' Build result for #2383 at cc2b44ad042daeac8f8af6ca24b1303f15f34635: [Success]url '"
b'b" That\'s a workaround
column11: but not a fix. Netty API does not imply that outbound handlers should come before inbound handlers in the pipeline to work. Actually
column12: I bet most of the time people would naturally list inbound handlers first like LittleProxy
column13: or code sample from Netty\'s own javadoc does (see url "'

column10: b"b' In fact
column11: shorter and probably cleaner way to fix it would be to call .writeAndFlush() on the pipeline
column12: rather than on current context. Pushing that minor change...'"

column10: b"b' Build result for #2383 at cc4edc5fa056a426a410594322a624f0c1b7a213: [Success]url '"

b"b' @died103times I disagree and in fact you are one of the firsts that suggested to add inbound handlers before inbound handlers. Even in our examples we add outbound before inbound handlers. I think it makes perfect sense to write from the position of the current handler in this case and also is better in terms of performance if you have a lot of handlers in the pipeline.'"

b'b\' "Suggested to add inbound handlers before inbound handlers"? What do you mean? So far every piece of code using Netty I\\\'ve seen was adding inbound handlers before outbound handlers. LittleProxy being one example of that. I\\\'ve picked up couple of projects from the url  at random:Forest adds decoder (inbound) first
column11: then encoder (outbound). See url Teiid same
column12: decoder first
column13: then encoder. See url  In Netty\\\'s examples: no
column14: you also have decoder coming first
column15: followed by encoder see javadoc for ChannelPipeline class. Would you care to explain how using different workflows to send "100 Continue" response and every other type of response back to client is making perfect sense? What is so special about "100 Continue"? Performance: If you have a lot of handlers in the pipeline
column16: it would actually take longer to find a handler if you add them in the order you suggest. Inbound handlers are looked up from beginning to the end of the pipeline
column17: and outbound in the opposite direction.\''

column10: b'b" This change will break any applications whose pipeline contains an handler that translates an HTTP message into another HTTP message (e.g. compression
column11: header manipulation
column12: etc) after the aggregator.  The reason it calls instead of is to ensure that the outbound event is handled only by the handlers placed before the current handler. If lacks the documentation about the ordering of handlers
column13: we should add some.  However
column14: this fix changes how our handlers usually works and will introduce the compatibility issues with other applications.  Sorry
column15: but I\'m not sure we are going to accept this pull request."'

column10: b'b\' This change is very specific: it only affects how specific handler HttpObjectAggregator writes specific response 100 Continue. The "100 Continue" response is very simple it\\\'s actually just one line: " 100 Continue". So
column11: there\\\'s no body to compress
column12: no headers to manipulate. Just a status code. I don\\\'t see how this change could possibly break something. On the contrary the LittleProxy case I have described earlier gives a very good real-life example how current behavior of HttpObjectAggregator breaks an application. Would you care to provide a realistic example of how this change breaks an application?\''

column10: b"b' Native memory leak in akka-remote based on Netty 3.8.0'"

b'b" We have a cluster of 50 nodes communicating through [akka-remote]url  (the code is [here]url  if you are interested) based on Netty 3.8.0 and we experience the following problem:The messages are 1-3 MB in sizeThe rate is up to 10 msg/sAll the processes run with  Heap dump tells that the heap is almost freetells that there is almost no direct memory allocated (under 40 MB)And at the same time some processes occupy 20 GB (based on in  ) and others hold 2-3 GB  The leaking processes have one thing in common -they produce high outgoing traffic to tens of other nodes.  This issue is somewhat similar to #2096.  Are there any ideas to consider? We have some alternative transport not using Netty and don\'t experience any similar problems with it
column11: so it is definitely not the application."'

column10: b'b" Sorry
column11: it seems that YourKit doesn\'t show memory correctly. I should have used MBean."'

column10: b'b" @incubos so it was not \'nettys fault\' ?"'

b'b" I didn\'t say that. I will reopen the issue after some deeper investigation if it is a Netty fault. It seems that direct buffers start leaking when there are some network flaps and the node can\'t connect to other nodes (we simulated it)."'
b"b' @incubos alright... let me know once you have more details.'"
b"b' @normanmaurer Sure. Thank you. Sorry for the premature disturbance.'"
b"b' After some investigation I confirm that there is a native memory leak on the nodes generating huge TCP traffic (up to 10 GB per hour) using Netty-based Akka remoting:  s occupy less then 20 MB
column11: heap size is under 1 GB and in up to 20 GB.I have only two ideas now:It is a strange memory fragmentation issue caused by possible reallocation of direct byte buffers (we are going to try to force to use to verify it)It is a JVM bug By the way
column12: shows that there are many regions of 64 MB and 128 MB allocated by process.Any ideas where to look into?'"

column10: b"b' Memory leak is not reproduced on JRE 7u5. So it seems to be a JVM bug.Closing the issue.'"
b"b' Thanks for the feedback'"
b"b' @incubos just one question... what java version you saw the problem with? Just in case someone reports the same issue.'"
b"b' @normanmaurer we are able to reproduce the problem using java 7u51 and 7u45'"
b'b" Although Netty tries to deallocate direct buffers as soon as possible wherever possible
column11: the life cycle of direct buffers are managed by JVM primarily
column12: and the direct buffers that were not deallocated explicitly (using the Cleaner hack) will only be deallocated when JVM\'s heap is under pressure. (Why does JVM free direct buffers when heap is under pressure? Don\'t ask me.) Therefore
column13: it is important to tune your JVM\'s memory configuration carefully so that direct buffers are freed sooner.  For example
column14: you could adjust NewSize
column15: MaxNewSize
column16: or NewRatio
column17: etc.  Unfortunately
column18: I\'m not really an expert on this matter. Your mileage might vary."'

column10: b"b' Reducing memory usage for HTTP/2'"
b'b\' Motivation: The connection
column11: priority tree
column12: and  flow controllerseach maintain a separate map for stream information. This is wastefuland complicates the design since as streams are
column13: multiplestructures have to be updated. Modifications:Merging the priority tree into Http2Connection. Then we can use  Http2Connection as the central stream repository.Adding observer pattern to Http2Connection so flow controllers can be  told when a new stream is created
column14: closed
column15: etc.Adding properties for  state to Http2Stream.  This allows the controller to access flow control state directly from  the stream without requiring additional structures.Separate out the StreamRemovalPolicy and created a "default"  implementation that runs periodic garbage collection.  This used to be  internal to the outbound flow controller
column16: but I think it is more general  than that. Result: HTTP/2 classes will require less storage for new streams.\''

column10: b"b' Re: linear search PoolSubpage is a node in a linked list of available subpages of the same elemSize.  i.e. All subpages in the list will have at least one slice left.  Removal of full subpage is O(1) and adding the unfull subpage back to the list is also O(1).'"
b"b' sure
column11: nice idea. I was thinking about balancing allocs
column12: say round robin on the list. (which is implemented on an array
column13: so not really O(1)) we can do that in a separate patch. Especially
column14: if it appears that lists have no additional overhead on perf.'"

column10: b"b' before CI could u please rerun the test suite that was failing for u (on linux) with these changes. thanks to give more insight into why I wanted balanced allocs is this worst case scenario.Say we have 1 poolsubpage that is full
column11: it is removed from the lista subpage is free
column12: it is added back
column13: this flip-flopping can keep happening.further removing need not be O(1) because u can take linear time to find the element in the list and then (if it is doubly linked list) then O(1) to remove it then
column14: addition can always be O(1) if we just add at head or tail. sorry
column15: I do not know any specialized java datastructs that can do both addition/ removal in O(1) time'"

column10: b"b' (...) should use correct EventLoop to notify on late registration'"

b"b' At the moment (...) will always use the GlobalEventExecutor to notify the returned ChannelFuture if the registration is not done yet. This should only be done if the registration fails later. If it completes successful we should just notify with the EventLoop of the Channel.'"
b"b' This fix does not appear to work in all cases. E.g. try running () in the Vert.x 3.0 test suite I believe in the case that the bind fails
column11: the event gets delivered on a global executor thread not the event loop.'"

b'b" Hi Norman
column11: In some cases the bind listener is still being called on the wrong thread (with Netty 4.0.2.4.final)E.g. let\'s say listen was originally called from eventloop1
column12: then some time later eventloop2 adds a listener on the same bind future
column13: then the second listener is called with eventloop1 not eventloop2 as expected. (I think it\'s a general principle that any handler should be called on the same event loop as the loop that sets the listener).You can replicate this in vert.x core as explained here:url (set the param to true and run the test)Cheers"'

column10: b"b' @Scottmitch1 The first draft of the HTTP/2 code had a separate class for each HTTP/2 frame type
column11: which were  in the standard Netty way.  The reasoning behind departing from this model was to reduce the number of intermediate object allocations. Since in most cases HTTP/2 frames will immediately be converted into some other object type (e.g. HttpRequest)
column12: it seemed best to leave the class as abstract and add specific implementations later. Does that answer your question?'"

column11: the HTTP/2 code doesn\'t yet have an adaptation layer  Netty HttpObject
column12: but that would be a welcome contribution! :)"'

column10: b"b' ChannelOutboundBuffer can cause data-corruption because of caching ByteBuffers'"

b"b' We cache the ByteBuffers in () for the Entries in the ChannelOutboundBuffer to reduce some overhead. The problem is this can lead to data-corruption if an incomplete write happens and next time we try to do a non-gathering write. To fix this we should remove the caching which does not help a lot anyway and just make the code buggy.'"
b'b" Well
column11: the cache won\'t help if the network is not congested enough.  However
column12: if it\'s under load and gathering writes are often incomplete
column13: this change will result in unnecessarily repetitive iteration.  Why don\'t you fix the cache?"'

column10: b"b' @trustin I thought about this... doing it in remove(...) but was worried that there may be still some chances for a race if the user for example call discardSomeReadBytes() etc.'"
b'b" If a user calls mutative operations on the flushed buffers
column11: isn\'t that a user\'s fault?"'

column10: b'b" For instance
column11: we update the readerIndex of the flushed buffers in our write loop.  I think it\'s better assuming that a user does not touch the flushed buffer
column12: but let me know if I\'m missing something."'

column10: b"b' @trustin hmm yeah I guess you are right. Ok let me adjust the fix to try to fix up the cache. '"
b"b' @trustin thanks for the review :)'"
b"b' No worries
column11: dude. :-)'"

column10: b"b' @trustin I think there is a problem with fixing up the cache after thinking about it. Here is the problem: write(ByteBuf)
column11: write(CompositeByteBuf)
column12: flush is calleda partial write happens that partially write the CompositeByteBuf (that is backed by two ByteBuffer).flush is called again which tries again to write the CompositeByteBuf but now goes not through nioBuffers() as it is the only ByteBuf in the ChannelOutboundBufferagain it is only a partial write. write(ByteBuf)
column13: flush is called which now tries to use nioBuffers() and so obtains a  which has not the correct position set as the previous write was done without nioBuffers() So the easiest fix would be to not cache ByteBufs with nioBuffersCount() @trustin WDYT ?'"

column10: b"b' ups closed by mistake'"

b'b" Not caching if nioBuffersCount() It sounds to me that the problem is: isn\'t always invoked by a transport and thus there\'s no way to  the cache easily.  Why don\'t we just add something that updates the cache on partial write so that  transport calls it?  We could simply invalidate the cache there
column11: but I think we can do a better job hopefully."'

column10: b"b' We could actually update the cache in  ?'"

b"b' @trustin after thinking more about it I think the whole idea of caching is flawed here because to have this work we must be use that internalNioBuffer(...) returns the same instance of the ByteBuffer all the time as otherwise the position() may not be updated correctly. Because of this we can also encounter this corruption when a DuplicatedByteBuf or SwappedByteBuf is written (as these we have internalNioBuffer(...) delegate to nioBuffer(...).  That said I think the best thing is to remove the cache as it will only give a slightly performance penalty if you use CompositeByteBuf. When writing normal ByteBuf the performance should be the same or maybe even better as we remove some branches in nioBuffers(). So to summarize I think the fix here is the correct way to handle all cases. '"
b'b" I\'m not sure what exactly problem is. We can keep the references to  s and update their positions.  There\'s no reason to call more than once
column11: because it is cached.  When updating the cache
column12: you only remove a fully written buffer or update the position of the partially written buffer from (or you could also move the buffer to the field when it is the last buffer in the array) Let me know if there\'s a reason to call or more than once for a during a write operation."'

b'b" @normanmaurer and I had a brief chat on this issue.  Here\'s the quick summary: **N**: Data corruption is expected to occur when a transport implementation mixes non-gathered writes and gathered writes while dealing with partial writes.**T**: We can fix that by fixing the transport implementation who made that mistake.  No need to disable caching in ChannelOutboundBuffer.**N**: That\'s true.  However
column11: it is error-prone because any transport can make the same mistake.**T**: Yeah
column12: we need to improve the API design of ChannelOutboundBuffer
column13: but removing the optimization we had just because of increased complexity isn\'t a good idea."'

column10: b"b' @normanmaurer will come up with a new short term fix for 4.0.22.Final.  Once 4.0.22.Final is released
column11: we will come up with the better API which is less prone and will address this issue more fundamentally.'"

column10: b"b' Not expand ByteBuffer[] in ChannelOutboundBuffer'"

b"b' At the moment we expand the ByteBuffer[]\\xc2\\xa0when we have more then 1024 ByteBuffer to write and replace the stored instance in its FastThreadLocal. This is not needed and may even harm performance on linux as IOV_MAX is 1024 and so this may cause the JVM to do an array copy. '"
b"b' Not expanding ByteBuffer[] was the cause of the regression we had 2 weeks ago. Could you explain why not expanding it is not a problem anymore?'"
b"b' @trustin can you explain me what the problem was or point to the issue ? I think not expand it should be fine as we should just keep on trying to write until isEmpty() is true or size() == 0'"
b"b' A composite buffer can have more than 1024 components.'"
b"b' @trustin maybe we should just do a memory copy in filterMessage(..) for this case ?'"
b'b" If the components are all direct buffers
column11: we might be doing unnecessary copy.  Also
column12: it is a leak of abstraction to hard code 1024 (IOV_MAX) here.  What if some O/S (or future version of linux) has  limit?  Epoll transport already handles the case where the number of buffers are greater than IOV_MAX
column13: so I\'m not sure why expanding the array is such a big concern."'

column10: b"b' @trustin ok... let me revert this then. '"
b"b' If the epoll transport has some deficiency handling the buffer array of more than IOV_MAX
column11: we should fix it there
column12: not in ChannelOutboundBuffer
column13: by the way.'"

b"b' AbstractTrafficShapingHandler not flushing'"
b'b" Hi
column11: the AbstractTrafficShapingHandler only manages write requests but ignores flush requests. This could lead to data that will never be received because the data was never sent. I\'m not entirely sure but wouldn\'t it be ok to just add delayed tasks for flush requests
column12: too ? Right now I\'m using a dummy handler which simply flushes on write and is added before the AbstractTrafficShapingHandler."'

column10: b'b\' @chrisprobst Indeed
column11: the AbstractTrafficShapingHandler ignores the flush since it manages directly the write this way:If a write is passed to the handler
column12: it computes the "delay"If the delay is If the delay is = 0
column13: the handler check if the "toSend" message queue is empty  If the queue is not empty
column14: the message is added to the queue to ensure the write order is preserved but with not extra delay  If the queue is empty
column15: it sends immediately (using write()) the messageWhen a flush is passed
column16: it does not intercept it
column17: so the flush should continue to the next handler and be activeWhen the delayed task is runned
column18: it unqueue all queued messages that are compatible with the current timestamp
column19: write all of them using write() and adding a simple flush() after. Have you any code that shows up any bad behavior?If so
column20: I could check and see where is the default... Bug is still possible.\''

b"b' HTTP/2 interoperability testing'"

b"b' We should run the http2-codec (in both server and client mode) against other implementations of the HTTP/2 spec.  This will be good to answer (and then update the examples) the following questions:1. How can we configure and run a HTTP/2 compliant HTTP/2 security restrictions url  in a java environment? Does this require java 8 (for TLSv1.2 and supported ciphers)?  If not does the default   allow TLSv1.2 to be used for client sockets? Do we have to add support for [jetty alpn]url  in netty? Do we have to update the cipher list in or supply a new cipher list specific for HTTP/2 2. Ensure compatibility in client mode.  Here are some potential servers to test against url  [nghttp2]url  test server already setup at this url [Microsoft]url  [Akamai]url  I should be able to get IP to test against [Jetty]url  Can we try to find  a server setup for us to test against? Twitter (details not yet known)3. Ensure compatibility in server mode.  Here are some potential clients to test against url  [curl]url  uses nghttp2 [mozilla]url  We should also think if this can be done in a repeatable fashion (think regression testing)?  Some of the setup may be prohibitive at this time but it is worth considering.'"
b"b' @nmittler FYI.'"

column10: b"b' SingleThreadEventLoopTest failing on Jenkins'"
b'b" ### Problem I noticed that and from are occasionally failing on the build server. As of now
column11: there have been 4 failures in the last 30 builds [1]. Basically
column12: these tests create a few periodic tasks
column13: wait for a few hundred milliseconds with and then check if enough tasks have been executed.### Likely Cause I noticed that the tests in seem to create a lot of garbage
column14: triggering frequent minor collections (which are STW). I looked at the console output of the last 30 builds and discovered that all failed builds had at least one very long GC pause in common (between 200 400ms):   While none of the 26 succeeding tests experienced GC pauses longer than (I checked them all). So it seems to me that it\'s quite likely that GC is causing these tests to fail. Since if a test schedules a task with a period of
column15: sleeps for and suddenly GC stops the program for obviously not all tasks will have been executed after  .### Solution I have no idea why produces that much garbage. These tests don\'t really do anything besides scheduling tasks and waiting. A test run triggers up to 50 GC runs in ~20secs
column16: cleaning up ~30MB per run. I believe the best solution for this problem is to find the root cause of the GC runs and to eliminate it. [1] url "'

column10: b"b' If I increase the heap size so that no GC runs during the test
column11: it uses up >500MB of memory:![screenshot from 2014-08-28 23 10 25]url  Pretty much all of it seems to be empty ~10MB sized int arrays.![screenshot from 2014-08-28 23 36 16]url  Any ideas where we are allocating int arrays @normanmaurer ?'"

column11: it\\\'s a legit hostname that will resolve to /10.186.55.168... I have now diagnosed this better: there\\\'s no bug anywhere
column12: except that there is a performance bug :-( because this exception is used internally but ignored: () will do this at line 112 (and other lines) then at the end
column13: we have So the only reason why this exception trace appeared in my radar is because using exceptions as control structure (basically what this code is doing as it tentatively parses a string that may or may not be a valid number) is very expensive
column14: so this exception is captured by JVM profiling. This trace appears using 0.22% of total CPU in my server
column15: but that\\\'s relatively very high lot in a program that\\\'s running on an 8-core machine and where the Netty epoll layer consumes 95% of all CPU; so this exception actually consumes 4.4% of the "rest" of my application processing time. I\\\'m going to close this bug
column16: you may investigate if Netty could avoid this call
column17: maybe it could since apparently this doesn\\\'t happen without the native epoll
column18: but not really your problem. I will try to raise this as a bug to the JDK.\''

column10: b"b' Improvement in unit test resource usage'"

b"b' Motivation:Some unit tests which use multiple NioEventLoopGroup objects have failed due to OutOfMemoryExceptions.This is caused by at least two reasons:1. Issue #28372. The tests are generally not re-using EventLoopGroups when they could which leads to a lot of  allocations Modifications:-HTTP/2 unit tests which are subject to this problem will be corrected to re-use EventLoopGroups-Handler unit tests which used HTTP/2 tests as templates will also be updated Result:-Less chance of OOM exception because of more efficient use of resources-Faster & more efficient unit tests'"

b"b' Reduce threads used by NioEventLoopGroups during tests.'"

b'b\' Motivation: Whenever a new (Nio|Epoll)EventLoopGroup is created it defaults tocreating twice as many threads as there are cores in the system. It\\\'s quite common that a single unit test method create2 3 (Nio|Epoll)EventLoopGroups. This leads to a lot of (unnecessary)threads being created. For example
column11: a unit test with 10 methods
column12: eachusing 2 NioEventLoopGroups creates 2 \\\\* 10 \\\\* 8 \\\\* 2 = 320 threads ifrun on an 8 core machine. It allocates \\\'only\\\' 160 threads if run on a4 core machine and only 80 threads if run on a 2 core machine. Now each thread allocates some memory for e.g. its stack
column13: tlab
column14: ...In GitHub issues #2841
column16: #2872 OutOfMemory errors due totoo many  yet GCed threads were reported. So while the thread count increases sharply on more powerful machines
column17: the default max heap size is limited to 1GB [1]. Modifications: When used within a junit test each Epolland NioEventLoopGroup allocates2 EventLoops and threads by default (independenly of the machine\\\'s core count).This should be more than enough to handle the "load" generated by unit tests. Result: Radically reduce the number of threads created by JUnit tests. [1] url \''

column10: b'b\' @Lekanich Well
column11: several points to try to answer (or not ;-)I finally was able to reproduce (see at the end of this message)
column12: but still not sure how to fix it... 1) On the smooth question
column13: nothing special set. I obtain the same results with HTTP Static File Server example (directly from Netty source) by adding the CTSH / GTSH to the pipeline (just after ssl but before any other handlers). To make it correct (disregarding the issue on ChunkedWriteHandler)
column14: I change the write process to an explicit loop on the RandomAccessFile by reading portion of it using a byte[65535] array
column15: then creating an explicit new ByteBuf and writing it. Something like: So nothing special again
column16: and the bandwidth is correct (10% around the optimal). 2) CheckInterval is only the time the "counters" are kept
column17: not any real data
column18: just counters. So there is no issue to set it to 100ms up to 100s. The only difficulty is accuracy of the bandwidth compute.Having a high CheckInterval is not the best since the average is compute on a biggest interval
column19: leading to "burst" effects (average makes possible to have a sudden burst effect: if no data are sent during 9s but during the very last second of the interval a huge amount of data is sent
column20: then the average on 10s and not on 1s make it possible to have almost 10 times the bandwidth allowed for a short period of time). Having a very small one is not a good idea too since the "average" could be wrong (not enough information to compute average) and the thread activity might be too high.So that\\\'s why in average
column21: I recommend something between 100ms and 1s. 3) Note however that the traffic shaping is not splitting any write in 2
column22: meaning that if you write 100 MB at once (one block of 100 MB in one ByteBuf)
column23: the trafficShaping will not split this buffer. It will only "delay it". So you might need to ensure that ByteBuf size written are at most of the size of the bandwidth (1MB/s =4) Note that the TSH store the "oldCounter" in memory
column24: such that if the reset was done too quickly (less than 10ms)
column25: it takes into account the previous time when a write was done (lastNonNullWrittenBytes )
column26: so that it makes an average
column27: taking into account a "memory" of the past traffic. By experience (and according to some other algorithms I saw)
column28: it seems correct to try to compute the immediate bandwidth (first try) and then
column30: a bandwidth based on a "n-1" bandwith computation. (sorry if it is not clear
column31: I invite you to read the writeTimeToWait ;-) In your example
column32: I don\\\'t believe it is your issue
column33: but just in case: it might be an issue on the "block" not splitten
column34: meaning you send a "huge" set of bytes at once ? ==Now I try to send a "big" file using the HttpStaticFileServer example. I finally found out a "bad" behavior. The reason seems that in the beginning
column36: meaning a correct delay. But as the new writes just reach the handler very quickly
column37: it seems that this way of computing the average is not correct.However
column38: I\\\'m struggling with a "good" way to resolve this issue. If you have any idea
column39: you\\\'re welcome !!I\\\'m thinking that one should consider the "already" delayed writes (the one still in the queue) to ensure the new delay is made according to the "last" valid time
column40: something like:first block delay is 100ms according to its size from current Time T010ms later
column41: second block delay is 100ms according to its size from "last delayed time" (T0 + 100ms + 100ms = T0+200ms)  However
column42: to ensure the result is ok
column43: one should take care the correct time is in fact between T0+100ms
column45: the result is T0+110ms. Doing as before
column46: the trafficShaping is really bad (45KB/s instead of 1MB/s) but it works. Now I have to see how to correct this. If someone has a better idea ?\''

column10: b'b\' I found the right correction I believe: In AbstractTrafficShapingHandler
column11: changing the write method as follow fix it: The idea behind is: the issue is related to the maxTime that try to prevent "Time Out" error. Once the delay is more than this max value (default begin 15s
column12: which is I believe ok)
column13: it just limit the next "delay" to 15s.Now as we wrote a huge amount of ByteBuf in short time
column14: the first blocks are correctly limited
column15: but the next ones are all limited to almost currentTime + 15s
column16: meaning all last blocks are send almost at the same time
column17: thus having no trafficShaping.My proposal is in fact to still try to limit the wait time to prevent TimeOut
column18: but using the last time we compute this "write" delay
column19: in order to compare it and see if there will be a real TimeOut or not. In short: let say that every 10ms we write a block
column20: and each time with a increased delay of 5sfirst write at T0 set delay to 5s
column21: then lastTimeWrite is T0+5ssecond write at T0+10ms set delay to 10s
column22: then lastTimeWrite is T0+10s+10msthird write at T0+20ms set delay to 15s
column23: then lastTimeWrite is T0+15s+20ms4rth write at T0+30ms set delay to 20s
column24: Previously: the new delay will be limited to 15s
column25: as all the next blocks
column26: meaning they all will be written shortly at T0+15s+30ms (every 10ms then)
column27: so a burst of writes  Now: the new delay will be 20s
column28: since the previous write was (in fact will be) at T0+15s+20ms and the next one will be at T0+20s+30ms so only 5
column29: 10s of difference < 15s...  So as long as the difference between 2 writes is less than 15s
column30: it will allow the wait to be Now I have correct timing for a big files (300MB) without any issue
column31: with almost constant 980KB/s. @normanmaurer @trustin I still have some improvements to do before proposing an update:changing the writeTimeToWait method in TrafficCounter since it would be nice if this is were this computations is done
column32: instead of here in the AbstractTrafficShapingHandlersee if I can fix the "wrong" statistics shown by the TrafficCounter on write
column33: since it shows in fact "asked write operation bandwidth" but not "real write operation bandwidth" (compute should use the written bytes pooling out of the queue. Some other  where I would like to have your opinion:I don\\\'t understand the issue on ChunkedWriteHandler where there is not ByteBuf reaching the ChannelTrafficShapingHandler but a DefaultFileRegion. As CTSH is the first handler in the pipeline
column34: it should be only ByteBuf objects
column35: but it is not. Do I understand correctly if somewhere "after" the pipeline
column36: the DefaultFileRegion is doing writes internally (so out of control of any handler in the pipeline as CTSH) ?Shall we make the writability change too (as we do for the readability) ?\''

b"b' AbstractNioMessageChannel not passing pipeline exceptions to exceptionCaught'"
b'b\' AbstractNioByteChannel wraps  () in a  which passes any exceptions through to (). (try: line 113
column11: fireRead: line 130
column12: catch: line 160
column13: -AbstractNioMessageChannel ( does NOT. It ONLY wraps the actual socket read in the . (fireRead: line 92). In order to get "normal" exception reporting behaviour on an NioDatagramChannel
column14: it is necessary to have an extra inbound handler which wraps all pipeline calls in a  and forwards to exceptionCaught manually. Please can UDP message channels handle exceptions in the "normal" manner
column15: as right now they vanish into the ether. Sidenote: It\\\'s very easy for Netty to "lose" exceptions. Even in the Byte case
column16: the extra fireChannelRead() in the exception path may itself throw an exception which (a) masks the original exception
column17: and (b) is itself lost.\''

b"b' check the bind future before writing DNS queries to the channel'"

b'b" Everything here applies against 5.0.0.Alpha2-SNAPSHOT in the master branch.  This same problem probably occurs in other branches that include DNS resolution but I\'m leaning pretty far forward in my use of netty right now. I noticed that the DnsQueryContext
column11: using the DatagramChannel bound in DnsNameResolver
column12: blindly writes to the channel without checking the bind future for success. I have a fairly complicated test that reproduces errors around this problem
column13: but I don\'t have a good reduction that I can attach here and the errors are timing dependent so I\'m not even certain they\'ll reproduce outside of my machine. This request just fixes the bug
column14: I\'m working to understand enough about this code to write a good test for my changes."'

b"b' HTTP/2 Inbound Flow Control Connection Window Issues'"

b"b' Motivation:The inbound flow control code was returning too many bytes to the connection window.  This was resulting in GO_AWAYs being generated by peers with the error code indicating a flow control issue.  Bytes were being returned to the connection window before the call to returnProcessedBytes. All of the state representing the connection window was not updated when a local settings event occurred. Modifications:The DefaultHttp2InboundFlowController will be updated to correct the above defects.The unit tests will be updated to reflect the changes. Result:Inbound flow control algorithm does not cause peers to send flow control errors for the above mentioned cases.'"
b"b' @nmittler When you get back lets talk about this one.'"

b'b" @Scottmitch I think I need more clarification as to what the problem is that you were encountering.  The existing code basically gets the connection window out of the way entirely to allow flow control to be driven by the stream windows alone.  I\'m not sure how this would result in a GO_AWAY."'

b"b' @nmittler Welcome back! So my scenario is as follows.1) Netty client and nghttp2 server (so we have some variation in implementation).2) Netty client opens a connection (with INITIAL_WINDOW_SIZE = MAX).3) Netty client sends WINDOW_UPDATE for connection stream to set window = MAX.4) Netty client sends some requests5) nghttp2 server responds6) Netty client receives response and sends a window update which would exceed the max window size (the increment is too large due in part to which was dynamic dependent on the number of streams being used in  )7) nghttp2 detects the invalid increment and responds with a go_away error=flow control.'"

b"b' Should the be updated when a windowUpdate is sent (and maybe received) (for the connection stream)? url Would it make sense to have an interface to control the connection flow control window?  Something similar to the existing approach.  For example return a object which has a and contribution? This PR needs to be reworked either way as it couples the connection window to all the stream windows (connection window is a subset of all stream windows).  It also assumes the byte amounts being returned to the stream windows can be safety applied to the connection window (which is not true because the limits could be different).'"
b'b" @Scottmitch thanks! :) From your scenario
column11: it sounds like a bug in nghttp2 to me. I don\'t believe that the spec ever states that the connection window be confined to the initial window size.  It only states that the initial window size be the initial value of the connection window upon establishment of the connection.  We should be free to expand the connection window to MAX_INT right away if we so desired."'

column10: b'b" @nmittler We are free to expand the connection window the issue was Netty attempts to return an increment that would result in a  .  I\'ll try the scenario again and provide more detail."'

The problem is the second window_update with an increment of (which is generated by the inbound flow controller).  In the is (seems reasonable) but the returns (because is  ).  So seems like we need to account for the and the and on the connection window discrepancies. Yes is the closest thing we have in Netty.  '"

b'b\' @nmittler I have been thinking about the confusion I had over which direction the settings frame was going while in the context of the  .  I would like to see if maybe we could clarify the naming conventions to make things  a bit more clear and get your thoughts on the following (before I open a new issue or take any action).... So as I understand it the terminology comes from the fact whenever a message is "inbound" (onDataRead) flow control will be applied. Similarly the terminology comes from where it is applied for "outbound" messages (writeData) flow control is applied.  However these term do not appear in the specification and are a bit confusing when we consider the parameters for the "inbound" flow controller are typically set by a "outbound" event (the last sent settings when a settings ack is received).  The same relationship exists for the "outbound" flow controller in that it is initialized from an "inbound" event (onSettingsRead
column11: http upgrade).  Additional now the "inbound" flow control is used potentially out of the context or sending or receiving messages to configure the connection (or any other stream) widow parameters. So if we are in agreement this situation is confusing then lets think about how to make this better :)  I would like to propose the following as a starting point:1) Lets try to stick with the "local" and "remote" terminology from the specification.  I think this will alleviate the need to orient your perspective when thinking about "inbound" and "outbound". If 1 then...2) It may be nice to extra the common functionality for the flow controller and make a common base class.  That way we can consider having the access point to the flow controller be in the interface.  This will alleviate the need for maintaining instances of the flow controller objects outside of the object (which I think will always have flow control: [section 5.2.1]url  WDYT?\''

b"b' Memory leak during high load. 4.0.25.final
b'b\' Hi guys. First of all
column11: thank you
column12: for great project! I think I found memory leak during my performance testing. I launched a server on VM with 2 CPUs (Xeon E5-2660 2.20GHz) under Ubuntu 14.04.1 LTS with java 1.8.0_31. And started performing load testing from another machine. Test scenario is pretty simple:1) Create 100 pairs of channels (1 pair is app and hard channels);2) In loop send message from app channel;  3) When server retrieves message it decodes it and forwards to connected hard channel and sends OK message back to app channel.That\\\'s it. Protocol is binary and every message is only ~8-10 bytes.  Initially I created 100 pairs and with code above generated ~10k . Server was pretty healthy with no problems during long term run. Network traffic was only ~1 . After that I decided to increase load by 50% by increasing number of client pairs to 150. After test restart I found that memory consumption started growing quickly. After few minutes I stopped generating load and java server process was 200% busy even without any load (look like GC was in infinite loop). Here is heap dump:![netty_4 0 25 final leak]url  I also tried netty-4.0.26.final. And situation with it much better memory leak still in place but memory consumption was few times slower than in 4.0.25.final version.![netty_4 0 26 final leak]url  Test itself you can find [here]url  Handler [here]url  Protocol  [here]url  Server build [here]url  if you want to reproduce locally run "java -jar server-0.1.jar". It needs java 8. Do you aware of such issue? Let me know If I could provide you with more info.\''

column10: b'b" Note that sending a message in Netty is asynchronous
column11: which means you\'ll get or the VM will enter GC spiral if you write many messages without making sure they are really sent out to the socket. is not a good idea because your write request can take more than 10 milliseconds."'

column10: b'b" I understand it is asynchronous and what does that mean. But why memory never released after I stopped performing test? Few high load peaks and server stops working after that... It doesn\'t seem as normal."'
b"b' OK. Then please:fix your testfix your leaks in your code (read [this]url rerun your test with higher JVM max memory .. so that I can make sure this is really a bug in Netty.'"
b'b" Trustin
column11: 1. My test is correct. It consuming only few resources and has no problem with CPU
column12: memory or software interrupts; If you want me to wait response from server after every write operation I\'ll be not able to make high load;2. I profiled both server and clients and didn\'t find any memory leaks in my code. Moreover all resource management is done by ReplayingDecoder and MessageToByteEncoder. I don\'t make any netty specific allocations in my own code; All my allocations are via \'new\'.3. Heap size is big enough for my tasks. The funny thing is my server during 10k  consumes only 300mb of heap and works as expected without growing heap. Problems only appear after load increases and server starts consuming more and more and never releases it. Yes I understand that because of asynchronous nature of netty it is expected but it is also expected that heap is cleaned after load go away. Here is also stacktrace during high-load. Maybe it will clarify something more. I also will try to use today native epoll transport so maybe situation there will be different.  "'

b"b' flushing delays with TCP_CORK ?'"

b'b\' I am exploring the use of TCP_CORK as a way of reducing packet fragmentation and thus bandwidth. The flip side seems to be the increased latency (up to 200ms) in case of not having enough data for a full packet which is a common scenario. The solution is to "uncork" and "recork" a corked connection to force sending
column11: as described here: url  Looking at Epoll package code it appears that Netty does not currently do this on a regular channel flush. I suppose it could be possible to manually call  after the flush
column12: but I wonder if there ought to be a higher level API for this (or a flushing option) as well as a single native call that would both uncork / recork the channel in a single JNI invocation ...\''

column10: b"b' Add a fair-mode alternative of OrderedMemoryAwareThreadPoolExecutor.'"

b'b\' This is a fair-mode alternative of OrderedMemoryAwareThreadPoolExecutor .### Motivation:1. Unfair of OrderedMemoryAwareThreadPoolExecutor The task executed in OrderedMemoryAwareThreadPoolExecutor is unfair in some situations. For example
column11: let\\\'s say there is only one executor thread that handle the events from the two channels
column12: and events are submitted in sequence:      Then the events maybe executed in this unfair order:     As we see above
column13: Channel B (Event B) maybe executed unfairly late. Even more
column14: if there are too much events come in Channel A
column15: and one-by-one closely
column16: then Channel B (Event B) would be waiting for a long while and become "hungry".### Modifications:1. Fair of FairOrderedMemoryAwareThreadPoolExecutor In the same case above ( one executor thread and two channels )
column17: this implement will guarantee execution order as:    _NOTE_: For convenience the case above use one single executor thread
column18: but the fair mechanism is suitable for multiple executor threads situations.### result: There is a fair-mode alternative of OrderedMemoryAwareThreadPoolExecutor and OrderedDownstreamThreadPoolExecutor now.\''

b"b' Can we return HTTP 400 upon malformed HTTP request?'"

b'b\' This is related to url  I searched the issues in github and couldn\\\'t find any related issue.  We are using netty 2.6 and we found that if today we send an invalid http request like this netty will just throw IllegalArgumentException and close connection.  I am wondering why not just return 400 in this case?  This is an issue for the scenario where we fronted our netty server with some caching server. Caching server may return "5xx" if netty http server close connection with giving any response
column11: which is a misleading status code.\''

column10: b'b" @alvinlin123 I think we only throw the exception and closing the connection is actually done by the play framework implementation when an exception is catched. I\'m not sure what exact version play uses though"'
b"b' Yes
column11: looking deeper it looks like Netty just forward the exception to the next upstream. This is non issue then. Resolving. Thanks for replying.'"

column10: b'b" Actually
column11: now I think about it upon unable to parse the HTTP request
column12: wound\'t it make more sense to throw some kind of special exception instead of IllegalArgumentException?  We are using Netty 3.6 by the way. Netty do throw TooLongFrameException if the first line is too long
column13: then I think it follows that Netty should throw
column14: say
column15: InvalidMessageFormatException
column16: if it can\'t parse the Http message?"'

column10: b'b" I think it\'s better upgrading in the long run.  (the supertype of and  ) has the property that tells you when decoding fails.  Since 4
column11: Netty does not throw an exception on a decoding failure but emits a partial message with the information about the failure
column12: so you can handle the decoding failure more gracefully. With Netty 3
column13: you don\'t have many options as you realized already."'

column10: b'b" I think upgrading makes sense
column11: but that\'s probably going to take some time with our production servers.  Is Netty 3 in maintenance only mode? Is making fix to Netty 3 not possible now? I may be wrong
column12: but catching http messge decoding error and throwing a new specialize exception should be a straight-forward and non-breaking change right?"'

column10: b'b" @alvinlin123 it\'s more or less in maintenance mode and we only fix bugs there atm."'

b"b' [#4030] XmlFrameDecoder is corrupt'"

b"b' Motivation: Two problems:1. Decoder assumption that as soon as it finds </ element it can decrement opened xml brackets counter. It can lead to bugs when closing bracket is not in byteBuf yet.2. Not proper handling of more than two root elements in XML document. First element will be processed properly
column11: second one not. It is caused by assumption that byteBuf readerIndex is 0 at the begging of decoding. Modifications: Both problems were resolved by fixes:1. decrement opened brackets count only if  enclosing bracket is found2. consider readerIndex higher than 0 when counting output frame length Result: Both problems were resolved'"

column10: b'b" Netty doesn\'t consolidate pending writes. So threads a
column11: b
column12: ..n all quickly make writes to some socket(s). Either it\'s already maxed it\'s bandwidth
column13: or the writing thread(s) don\'t own the socket and the thread that does is busy. Meanwhile these writes will queue up in these entries. Properly written code will eventually respect water marks
column14: detect the build up
column15: and back off. However
column16: netty decides to keep the entries it was using (maybe even very transiently using) just in case it needs them again. My original complaint comment was focused on cases where many threads could trick a recipient thread into holding way more cache objects than normal by taking advantage of its blind greed. It sort of sounds like that was addressed to some degree
column17: but I haven\'t looked into it since."'

column10: b'b" Discussion from stack @RemyLebeau it does. I have an application which used to check for RDHUP and IN in that order. It had the bug that if the peer sends something (such as a termination reason) and immediately closes
column11: my app was not receiving that data because it checked for RDHUP first and killed the connection. From what I\'ve seen
column12: this happens when both endpoints are on the same machine
column13: not sure it happens on different machines. \\xe2\\x80\\x93  haelix Nov 7 \'14 at 8:141  @haelix I am looking at this right now
column14: and can confirm this. A fast  on localhost will result in 0x2001 (RDHUP|IN)
column15: but with data in the pipe
column16: and read returning first the data
column17: then zero. Also for example a SIGPIPE will result in 0x2019 (RDHUP|HUP|ERR|IN) with a read returning zero. In this edge case you could skip the read and just act on the RDHUP
column18: but in the case above you prob want the data sent
column19: which in my mind makes RDHUP pretty useless since you anyway need to handle this when reading. \\xe2\\x80\\x93  Fredrik Widlund May 31 at 12:40add a comment"'

column10: b'b\' @ninjaI considered fixing the pooling code for derived buffers but it boiled down to having feedback from the to all its derived buffers when the reference count went to 0. This would require keeping some sort of collection in that must be thread safe. I did not go through this exercise because it seemed like overhead of maintaining this thread safe collection may out weight the benefits of pooling in  cases. That lead me to take the "easier" path which was to pull it out because it was not functioning as originally intended. Can you explain why is preferred over due to the objects returned by not being pooled?\''

column13: garbage. And I worked quite hard to pool everything so that the number of garbage it creates during I/O is an exact 0. IMO that\\\'s the behaviour we could use:1. creating a new derived buffer increases refCnt on the original 2. the derived one maintains its own refCnt starting on 1 and calling retain() on derived would not touch the refCnt on the original2. if release() is called on derived

column11: so that the implementation of can focus on decode the content of the frame. Which is a good idea. However will the method always be called when the channel is closed
column12: even if there is no remaining data. This seems illogical (to me) since the prepended has the task of not pushing through data in your chain which does not have a full frame (other decoders like  do the same). So in the end implementations of and (since issue #4087 is fixed) do need to check for the received buffer size before being able to decode. Steps to reproduce:1. Implement a  2. Add a and your implementation to the chain3. Close the connection4. gets called with an empty buffer'"

b"b' High CPU usage with SO_LINGER and sudden connection close (4.0.26.Final+)'"

b"b' We are using Netty 4.0.29.Final in one of our services. We are seeing high CPU usage (~100%) in certain periods and almost negligible CPU usage in remaining periods. Though there is no change in request rate. The request rate itself is very small (less than 100 per second per box). The service mostly does an inmemory cache lookup. The CPU and memory graph is below:![bad1]url  We found that what differentiated periods of high CPU usage and periods of low CPU usage
column11: was the amount of objects created per second (Notice the zigzag during high CPU phase and a smooth line during low CPU). When we did memory profiling during the high CPU periods
column12: we saw that more than 90% instances are of PoolThreadCache$MemoryReagionCache$Entry
column13: DirectByteBuffer
column14: Recycler$DefaultHandle and Integer. The screenshot is below:![bad2]url  When we tried Netty 4.0.33.Final in one of our boxes
column15: we found that the DirectByteBuffer instances remained the same but the instances of PoolThreadCache$MemoryReagionCache$Entry dropped drastically (~600). This was possibly because of this PR: url  I scanned Netty commit logs to find all the changes that have went in for PoolThreadCache. There was one major PR url  that went with Netty 4.0.18.Final. We tried with the previous Netty version 4.0.17.Final with one of the production instances. There was hardly  any CPU usage for this instance. The graphs and memory profiler report are attached below. These were taken at the same time as the previous graphs
column16: under exactly same load.![good1]url ![good2]url '"

column12: and maybe latest netty versions made that more visible. the reason why you have 500 mil instances is that they aren\'t recycled since it\'s above the recycler size limit
column13: so an instance is created every time. when you aren\'t like writing too fast etc. it should be stable around 200k_cores_2 max without gc

column10: b"b' @ashish-tyagi you could also try sampling CPU with VisualVM to confirm where the busy loop is.'"
b"b' @johnou The CPU profile is already attached in the comment dating  Nov 14
column11: 2015. The busy loop is NioEventLoop which keeps on reading the same key
column12: which keeps on failing because of underlying connection being closed
column13: which causes Netty to schedule a close() in an executor.'"

column10: b"b' The executor which issues a close() gets stuck. I see these stack traces. These are not recovering either. Ideally the close() should block max for 1 sec (=SO_LINGER).  '"
b"b' I measure the time for which the threads were stuck in close()
column11: it was equal to SO_LINGER. I was under the assumption that SO_LINGER is in milliseconds
column12: turns out that it is in seconds.'"

column10: b"b' @normanmaurer The problem is that if the channel is not closed in IO thread
column11: the IO thread goes in an infinite loop
column12: issuing close() again and again. You can easily produce this issue even without SO_LINGER. Just comment out the code in method of class. Open a connection and close it from the client side. The IO thread will go in infinite loop. I have put the reproducer code along with the modified class in this [git repo]url  This reproducer works even when both client and server are on same machine.'"
