b'b" We\'ve discussed this in the past for a variety of reasons. Trailers definitely have to go through the flow controller since they can\'t be sent until after the last DATA frame. However
column11: there isn\'t a good reason that I\'m aware of that we shouldn\'t just send HEADERS immediately. Adding HEADERS to outbound flow control will add work to the new (#4464) since it has to keep track of zero-length frames separately ... and HEADERS are zero-length frames.  As part of resolving this issue
column12: we should refactor the fix in #4502. We need a better solution for dealing with delayed frames. /cc @Scottmitch @louiscryan "'

column10: b'b" @normanmaurer I think this should go into the next release ... would you mind holding off on the release until next week? I\'ll cook up a PR shortly."'
b"b' @nmittler deal '"
b"b' Thanks for reporting @nmittler!'"

b'b" Just chatted with @louiscryan and @ejona86 about this offline.  We\'re thinking that keeping HEADERS in the flow controller as we do now lends itself to better goodput due to data locality.  If we send HEADERS for all streams way before data is actually sent
column11: they\'re consuming bandwidth for those streams that are sending real data. I think we should abandon this issue in favor of two changes:1. We fix sending RST_STREAM for streams that we have not yet sent HEADERS for. (#4465).2. We fix the to enqueue empty frames into the same queue as the other frames.  If we don\'t send all empty frames
column12: that\'s ok ... so long as we make sure that the head of the queue is never empty. By keeping empty frames separate
column13: we were actually breaking data locality
column14: which could potentially degrade goodput. @Scottmitch @normanmaurer Make sense?"'

column10: b"b' Closing this for now ... we can re-open as necessary.'"
b"b' @nmittler A few  points:1. Sending empty frames may help to advise of a  change (priority change of headers
column11: maybe less significant if both ends ignore priority) or alleviate resource constraints on the remote end (END_STREAM in empty data frame).2. -3. Queuing empty frames (particularly headers) locally increases the work we do
column12: and amount of resources we consume locally.'"

column10: b'b" @Scottmitch True
column11: but the spec doesn\'t really require that both endpoints be all that in sync WRT priority. We\'re favoring  over correctness. The oddball here is that the PRIORTY frame is not flow controlled.  I think it should be consistent with whatever we\'re doing with HEADERS frames.Empty frames are not special WRT the
column12: as it\'s just focused on serving the next HEAD of the queue. If an application always wants to make progress on high-priority frames
column13: it would have to use a priority-based distributor.Yes
column14: it\'s 1 extra object per stream for the headers frame. It\'s unclear without more investigation if this is adding significant memory pressure ... I suspect not."'

column10: b'b" @nmittler -Agreed. The focus here is not on what the other end does with the data
column11: but how soon we get it to them (to allow them to potentially do something useful with it). we may need to consider other frame types. Seems like only queuing what we need will simplify things here.I guess the exception would be that 0 length frames don\'t consume flow control window and don\'t _have_ to be prioritized.Also extra operations on the queue. Not a deal breaker
column12: but just pointing out there is a bit of extra overhead."'

column10: b"b' I will reopen to continue discussion'"

b'b" @louiscryan @ejona86 @Scottmitch @normanmaurer  The idea of flow controlling frames adds a reasonable amount of complexity to the HTTP/2 logic and is probably worthy of further discussion. The first thing that comes to mind is that frames **must** be sent in the same order in which they were created by the local side (e.g. 3 followed by 7). The current flow controller seems to work in this regard
column11: but AFAIK it\'s not something that is specified in the API contract. Since the flow controller is frame agnostic
column12: we would have to make the contract more general regarding the sending of initial frames on streams. We also need to decide how to handle other frames that identify a stream
column13: specifically and  . I believe only way to guarantee that the two sides don\'t get out of sync would be to flow control those as well. If we delay sending a frame
column14: we could run into a couple of interesting situations.  First
column15: priority changes sent for various streams could be sent out of order
column16: resulting in an undesirable shaping of the priority tree on the remote side. This isn\'t a deal breaker
column17: but would be unfortunate. Second
column18: the dependent stream might have been closed (by either endpoint)
column19: which would likely result in the remote endpoint breaking the connection. This is much more severe. To get around this
column20: our encoder would have to be modified so that when a stream is closed
column21: it iterates over any unsent frames and changes the dependency (e.g. 0) if it references the closed stream.  Since frames have a frame built-in
column22: they would suffer from these same problems. may also be a bit tricky. Generally they are sent by the server on a client-initiated stream
column23: so I\'m not quite sure if they would need to be flow controlled. If for some reason they do
column24: then we have the problem of ensuring that no frames on the promised stream are sent until the headers on the original stream. This _may_ be something that could be solved by priority
column25: but it is not guaranteed. We also have the case of custom frame types
column26: but I think we can punt on that for now. Did I miss any cases? What do you guys think?"'

column10: b'b\' Short-term (for the release)
column11: it seems we should focus on doing as few changes as possible
column12: and just those changes necessary for correctness for major cases. It seems #4465 should be fixed because it _should_ cause the connection to be terminated and apparently is easy to hit if you are doing benchmarking. Thus I propose we do one of these two options
column13: based on whichever is mostrisky:1. Fix RST_STREAM for queued HEADERS (#4502). #4502 seems rather small (~50 lines ; mostly trivial)
column14: although the amount of changes necessary to tests is a bit daunting.2. Don\\\'t flow control initial headers. I don\\\'t think we should hold up the release for the other issues described
column15: since they won\\\'t prevent operation. What to do in the long run is a longer discussion... #### No strong issues with invalid wire protocol Concerning PRIORITY frames:So it is safe to send PRIORITY at any time. So the "only" problem for PRIORITY is reordering with respect to HEADERS
column16: since HEADERS also specify PRIORITY information. nmittler wrote:Actually
column17: http/2 is more strict than that:I think that means that you can send PUSH_PROMISE _before_ you send your initial HEADERS response for the client-initiated stream
column18: because the client\\\'s request opened the stream. Which means PUSH_PROMISE is free to ignore flow control. If they went through the flow controller
column19: then we would need some solution for stream id reordering. I don\\\'t know what it would mean if we reorder a PRIORITY frame to before a PUSH_PROMISE for the same promised stream id. Maybe we can disallow this in our API (which I think client channels would do)
column20: but it might be useful to break the implicit dependency. The spec isn\\\'t too clear (which probably means "we shouldn\\\'t do that"):So all the above means that the _wire protocol_ portion is easy to deal with. We "just" need to figure out how to store and convey the information properly. ### Approaches to the problem #### We have to solve it The problems discussed here still apply even if we aren\\\'t flow controlling HEADERS directly
column21: because of MAX_CONCURRENT_STREAMS (although I do understand that that limit is handled by and not the normal flow controller). It seems these cases we are describing are broken if max concurrent streams is reached
column22: even if HEADERS aren\\\'t flow controlled via the flow controller. Because they will be "flow controlled" by MAX_CONCURRENT_STREAMS. So even if we don\\\'t flow control headers
column23: we still have to solve the same problems. I have a general preference to make any "large" frames go through the flow controller
column24: because then we can have a central place to observe channel writeability and intelligently schedule frames. About a month after letting people use gRPC our users were creating 1000 streams immediately on the connection. Going through the flow controller observes writability which can prevent accumulating too much in the outbound queue
column25: as well as allowing us to schedule small DATA frames along with the initial HEADERS. Responding with HEADERS alone is generally unhelpful; if we weren\\\'t going to complete the response soon after the HEADERS it would have been better to delay sending the HEADERS and use that bandwidth for another stream\\\'s DATA to let it complete. #### How much wiggle room? We can trivially allow HEADERS with priority to be reordered by sending a PRIORITY frame immediately before enqueuing the HEADERS without their priority. We could try to do the extra work only if exclusive bit is set
column26: but that seems like a losing battle. Delayed stream id allocation could solve some problems
column27: but it doesn\\\'t seem like a solution that helps initial HEADERS to be flow controlled. PRIORITY between queued streams would be a problem. Interesting protocol detail: client-specified MAX_CONCURRENT_STREAMS doesn\\\'t apply to reserved streams but it does to open streams; it doesn\\\'t prohibit sending PUSH_PROMISE on server-side
column28: but it does prohibit sending the response. #### Proposal1. PRIORITY ignores flow control. Exclusive priorities effectively require it. They are probably intended to take effect ASAP.2. PUSH_PROMISE ignores flow control. Reordering a PRIORITY before its PUSH_PROMISE would be too problematic. We don\\\'t expect many PUSH_PROMISES in general and the size of frame is likely not too large
column29: since it wouldn\\\'t generally include cookies
column32: the PRIORITY issue may go away. If so
column33: we maybe could revisit this.3. Initial HEADERS observes flow control. If a priority is specified
column34: split it out to a separate PRIORITY frame. We would need to keep a separate queue for new streams or always add to the end of a combined queue to prevent reordering. We would also need to handle RST_STREAM racing with the initial headers.\''

column10: b"b' @ejona86 thanks for the breakdown ... the proposal looks good! One thought is that we might just _always_ send a frame before sending our first frame
column11: even if no priority was specified. That way we ensure that the remote side knows about the stream in advance and the RST_ effectively _goes away_.'"

column10: b'b" PRIORITY _doesn\'t_ change the state
column11: it simply can be sent at any time. If you send PRIORITY for an idle stream it is still idle.And that means that a RST_STREAM before the headers would be a connection error:"'

column10: b"b' Yup agreed.  I think the right thing to do here would be to always create streams in the state and not open them until we write the first frame. In addition
column11: we would never send  IDLE'"

The assumption is that consolidation of code will also help with the goals of the "child channel for streams" effort.Although we discussed that synthesizing frames is a bit "magical" and unexpected

column11: I just don\'t know what the preferred netty solution is to fixing this.  Where: [InboundHttp2()]url  Why: It is happening because is throwing an exception due to an invalid character in a HTTP/2 Header\'s .  So basically the allocator is creating a for use in the
column12: then the method is called passing in the  . throws a validation exception
column13: and the buffer is not released. One solution is for the to take responsibility for this and release the buffer if an exception occurs before returning the message.  The other is to treat this as an unusual circumstance and just fix the unit-test.  I prefer the former
column14: but it would also require us to look at other scenarios (such as SPDY or even  header validation)."'

b"b' Fixed by url '"
b"b' Race condition in MessageToMessageEncoder if (..) is called from channelWritabilityChanged'"
b'b\' Hi
column11: I triggered a race condition by calling ().write(...) from channelWritabilityChanged. One can argue if it\\\'s a bug or expected behavior
column12: but since I think it is very hard to track down for new netty users it should be fixed or the user should be warned in documentation of channelWritabilityChanged. Assuming your handler calls write in "channelWritabilityChanged" e.g. like: and then write something to the channel you end up triggering a race condition in MessageToMessageEncoder breaking HTTP chunked transfer. This could produce this output: a size(someChunk)a CRLFa someChunkb size(anotherChunk)b CRLFb anotherChunkb CRLF**a CRLF** instead of  a size(someChunk)a CRLFa someChunk**a CRLF**b size(anotherChunk)b CRLFb anotherChunkb CRLF Browser won\\\'t parse that and terminate the http connection. This is because MessageToMessageEncoder triggers multiple writes for each HTTP chunk (chunk size
column13: CRLF
column14: chunk content
column15: CRLF). channelWritabilityChanged seems to get fired between these writes: Since we are still inside the eventloop
column16: the the write inside channelWritabilityChanged is executed right away before the chunk is written completely. I fixed it for me by no longer directly invoking write from channelWritabilityChanged: So in my opinion
column17: enqueuing channelWritabilityChanged in the eventloop could fix it inside netty.\''

column11: which it doesn\'t do now.OpenSsl could allow a special method to initialize itself if it hasn\'t done so

column10: b"b' A new ChannelHandler that allows the user to control the flow of mess\\xe2\\x80\\xa6'"

b'b" \\xe2\\x80\\xa6ages if upstream handlers emit more than one event for each read() Motivation: Some handlers such as HttpObjectDecoder can emit more than one event per read()which leads to problems in downstream handlers that expect only one event and hopethat ChannelConfig#setAutoRead(false) prevents further events being sent while they\'reprocessing the one they\'ve just received. Modifications: A new handler called FlowControlHandler that feeds off read() and isAutoRead() and actsas a holding buffer if auto reading gets turned off and more events arrive while auto readingis off. Result: Fixes issues such as #4895."'

column11: issue the command "GET nonexisting" ("nonexisting" can be any key not present in the redis server) twice and exceptions are thrown (error messages at the bottom).### My analysis At the begining #decode()
column12: currentMessage is not null as expected for the second GET command

column14: which is again because

column16: cannot pass the test #acceptInboundMessage() in order to find its way into #decode() to finish up the aggregation process.### My solution My idea is to let GET operations for non-existing keys resemble those for existing keys. That is
column17: to represent null string in null response
column18: use a DefaultLastBulkStringRedisContent with empty buffer instead of . Please feel free to comment
column19: thanks!### FULL Error messages Note that "nonexisting" is a non-existing key in the redis server; user input will be **bold**. Enter Redis commands (quit to end)**get nonexisting**(null)**get nonexisting**exceptionCaught: :   at (:99)  at (:83)  at (:154)  at (:354)  at (:145)  at (:277)  at (:264)  at (:83)  at (:154)  at (:354)  at (:145)  at (:1078)  at $(:117)  at (:544)  at (:485)  at (:399)  at (:371)  at $5.run(:742)  at $(:145)  at (:745)Caused by:   at (:195)  at (:89)  ... 19 more(null)\''

b'b" Hi
column11: there may be more problems regarding representing null strings that I discovered while trying to create a patch for it for fun (I\'m basically a student on it :) ). In #decode()
column12: we have this line: That means currentMessage
column13: returned from beginAggregation() method of the derived classes
column14: is assumed to have its ByteBuf derived from CompositeByteBuf (as we will do appendPartialContent() on content later). But #beginAggregation() may return  for special null string. This means
column15: if null response results in two messages going into decode() ( as I initially considered above)
column16: the conversion line will explode. Here I suggest some possibilities on dealing with the special null response strings:1) Decode it into one message. Change MessageAggregator to allow this special non-chunked message.2) Decode it into two messages. While EmptyByteBuf is still used to represent null strings
column17: change decode() to not force use of CompositeByteBuf in (). That may involve changing the ByteBufHolder interface to allow its underlying ByteBuf to be assigned.3) Decode it into two messages. Use ordinary zero-length ByteBuf to represent null strings. There will be no way for the downstream handlers to tell the differences between null strings and zero-length string values. Please feel free to correct me."'

column10: b"b' if there is no exception then the buffer will be written to the underlying channel
column11: which is responsible for releasing the buffer. If there is an exception we _may_ need to release the buffer (which is done in a block. so I think we are good as is. What is the motivation for this issue (code inspection
column12: buffer leak tools
column13: etc..)? If you have buffer leak report can you provide it plz?The reason for this was prior to commit 8b5f2d7 the parameter was copied to another buffer
column14: and then was written to the underlying channel. So would be released by the channel
column15: but would not be released and thus we had to ensure it was released in a block. Now that is directly written to the channel this is no longer necessary.'"

b'b" Having a singleton instance doesn\'t leave much room for interpretation ... it has to be shareable. I think there is value in removing any potential ambiguity
column11: or expecting the user to look for an application defined annotation and do the right thing. This change would also be API breaking right? I also see value in consistency
column12: but if we _could_ break APIs I think I would lean more toward using language patterns (singleton) rather than relying on annotations."'

column10: b"b' Netty has indication for such cases. What the point in this annotation if netty will provide INSTANCE for all sharable classes? Messing both approaches is bad style. this is why this ticket appeared :) : '"

b'b" I agree having both is redundant. I don\'t think we can change the API for 4.x though (unless the API creates some sort of bug). As I said if we _could_ change the API I would vote for singleton (and the method) as opposed to the annotation approach. Unless someone makes a good pitch for the annotation I think using native language constructs (singleton
column11: boolean method
column12: etc...) leaves less room for ambiguity."'

b"b' Motivation: Adds support for decoding NAPTR and SRV DNS records. Using DnsNameResolver it will now be possible to resolve SIP URIs and Tel URIs as well as building load balancing resolvers based on service resolution by SRV records.'"

b'b\' After a closer inspection of the resolver code
column11: I think this change may break existing code. For example
column12: if we would introduce explicit A or AAAA record types
column13: DnsNameResolverContext#onResponseAorAAAA() would stop working
column14: since it depends on DnsRawRecord. Existing code "in the wild" may already depend on DnsRawRecord being returned
column15: instead of type specific records such as SRV and NAPTR. If we want to continue
column16: we need a way to  customize the DnsRecordDecoder and have it injected through DnsNameResolverBuilder. The question is if it worth providing all that flexibility
column17: or just let the users write their own decoding of DnsRawRecords when needed?\''

b"b' Support Unicode filenames and spaces in directory listing'"
b'b" ## Motivation: The HTTP Static File Server seems to ignore filenames that doesn\'t contains only latin characters
column11: but these days people wish to serve files in other languages
column12: or even include some emojis in the filename. Although these files are not displayed on the directory listing
column13: they are accessible by HTTP requests. This fix will make such files more visible.## Modifications: I\'ve changed the pattern to disallow only files that starts with underline
column14: minus or a dot (such as .htaccess). Other filenames
column15: including the space character are allowed. I\'ve also added charset encoding to the directory listing
column16: because the browser default MAY be configured for ISO-8859-1 instead of UTF-8.## Result: Directory listing will work for files that contains the space character
column17: as well as other Unicode characters."'

b"b' Convert X509TrustManager into X509ExtendedTrustManager for Java 7+'"
b"b' Motivation: Since Java 7
column11: X509TrustManager implementation is wrapped by a JDK classcalled AbstractTrustManagerWrapper
column12: which performs an additionalcertificate validation for Socket or SSLEngine-backed connections. This makes the TrustManager implementations provided byInsecureTrustManagerFactory and FingerprintTrustManagerFactory notinsecure enough
column13: where their certificate validation fails even when itshould pass. Modifications:Add X509TrustManagerWrapper which adapts an X509TrustManager into an  X509ExtendedTrustManagerMake SimpleTrustManagerFactory wrap an X509TrustManager with  X509TrustManagerWrapper is the provided TrustManager does not extend  X509ExtendedTrustManager Result:InsecureTrustManagerFactory and FingerprintTrustManagerFactory are now  insecure as expected.Fixes #5910'"

b"b' HTTP/2 Child Channel and FrameCodec Feature Parity.'"
b'b" First of all
column11: I would like to say that I am really sorry for the large PR. It\'s really 2 PRs in one
column12: but unfortunately it\'s been some time after the first PR #5747
column13: performance evaluation #5772 and moving gRPC to this API
column14: in which things have changed so much that it was impossible for me to keep the changes separate and in sync :(. This PR firstly adds outbound flow control to the and secondly aims to make the ready to be used standalone and without the  . I have already (experimentally) ported gRPC to this API
column15: with good results. Classes like
column18: ... are planned to eventually replace their counterparts without the 2 suffix. That is
column19: once we have a plan to make the Http2Connection API package private. **Motivation:** This PR (unfortunately) does 4 things:1. Add outbound flow control to the Http2MultiplexCodec:  The HTTP/2 child channel API should interact with HTTP/2  flow control. That is
column20: if a H2 stream used up all its flow control window
column21: the corresponding child channel should be marked unwritable and a writability-changed event should be fired. Similarly
column22: a unwritable child channel should be marked writable and a writability-event should be fired
column23: once a WINDOW_UPDATE frame has been received. The changes are (mostly) contained in ChannelOutboundBuffer
column24: AbstractHttp2StreamChannel and Http2MultiplexCodec.2. Introduce a Http2Stream2 object
column25: that is used instead of stream identifiers on stream frames. A Http2Stream2 object allows an application to attach state to it
column26: and so a application handler no longer needs to maintain stream state (i.e. in a map(id -3. Remove stream state events
column27: which are no longer necessary due to the introduction of Http2Stream2. Also those stream state events have been found hard and complex to work with
column28: when porting gRPC to the Http2FrameCodec.4. Add support for HTTP/2 frames that have not yet been implemented
column29: like PING and SETTINGS. Also add a Http2FrameCodecBuilder that exposes options from the Http2ConnectionHandler API that couldn\'t else be used with the frame codec
column33: etc. **Modifications:**1. A child channel\'s writability and a H2 stream\'s outbound flow control window interact
column34: as described in the motivation. A channel handler is free to ignore the channel\'s writability
column35: in which case the parent channel is reponsible for buffering writes until a WINDOW_UPDATE is received. The connection-level flow control window is ignored for now. That is
column36: a child channel\'s writability is only affected by the stream-level flow control window. So a child channel could be marked writable
column37: even though the connection-level flow control window is zero.2. Modify Http2StreamFrame and the Http2FrameCodec to take a Http2Stream2 object intstead of a primitive integer. Introduce a special Http2ChannelDuplexHandler that has and methods. It\'s recommended for a user to extend from this handler
column38: to use those advanced features.3. As explained in the documentation
column39: a new inbound stream active can be detected by checking if the Http2Stream2.managedState() of a Http2HeadersFrame is null. An outbound stream active can be detected by adding a listener to the ChannelPromise of the write of the first Http2HeadersFrame. A stream closed event can be listened to by adding a listener to the Http2Stream2.closeFuture().4. Add a simple Http2FrameCodecBuilder and implement the missing frame types. **Result:**1. The Http2MultiplexCodec supports outbound flow control.2. The Http2FrameCodec API makes it easy for a user to manage custom stream specific state and to create new outbound streams.3. The Http2FrameCodec API is much cleaner and easier to work with. Hacks like the are no longer necessary.4. The Http2FrameCodec now also supports PING and SETTINGS frames. The allows the to use some of the rich features of the API."'

b'b\' As this got collapsed
column11: I ll re-post it here. Just some thoughts regarding  . The method allows one to create a new object (without a stream identifier). This method is thread-safe. The idea is that a user can call it from within or outside the eventloop to obtain the object and then attach it to the first headers frame. The frame codec will then assign a stream identifier to the object. So far so good. During development I noticed that it\\\'s pretty useful for one to be able to perform some action when a stream closes. I initially had a method void in mind but after a discussion with @ejona86 he suggested that a better way is to have where one can attach listeners that get executed when a stream closes. Having a ChannelFuture is nice as it feels more like Netty and also makes the threading clear: all listeners are executed in the channel\\\'s eventloop. An implication of this is
column12: that a  e needs a  . So may only be called after the handler was added to the pipeline. This might complicate things when calling from outside the eventloop. I think that\\\'s fine thoug
column13: because Netty has the same problem with writing from outside of the eventloop. Netty is just not nice if you don\\\'t want to block at all on the client side (not even until a channel is registered). However
column14: one problem to think about is what to do with objects that are never mapped to an active stream. What "guarantees" should we give for  ? What if is and never reaches the  . What if an is thrown before the write? Should that still be executed eventually? In the current implementation the answer to this question is yes. That is the frame codec maintains a list of pending streams. Pending streams are streams that never become active. If the frame codec is removed from the pipeline or the channel is closed the closeFutures of all pending streams are completed. However
column15: the implementation of pending streams is complex and requires locking (or someone to implement a lock free doubly linked list). All that to handle an edge case that most applications will never encounter
column16: but for which all applications pay a performance penalty. So an alternative would be that only after a stream becomes active the is guaranteed to be completed eventually. I think I would prefer the second API however I can also see that users might not read the API documentation carefully and write buggy applications.  In order to notify users that they simply can\\\'t rely on the to be completed until the stream is active
column17: we could throw an exception Alternatively
column18: we could also call the method :) Thoughts?\''

column10: b'b\' Hmmm... the newStream close future problem is interesting... The lack of Channel could be solved
column11: worst-case
column12: by requiring the Channel be passed to the Handler on construction. That\\\'s not super-great
column13: but may also not be the worst thing. But it doesn\\\'t solve the bigger problem of "at what point will the close callback be honored." The problem is that the stream isn\\\'t actually alive yet
column14: so it has no lifetime. And this problem is not shared when using child channels.I would prefer that. Even if we go through the effort of making sure the future is _eventually_ closed
column15: _eventually_ is a very low bar and probably not useful in many circumstances.I was at first revolted by that suggestion... But then it grew on me a bit. It forces the user to delay adding the listener via first handling the write future. On the other hand
column16: it does open itself up to very rare bugs
column17: like getting the closeFuture after the write fails (so they delayed the behavior
column18: but then got the logic wrong). Granted
column19: if not doing this the code could have just as easily been wrong and gone undetected in that rare case. Since most users won\\\'t need to use this part of the API
column20: I\\\'m not sure I mind too much
column21: one way or the other.\''

b"b'  Implemented batching versions of LengthFieldBasedFrameDecoder and Fixed\\xe2\\x80\\xa6'"
b"b' \\xe2\\x80\\xa6LengthFrameDecoder  Motivation:  According to performance tests
column11: LengthFieldBasedFrameDecoder and FixedLengthFrameDecoder generate a lot of garbage as well as perform quite poorly in cases where clients send data at a very high-speed rate.  Modifications:  Introduce a base class which implements batching of all incoming ByteBuf messages as well as provides a convenient API for decoding the resulting chunk of data Introduce an optimised version of LengthFieldBasedFrameDecoder BatchLengthFieldBasedFrameDecoder Introduce an optimised version of FixedLengthFrameDecoder BatchFixedLengthFrameDecoder  Result:  BatchLengthFieldBasedFrameDecoder and BatchFixedLengthFrameDecoder will provide much better throughput as compared to LengthFieldBasedFrameDecoder and FixedLengthFrameDecoder  P.S I [created]url  a simple echo application which tests three batching strategies. Here are some throughput as well as GC diagrams:  [Dummy Handler]url  ![Dummy Handler Throughput]url  ![Dummy Handler GC]url [Batching Handler]url  ![Batching Handler Throughput]url  ![Batching Handler GC]url [Optimised Handler]url  ![Optimised Throughput]url  ![Optimised GC]url This particular handler mimics the semantic of the one in the [PR]url  As you can see
column12: throughput in the last case is much higher.  This PR is probably related to the following issues: #1759

b"b' Disallow setting logger factory twice'"
b'b\' Motivation:  InternalLoggerFactory either sets a default logger factory implementation based on the logging implementations on the classpath
column11: or applications can set a logger factory explicitly. If applications wait too long to set the logger factory
column12: Netty will have already set a logger factory leading to some objects using one logging implementation and other objets using another logging implementation. This can happen too if the application tries to set the logger factory twice
column13: which is likely a bug in the application. Yet
column14: the Javadocs for InternalLoggerFactory warn against this saying that InternalLoggerFactory#setLoggerFactory "should be called as early as possible and shouldn\\\'t be called more than once". Instead
column15: Netty should guard against this.  Modications:  We replace the logger factory field with an atomic reference on which we can do CAS operations to safely guard against it being set twice. We also add an internal holder class that captures the static interface of InternalLoggerFactory that can aid in testing.  Result:  The logging factory can not be set twice
column16: and applications that want to set the logging factory must do it before any Netty classes are initialized (or the default logger factory will be set).\''

b"b' Allow to set max BIO memory size'"

b"b'  Motivation:  By default openssl uses 17k bytes as memory size for its BIO. This can become very wasteful if you need to handle a lot of concurrent connections. We should allow to adjust the used memory and so trade memory usage with cpu usage.  Modification:  Allow to adjust the max memory used by the BIO Adjust SSLEngine implementation to not assume 17k buffers.  Result:  Its now possible to use smaller buffers when using openssl based SSLEngine.'"

b"b' @trustin @nmittler @Scottmitch this allows to constumize the max number of bytes that are buffered by the BIO. By default it uses 17k buffers which means the whole SSL record can be buffered. The problem is that this may result in problems as you want to handle a lot of concurrent connections. When you lower the number of bytes in the buffer you can safe memory but need more CPU as you will need more often do JNI calls. So as always there are tradeoffs ;)  This is related to url Also @siyengar check this... The old code did not always handle the case correctly when the size was not the default one
column11: with this change it does (or at least it seems ;)).'"

b"b' [#6141] OpenSSLContext Mutual Auth does not announce acceptable CAs'"

b"b' Motivation:  Openssl provider should behave same as JDK provider when mutual authentication is required and a specific set of trusted Certificate Authorities are specified. The SSL handshake should return back to the connected peer the same list of configured Certificate Authorities.  Modifications:  Correctly set the CA list.  Result:  Correct and same behaviour as the JDK implementation. '"

b'b" @normanmaurer @Scottmitch So here is my findings so far : I made a simple test that creates 400 users (opens 400 SSL keep-alive connections) and 400 hardwares (opens 400 plain  keep-alive connections). 800 in total. All hardware connections send 1 message in loop. Pipeline on server delivers those message to corresponding user. So this is like 1 to 1 chat for 400 users.  I run same test on few configurations : epoll + opensll failed with OOM (1-2 minutes). epoll + no openssl failed with OOM. epoll + opensll + works for ~5 minutes while consumes memory slowly. After it grabs 40% of available memory all connections dropped. However no OOM here. epoll + ok.  Test creates very high request rate (however bandwidth is low ~10 Mbps) so in all tests some of 800 connections are dropped. In average there only 400-500 connections only survived. With low request rate I\'m not able to reproduce OOM. On prod load is 10 times lower
column11: so issue for sure not in request rate.  Test code :  I tried also to use   and  but in both cases I get NPE :  Advanced mode for memory leak shows nothing in all cases."'

b"b' Allow to configure SslHandler to wait for close_notify response before closing the Channel and fix racy flush close_notify timeout scheduling.'"

b"b'   Motivation:  SslHandler closed the channel as soon as it was able to write out the close_notify message. This may not be what the user want as it may make sense to only close it after the actual response to the close_notify was received in order to guarantee a clean-shutdown of the connection in all cases.  Beside this closeNotifyFlushTimeoutMillis is volatile so may change between two reads. We need to cache it in a local variable to ensure it not change int between. Beside this we also need to check if the flush promise was complete the schedule timeout as this may happened but we were not able to cancel the timeout yet. Otherwise we will produce an missleading log message.  Modifications:  Add new setter / getter to SslHandler which allows to specify the behavior (old behavior is preserved as default)   Added unit test.   Cache volatile closeNotifyTimeoutMillis.   Correctly check if flush promise was complete before we try to forcibly close the Channel and log a warning.   Add missing javadocs.  Result:  More clean shutdown of connection possible when using SSL and fix racy way of schedule close_notify flush timeouts and javadocs.'"

b"b' *(...) never notifies the Future when empty ho\\xe2\\x80\\xa6'"

b'b\' \\xe2\\x80\\xa6stname is used.  Motivation:  When an empty hostname is used in *(...) it will never notify the future / promise. The root cause is that we not correctly guard against errors of (...) which will throw an IllegalArgumentException when it can not parse its input. That said we should also handle an empty hostname the same way as the JDK does and just use "localhost" when this happens.  Modifications:  If the try to resolve an empty hostname we use localhost Correctly guard against errors raised by (...) so we will always noify the future / promise Add unit test.  Result:  *(...) will always notify the future.\''
b"b' @Scottmitch PTAL again... This was the only way I could find without introduce some sort of API breaking in non marked stuff.'"

b"b' Memory leak on jboss wildfly 9.0.1'"

b'b\' We migrated our application from jboss 7.1.1 to 9.0.1 and without changing our code relating to the infinispan interaction we experience a slow memory leak over the course of a month. JProfiler and VisualVM showed us $MemoryRegionCache$Entry had the biggest memory size with ~500MB and a 21 million instance count.  We upgraded the netty module in the jboss and infinispan instances to 4.1.6 but the garbage collection frequency increased even more rapidly proportionate with the memory size.  ### Netty version 4.0.26  ### JVM version java version "1.8.0_112" Java(TM) SE Runtime Environment (build 1.8.0_112-b15) Java HotSpot(TM) 64-Bit Server VM (build 25.112-b15

column10: b"b' @ByunghyunBang thats expected as headers are US_ASCII as defined by rfc'"
b'b\' I am developing http proxy with netty. As you said
column11: header name should be ASCII charactor
column12: but header values can be from various encoding in act.  Currently netty is receiving HTTP request by ByteBuf and store it as "CharSequence" on HttpObjectDecoder. During this operation
column13: all character on ByteBuf is moving to char[] without breaking encoding. But in process() function
column14: type casting from byte to char  does not consider msb (sign-bit). So the value over 127 can be casted wrong value. (ex :  0xec in byte I checked similar codes in netty
column15: they all have "(char) (value & 0xFF)"  Please think this point. \''

column10: b"b' See the [RFC7230]url > content (obs-text) as opaque data.'"
b"b' so.. maybe Netty should ignore a not-ascii characters.'"

b'b" I think this problem is NOT a RFC issue BUT a wrong casting from byte to char. If this casting problem is fixed
column11: we don\'t need to concern RFC issue.  Good example is like these :  1. ()   public static char b2c(byte b) {   return (char) (b & 0xFF);   } 2.  void skipControlCharacters() {   ...   while ( < ) {     char c = (char) ([++] & 0xFF);   ...   }  "'

column10: b"b' @trustin @Scottmitch wdyt ?'"

b'b" I believe it\'s pretty common in CJK world that header values contain non-ASCII characters. It would be very useful for them if we preserve all the bits. i.e. +1 for @ByunghyunBang\'s suggestion.  However
column11: we may want to disable this behavior by default and ignore the header entries that violates the RFC to avoid potential issues that non-CJK world users might experience."'

column10: b'b\' @trustin I wonder what "issues" you would expect. Can you clarify ?\''
b'b" @normanmaurer A user might assume the header values decoded by Netty will always be strictly 7-bit ASCII and write  code based on that assumption
column11: which can cause an unexpected exception on their side.  I think this PR is fine to be merged as-is because we didn\'t care much about non-ASCII characters yet anyway.  We may want to come up with another PR that adds  mode for header decoding in the future."'

b"b' [Proposal] Keep information about the  that released the buffer'"

b'b" From time to time you get this notorious which basically means that you released the same buffer twice. It can be a real pain in the neck to track down the method which released this particular buffer.  It\'s especially painful if you have a quite large pipeline and you\'re juggling with instances back and forth. The exception itself tells only two things:  1.  The buffer was already released (i.e. its reference counter is zero) 2.  The actual stack trace which shows you which method and in which class called the method  It would be great if Netty could keep some information about the caller in the ByteBuf instances. So when you call the method and see that the reference counter is zero
column11: you could attach this information to the exception message and a user would know who released this particular buffer earlier.  I think it would simplify the debugging process a little bit. At the moment it can often be impossible to understand who released the buffer without knowing this additional information about the previous caller.   or something similar should do the trick. This feature can also be implemented as a special type of which can only be enabled with some startup option (like a memory leak detector). Because it\'ll definitely be very costly to use this feature all the time
column12: I think.  WDYT?"'

column10: b"b' @maseev it looks like you are looking for the feature provided by  ? [This wiki page]url  details how to use it. Or am I missing something in your proposal?'"

b'b\' This request sounds different than  . Instead of detecting things that aren\\\'t released (what tries to do) this is requesting tracking call stack information when a buffer is actually released to help debug "double release" scenarios.  As you indicated I think the challenge here is balancing overhead introduced by the additional tracking and potential API impacts. Do we retain a field in each object and increase the memory footprint of each object (even if we are not "tracking" would we still have an additional member variable to track)? Do we sample like we do for ref counting ... what if your object wasn\\\'t sampled do we offer a mode to track all deallocations? How common is this in practice and is it worth the additional  to track this?\''

b'b"  This feature can be implemented the same way as the memory leak detection subsystem. You pass a option with the desired level and instead of receiving simple you start receiving instances.  But the end users won\'t notice any differences because they primarily work with a class. The similar approach can be used to implement this feature. But I think it would be rather problematic to allow users use the memory leak detection and \'double release\' detection features at the same time. It\'s not necessary. This feature can only be enabled when the user passes a special startup option. So
column11: when this option is present
column12: we work with a special subtype of class which can remember who released it. But when the option is not present
column13: we work with the good old (or something similar) which obviously doesn\'t have any overhead related to this new feature. I think you can \'sample\' all deallocations. You can check the reference counter field and if it\'s greater than zero then you just update this field which keeps the information about the previous caller of the method. But if you see that this counter is zero
column14: you get the information about the previous caller and attach it to the exception message. The more I work with Netty and the more I use different components (TLS and other types of handlers)
column15: the more often I see this exception. The same question can be asked about the memory leak detection subsystem. Is it that common that people who use Netty simply forget to call release and end up with OOM? These two features are common in this regard. It\'s very simple you receive a instance and you either release it or pass it down the pipeline.  I encountered a very weird scenario not so long ago when a device from one manufacturer had connected to the server
column16: passed the handshake and then disconnected abruptly because the server blew up with the exception in some of the Netty\'s class (it wasn\'t one of the server\'s handlers). When I tested the same case with a different device the test passed without any exceptions. For some reason switching from to did the trick. But it\'s basically a workaround not a solution of the problem."'

column10: b'b"  Hum I don\'t have cycles to think too deeply about this problem but it would be nice to avoid introducing another layer of object  and work out how this interacts with the leak detection layer. I don\'t see why having both on (leak detection and double release) simultaneously would logically be a problem ... more a question of how its implemented. I wonder if enhancing the leak detection to also (optionally?) track double release too makes sense... Note that this doesn\'t necessarily mean that there is an issue in Netty. If for example the Netty class is designed to retain reference count ownership this means the application called it shouldn\'t have. This is worrisome and agreed it would be better to understand the root cause."'

b'b" >I wonder if enhancing the leak detection to also (optionally?) track double release too makes sense...  This is probably the only way it can be implemented so that users could use this two features at the same time. At least
column11: this is the only way I could come up with. Or it can be implemented as a separate feature (not an enhancement of the memory leak detection feature). But in this case
column12: Netty would need to check what features are enabled and throw an exception if these two features were turned on.  >Note that this doesn\'t necessarily mean that there is an issue in Netty. If for example the Netty class is designed to retain reference count ownership this means the application called release() it shouldn\'t have.  I agree. But the strange thing is at the time of testing I had the only implementation of the pipeline which handled connections from these devices. And only one type of the device was making the server throw this exception.  >This is worrisome and agreed it would be better to understand the root cause.  Again
column13: it\'s quite difficult to say what went wrong without knowing who released that particular buffer before. It\'s interesting that this particular feature was already implemented during the investigation of this [ticket]url "'

b'b" The problem with calling  (or the public API ()) is that it only clears _the current thread_. Some of this was discussed way back in 2014 url  Setting the ThreadLocal to would _help_ the problem
column11: which destroy() did before url  (I figured out the answer to the question!).  ThreadLocalMap (the thing stored in Thread) has a weak reference to ThreadLocal but a strong reference to the value. But since the value is a Netty type it has a strong reference to the ClassLoader which has a reference to the static ThreadLocal. So the ThreadLocal will never be GC\'d for the life of the Thread.  ThreadLocal lazily cleans up GC\'d ThreadLocals from ThreadLocalMap when adding new entries. So clearing the reference to the ThreadLocal will allow it to be GC\'d and then you can hope enough other users of ThreadLocal come along and trigger a clean up of the specific Entry for our ThreadLocal.  @normanmaurer
column12: this reminds me of -it-was :)."'

b"b' Allow to detect failed query caused by an Timeout / IO error and also\\xe2\\x80\\xa6'"

b"b' \\xe2\\x80\\xa6 not cache these.  Motivation:  At the moment there is not way for the user to know if resolving a domain was failed because the domain was unkown or because of an IO error / timeout. If it was caused by an timeout / IO error the user may want to retry the query. Also if the query was failed because of an IO error / timeout we should not cache it.  Modifications:  Add DnsNameResolverTimeoutException and include it in the UnkownHostException if the domain could not be resolved because of an timeout. This will allow the user to retry the query when inspecting the cause. Do not cache IO errors / timeouts Add unit test  Result:  Easier for users to implement retries for DNS querys and not cache IO errors / timeouts. '"
b"b' @slandelle FYI'"
b"b' @Scottmitch btw I wonder if we should also add another option to DnsNameResolver to allow configure a retry on timeout / IO error. I think that is usually what you want and expect.'"

b"b' Determination of MAX_DIRECT_MEMORY in  fails on '"
b'b\' ### Expected behavior  MAX_DIRECT_MEMORY
column11: which controls later behaviour of Netty
column12: should be initialized with correct value.  ### Actual behavior On  netty initializes this value with 64M
column13: even the direct accessible memory is actually unbounded.  Reason is the way
column14: how the IBM Java VM administrates direct memory.  The Windowsor Linux-based VMs report the correct final value asking the corresponding APIs
column15: i.e. ((). But the IBM JVM on  returns here just the initial start value for accessible direct memory
column16: 64MB
column17: even this is not the final limit. (see [url  The IBM JVM increments this value on demand in 32MB steps.  Netty asks only once in a static initializer for this value and
column18: for
column19: erroneously assumes
column20: that would be the final value.  The so unnecessarily bounded value of 64M leads finally to  memory (used: 67092277
column21: max: 67108864)  at (:615)  Conclusion: on  the used APIs offer not the desired correct value for available direct memory.  Suggested solution: the heuristic in () has to consider the . In case of  the first try with () is to skip. the following search for -XX:MaxDirectMemorySize or () may offer the correct value.  by the way: limit the available direct memory with -XX:MaxDirectMemorySize=512M helps as workarround. Adding this argument at start the IBM VM returns 512M as initial value which is quite the correct final value.  ### Steps to reproduce run added code on ### Minimal yet complete reproducer code (or URL to code) This code is a copy of  ()
column22: needed method added
column23: Shortcuts removed
column24: some () added.   Output: ### Netty version occured with 4.1.13

column10: b'b" According to IBM docs: There is no hard limit
column11: until -XX:MaxDirectMemorySize is specified on command line. It will keep allocating until the process hits whatever limits are set by the kernel on the process. This is probably a dangerous default policy
column12: IMHO. Having Netty enforce a reasonable default limit on direct memory allocation is still a good idea you just have to pick a value by some other means. However
column13: if you see () is higher than your chosen default limit
column14: you should go with the higher one. This means the user probably explicitly configured a limit
column15: and you will want to respect that. That\'s my two cents."'

column12: I use  &  that I\'m not releasing. eg.  Do these count as memory leaks?"'

column10: b"b' The first yes if its a object the second not if you pass it to or  '"
b"b' See url  for more info on reference counting.'"
b'b" I have a few concerns here  @Scottmitch  _Since Netty version 4
column11: the life cycle of certain objects are managed by their reference counts
column12: so that Netty can return them (or their shared resources) to an **object pool** (or an object allocator) as soon as it is not used anymore..._  So what is the point on reference counting Unpooled buffers?  @normanmaurer  Does ChannelInboundHandlerAdapter automatically reference count channelRead\'s msg Object ? is this a direct memory buffer? Is this also if a byteBuf object is used in a  for writing?   Also
column13: I found that both Unpooled.**copiedBuffer** and Unpooled.**wrappedBuffer** in my case are reference counted once they constructed by their nature (in ) but they are heap based **and not** direct.  1: Unpooled.**copiedBuffer**(XML
column14: ) in this case  **** class is called which calls where true=enforceHeap  2: Unpooled.**wrappedBuffer**((byte[]) packet)  so both are heap based buffers.  Eventually
column15: there must be 2 leaks 1) A direct(?) memory leak because I use **ChannelInboundHandlerAdapter** channelRead instead of **SimpleChannelInboundHandler** channelRead**0** and I do not release the msg object that is automatically ReferenceCounted on channelRead.  2) A heap memory leak due to reference counting in (byte[]...) & (CharSequence...)
column16: since I\'m not always writing the created byteBufs to a channel.  However heap usage always goes down to bottom after full gc when all clients disconnect. And I can\'t access the private static field () that is used at the  in order to do some tests with direct memory metrics. "'

column10: b'b"  1. We may not use the JDK\'s default allocation mechanisms for performance reasons. This means you may leak direct memory if you are not properly releasing. 2. If you are conditionally releasing based upon what allocator you start with ... it will be difficult later to switch between  allocators. All objects are reference counted. Anything that implements [ReferenceCounted]url  is reference counted."'
b"b' Very useful information

b"b' RFC: Reimplement Recycler to reduce impact of pathological cases'"
b'b\' Motivation:  Recycler is hard to tune and reduces performance in same cases. Inspired by the simplicity and large performance gains seen with Go\\\'s
column11: which only reuses objects between GCs
column12: it seemed a more conservative approach could be applied to Recycler. Note that this looks nothing like
column13: as Recycler has _very_ different trade-offs and environment.  Modifications:  Reimplement Recycler as a weak reference free list
column14: with low rate of recycler-enabled objects and heuristics for reusing older objects. Add a nanobenchmark to better contrast the implementation options
column15: especially with the \\\'gc\\\' profiler.  Result:  A Recycler that can improve performance while worst-case would have neglible impact to GC
column16: memory
column17: and CPU use.  - There\\\'s no rush for this and it wouldn\\\'t bother me to close it. I couldn\\\'t find the issue where we were talking about disabling the Recycler. This PR should not be considered an argument against doing that; this was a "fun thing" that had interesting enough results I thought I should share. _I honestly don\\\'t know if it\\\'s worth anyone\\\'s time to look into this as a "solution" to Recycler._  I\\\'ve only run some nanobenchmarks against this. The "generational" behavior in particular is unproven
column18: although it looks interesting. It\\\'s possible it is unnecessary and just a single LIFO linked list would be enough
column19: but I went ahead with it because it was the more conservative approach and shouldn\\\'t be any worse than the single list approach.  I was a bit worried about whether having so many weak references could cause GC slowdowns; weak refs aren\\\'t something I tend to see at large scale. But I think many such concerns are addressed by the 1% sampling.  Although it didn\\\'t show up in the code at all
column20: I should note it is _really_ easy to add statistics to the linked list like its length or how reused the objects were
column21: and then have that available _after_ a GC threw the list away by keeping the stats in the WeakRef.  The new implementation doesn\\\'t need to use ObjectCleaner :smile:.\''

b'b\'  This handles that case by the recycling thread receiving "ownership" of the recycled instance (no pushLater). If that receiving thread needs to allocate in the future
column11: it can use the recycled instance. So if coordinating between Netty threads
column12: it should work well.  If the recycling thread won\\\'t ever need instances (it\\\'s not a producer as well) or there\\\'s an imbalance
column13: then no (or limited) reuse will be performed. This is when the 1% sampling kicks in and predominantly uses non-recyclable instances
column14: effectively as if the Recycler wasn\\\'t being used. Note that this is opposite to dropHandle() which drops objects when recycling; they are instead _created_ with the inability to be recycled.  It would be possible to have a larger shared pool to put things in when a particular generation\\\'s list grows too long
column15: or something. But it would need synchronization and Java\\\'s GC seems better suited to that case.  I didn\\\'t entirely follow how worked in the previous implementation. That\\\'s partly because I spent time confused until I realized is a static ThreadLocal whereas was non-static.  before for producerConsumer is 66 . I believe that\\\'s halved

column11: it took me a little bit to grok this patch
column12: and I\'m still not totally sure of its intent I wonder if you could explain at a high level what you expect this algorithm to do
column13: and why you think this would work well?  As it stands
column14: it looks like it will lose its contents on every GC (or
column15: at least
column16: most or part of its contents
column17: and potentially all on a major GC)
column18: so only those items that are in use across a GC boundary will be available for allocation (or \\xe2\\x80\\x98promotion\\xe2\\x80\\x99)?  If so
column19: that seems a much weaker semantic of recycler
column20: and will never reach a stable garbage-free point?  It\\xe2\\x80\\x99s possible you intended to use SoftReference?  This leads to its own semantic problems
column21: but we can have a better discussion once we know what you intended as the algorithm
column22: and what you anticipate its behaviour to be?  There\'s certainly some elegance to the idea of a self-tuning pool
column23: although it is never truly self-tuning.  Here we\\xe2\\x80\\x99re externalising our tuning onto GC parameters
column24: which are already notoriously hard to deal with
column25: and must handle many competing pressures.  Right now
column26: my understanding of Recycler\\xe2\\x80\\x99s main cause of pain is cross-thread recycling.  This is because we tried to absolutely minimise CPU cost without bounding memory cost
column27: and I can see a lot of minor mitigations have been done to improve the situation
column28: without properly tackling it.  This problem is most pronounced when there are a LOT (perhaps hundreds) of threads recycling to each other
column29: and explains the MAX_DELAYED_QUEUES_PER_THREAD option.  In this case
column30: it\'s fairly likely there will be distinct producer and consumer threads
column32: this patch doesn\'t address this problem. In effect it disables the recycler in this case
column33: but with some extra GC burden as we have to wait a couple of GC cycles to discard the unusable objects.  It\'s probably best not to conflate these distinct problems in a single patch
column34: given the complexities of each.  There are a lot of things that can be done for this problem
column35: that are orthogonal to the main thrust of this patch and should probably be addressed independently IMO.  Some that spring to mind:  * Our WeakOrderQueue recycles 16 items at once (configurably); there\\xe2\\x80\\x99s no reason to actually prevent the allocating thread from seeing the chunk immediately
column36: so that we can recycle objects before we have amassed 16 * Per-thread we can track the maximum number of allocated buffers we had in-flight at any one time; if we currently have fewer than this in our buffer
column37: we could steal an object we would have recycled to another thread.  If the thread never allocates
column38: we will cross-thread recycle as normal
column39: but we will save many such cross-thread recycles otherwise. * We could automatically switch to a shared MpscQueue that is not weakly ordered if there are too many WeakOrderQueue
column40: particularly if there are hundreds of threads cross-recycling to each other (though probably this will be of much lesser importance with the above mitigations) * We can and perhaps should impose system-wide recycler limits
column42: and have each Recycler and WeakOrderQueue take permits as necessary *  we could offer very similar cross-thread guarantees as this patch
column43: that only recycles to the thread performing the recycling
column44: but guarantees no memory leaks to those that only recycle
column45: never allocate. * We can also offer the option of simply disabling cross-thread recycling
column46: possibly on a per-recycler basis as well as system-wide.  So that those who benefit from simple recycling can do so
column47: without having to turn off recycling entirely.  FWIW
column48: the benchmark as created is probably too limited to be of use IMO
column49: as it only ever has one object in flight at a time.  In real use there may be hundreds or thousands of allocated objects that are in use and yet to be recycled.  I\\xe2\\x80\\x99ve pushed a suggestion for a general approach that would at least somewhat account for this behaviour here: url  though I haven\'t played with it extensively  We should also ideally be benchmarking cross-thread recycling
column50: in both the mixed  and the isolated  cases."'

column10: b'b\'  Hmmm... I felt like the documentation I added at the very top of Recycler did that. Based on the other comments it seems it may be a case of "yes
column11: it really does that." Yes
column12: it loses contents every GC. The problem with the previous Recycler implementation is that it could retain objects too long and didn\\\'t have a trigger to stop saving objects. This new one takes the approach that if it reuses an object 100 times between two GC\\\'s
column13: then that\\\'s a win
column14: even if the object is then GCed. Why does it need to wait a couple of GC cycles? All objects that can be cleaned up will be cleaned up
column15: excepting a single WeakReference per thread.  Also
column16: the sampling approach taken means that even if the recycler is not helping
column17: it is unlikely to cause harm. Recyclable objects will only accumulate if they are being reused. I wasn\\\'t "trying to fix Recycler" per se. I was addressing the concerns that 1) Recycler causes harm in some workloads
column18: 2) it\\\'s hard to tell which work loads it helps and which it hurts
column19: 3) manual tuning helps it
column20: so the problems with (1) and (2) may just be poor tuning
column21: and 4) we were seriously considering deleting Recycler completely.  In the face of that
column22: I realized I could greatly reduce the  of Recycler by being okay with objects being GCed. Everything else was just gravy to further reduce . But how do we validate those changes
column23: and determine if they resolve issues with pathological environments without creating new issues? The problem is the Recycler performance can\\\'t be truly tested without a real heap and real application behavior. That means we need to run a wide variety of real application benchmarks  Recycler and see what happens. That\\\'s been obviously too high a cost to validate a plethera of optimizations and for iteration.  This new recycler on the other hand targets very low cost in general
column24: and then chips away at easy gains that help in certain scenarios while being unlikely to harm other scenarios. That was not the point of the benchmark. The benchmark was to show the pure overhead of the approach. It was targeting the worst-case. In showing the worst-case performance loss is small
column25: if we show a single use-case where it helps (via real-world benchmarks) then at that point it is already "safe" and "helpful."  Also
column26: some of the benchmarks were just to increase confidence that the code was behaving as expected. Meh. Number of allocated objects doesn\\\'t really matter to this implementation
column27: nor did it seem to matter with the previous implementation.  The point of the Recycler is not to reuse objects. There\\\'s no "performance gain" from that directly. The point of the Recycler is to reduce the frequency of GCs. And the cost of GCs depends directly on the actual heap used and application allocation behavior. So anything short of a real application benchmark provides little signal for whether the Recycler is helping.\''

column10: b'b\'  Two things: 1) _retained_ objects mainly contribute to GC overhead
column11: not collected objects. 2) the number of objects in the recycler should be within the rounding error of memory usage in an actual application (if it\\\'s not
column12: that\\\'s a problem). The application\\\'s own retained objects will be contributing the majority GC cost per collection. Yes
column13: it ignored directly measuring the GC burden
column14: because that can only be measured in a real application. The GC burden comes from everything-that-is-not-the-recycler. It was mainly focused on CPU usage since that is where the worst-case performance loss should come from. It did measure allocation rate
column15: which will contribute to GC burden
column16: to get an idea of how it behaves.  GC burden = per-GC cost x frequency of GCs. The Recycler can only provide benefit by reducing the frequency of GCs. Recycler\\\'s in a no-man\\\'s land
column17: but the only expected action to take before this PR was to delete it. The main discussion around the Recycler has been "delete it" because it keeps causing performance degradation and lots of people have disabled it to good effect. But deleting it is also risky because it could be contributing well in some cases. But there\\\'s only a history of decisions; not something that we can test changes against to iterate on the implementation. So it\\\'s sort of stuck in a "can\\\'t move forward; can\\\'t move backward" state
column18: unless we expend a lot more energy on it.  This change tries to side-step the problem by having a zero-tuning system that works well when it works and does almost nothing when it doesn\\\'t. I completely agree. This is one of the reasons I\\\'d be in favor of trashing the Recycler
column19: because the things being Recycled have mainly just been guesses as to what would be "helpful." And the current Recycler can hurt as much as it helps.  But with this proposed recycler
column20: the risk of getting the trade-off wrong is much lower. I\\\'d still be happy if we were more precise in when we choose to use the Recycler
column21: but it\\\'s not something we\\\'re going to get 100% right as it is work-load dependent and this change decreases the chances of the Recycler being harmful.  Now I agree there may be cases where we should cross-thread recycle
column22: although that probably is only "byte buffers" and we already do that. Today
column23: Recycler is only usable for _cheap_ objects
column24: because otherwise it will cache far too many. So this new Recycler is no worse off. We know the sources of the _negative_ effects today: memory usage and CPU use. Let\\\'s say you only do cross-thread operations. Then the Recycler is pure overhead. And it can contribute overhead via over-caching (memory) and managing the cache (CPU). It avoids us needing to hand-optimize various use-cases as it is self-tuning and has low overhead when unhelpful. It also handles well the cases Recycler handles well. The Recycler is pretty old and we\\\'re really no better off with having a good benchmark suite than when it first began. I understand the value of trying to reach a local maxima
column25: but I see no evidence we are approaching that right now with Recycler.  The only knowledge as an ecosystem I think we have today is "try turning off Recycler and see if it helps." In what use-case do you think this new implementation would increase GC burden compared to the previous implementation? I agree there is risk that we may overlook something
column26: but I thought it was clear I had tried to cover the bases.  The only major risk I identified is we could cause objects to be promoted to older generations only to soon thereafter orphan them (because the weak reference linked list was broken). I pre-emptively added handling for that case that seems work work well for CMS. I agree it wouldn\\\'t work as well for G1. But it still seems better than the current Recycler.  We _know_ that the current Recycler increases  burden for many applications
column27: as many applications have disabled the Recycler completely. I feel like the bar is very low.\''

column10: b'b" So
column11: before completely signing off
column12: I figure I should say what I think a reasonable course of action would be...  1. There seems to me clearly some value in maintaining the same-thread recycling behaviour we have today
column13: even if it is simplified dramatically and has much stricter constraints put upon it (e.g. limiting the size of each thread\'s stack more than it is today).  Netty is a library used by applications who both do and don\'t care about generating garbage
column14: and given the tools are already present to limit garbage
column15: it seems unnecessary to discard them for use cases where it is trivially beneficial. 2. If we think cross-thread recycling is really bad (which it probably is
column16: at least with applications with many threads)
column17: using a modified version of this patch\'s approach
column18: where a thread recycling an object from another thread first puts it onto a queue whose head is a WeakReference
column19: so that it\'s always guaranteed to be in Eden and collected swiftly (of which only one is maintained per recycler).  There would be no WeakReference allocated for a handle
column20: so there would be at most one WeakReference per thread X recycler at any one time
column21: and we would anticipate very few unused objects making it to tenured
column22: though many may make it to Survivor II.  This would be a more modest change to the current design
column23: probably retaining much of the benefit
column24: and limiting any of the possible downsides that have been proposed or inferred.  As far as limits are concerned
column25: given recyclers are thread-local
column26: there could quite easily be global hard-limits imposed per-thread (across _all_ recyclers) or soft-limits imposed across the process (also across all recyclers)
column27: with each Recycler defining a Weigher for its items (using either a constant or simple arithmetic for dynamically sized objects).  This would guarantee bounded memory utilisation
column28: and the CPU burden would remain low
column29: as it would be a simple stack
column30: with only two extremely simple single-threaded queues to consult and maintain."'

column11: part of the point of this PR is that it requires no tuning. At the end of the day I want to stop thinking about the Recycler and optimizing it for my (users\\\') workloads. That was not possible previously. This PR sheds some hope for that reality
column12: and it\\\'s half the LOC to boot!  While I value pre-existing code (which I agree is frequently undervalued)
column13: I do find suggestions of patching the Recycler in ways A
column14: B
column15: and C to start looking like a sunk cost fallacy. I agree the Recycler could be improved
column16: but I think it is close to a local maximum. In a very large heap
column17: minor GC costs easily come from the mark phase as the GC needs to scan the large heap in order to find references to the very small eden. This cost increases the more tenured objects mutate
column18: as pages containing those objects have to be scanned to see if they reference an object in eden (see card marking). The sweep is relatively low cost since worst-case it copies all of eden but eden is small. I agree reducing the GC rate is beneficial
column19: and there can be multiple ways that comes to pass. But that\\\'s all beside the point. My point was that a benchmark needs to have a _real heap_ with _real behavior_ modifying that heap
column20: since the GC needs to traverse that heap to determine what is trash. If the heap isn\\\'t filled with GBs of objects (real objects
column21: not some synthetic construction)
column22: then you aren\\\'t actually seeing a realistic per-GC cost.  > But you don\\\'t know a priori whether an object will be used for local or cross-thread recycling. The current Recycler has a high per-object allocation cost in terms of relative GC churn. is 56 bytes in size. Consider which is using Recycler and is 48 bytes; the recycler allocation is larger than the object to be recycled. All of this "it\\\'s trivial" seems to be ignoring the point that "it\\\'s not trivial." Or rather
column23:
if it\\\'s so trivial please send a PR because it isn\\\'t trivial to me." Simply deciding between those options doesn\\\'t seem trivial to me, each having its own tradeoffs. Unfortunately it can\\\'t work that way because WeakReferences are "immutable" (the reference stored within the WeakReference object can\\\'t be changed, other than cleared). To have a WeakReference point at an object, you must allocate that WeakReference. My problem with that is it is workload dependent. There isn\\\'t a "one size fits all" appropriate limit. This is the normal problem with free lists. Some applications may only need 3 objects and some may need over 1000. And many applications have needs that vary over time. We\\\'ve not looking to limit the Big-O; we do that mostly already, I thought.\''

b"b' Motivation: should be (reasonably) cheap to invoke so it can be used within observability. Modifications:  Remove code that dispatch access to the internal taskqueue to the EventLoop when invoked as this is not needed anymore with the current MPSC queues we are using. See #8196 (comment). b'b\' Hmm
column11: no
column12: that is the opposite of what you want to do. By bailing early you are preventing any  domains from ever resolving. That\\\'s the entire point of allowing multiple resolvers
column13: if one fails or can\\\'t find the domain
column14: you try others. Not every domain name or sub domain is on a public resolver. If 8.8.8.8 returns first with "no result" and that\\\'s the only result you use
column15: then private domains will never work.\''

column10: b'b" I\'m curious if there is any RFC section that tells us what to do in this case
column11: i.e. try other name server on NXDOMAIN. Such a behavior would increase the load on secondary name server and total lookup time for a non-existent domain name
column12: and it doesn\'t sound like a good idea to me."'

b'b" I know what you mean
column11: but the entire point of private domains is that a public query would return NXDOMAIN. Here\'s my setup:  * Ethernet connection: IP Address in the 192.168.55.X single DNS Resolver at 192.168.55.5 * VPN IP Address in the 10 range
column12: Primary DNS 10 Secondary DNS 10  The regular ethernet connections DNS resolver is a standard recusive resolver with cache. It will never be able to resolve things that are private to the company (i.e. dig someHost@myCompany or dig someHost@ will always return NXDOMAIN). This is expected because I don\'t have access to those resolvers that know about those domains when off the VPN.  The VPN dns servers (both primary and secondary) can resolve those as they know of the internal domain names.  In this setup I effectively have 2 primary resolvers
column13: one for standard ethernet
column14: and another for the VPN. If netty only takes my public resolving DNS as the primary
column15: then the internal domain names over the company VPN will never get picked up."'

b"b' When you are connected to VPN
column11: the VPN software should update the  so that only the internal DNS servers are used. On disconnection
column12: the VPN software should update the  again back to the public DNS servers. You should not mix public and internal DNS server. If you would
column13: you have to put the private ones *before* the public ones.  Is your VPN connection established *after* you start up your Netty application? Then Netty may use the outdated public DNS servers to send queries
column14: but otherwise
column15: all is working as expected in my opinion.'"

column10: b'b\' So
column11: I ran a wireshark on port 53 as suggested. Looks like the preferred order for nslookup when using git-bash on windows is to use the VPN DNS first. It appears that the priority is correct at the OS level. I only see  queries against "default" server (since nslookup only uses a single server).  I then tested it using Firefox and it used all 3 DNS servers. It actually tried resolving against the non-VPN server first
column12: which failed:  . Firefox then followed up with subsequent queries to the other DNS servers on the VPN.  The actual order of the  from Firefox looked like this: 1. Parallel request to the 2 primary DNS interfaces (VPN and Non-VPN. I assume if I had 3 interfaces up
column13: it would have sent 3 requests
column14: one for each primary... maybe not though) 2. Primary non-VPN request failed 3. Request sent to secondary DNS on the VPN 4. Primary DNS on the VPN responded with a success 5. Secondary DNS on the VPN responded with a success.  Running wireshark against Chrome provided a similar workflow (querying all the DNS servers)
column15: but instead ran against the VPN DNs servers first.  Technically from a traffic perspective Chrome is worse as it makes lots of calls out to google services that are really just unnecessary.  I guess the end result is what you are trying to accomplish with this resolver. If you want it to match the specs as close as possible and work more like a "dig" or "nslookup"
column16: then no changes would be needed. It would be doing it\\\'s job as-designed. If your expectation is that this resolver is used for end-user applications
column17: then it should probably ignore NXDOMAIN and try against other servers in order to try and  get a working record. \''

column10: b"b' @trustin I am still not 100 % sure what to do about this in general but that said what you think about refresh the DNS servers / search domains on regular basis just as the JDK is doing:  url   ?'"
b'b" I think there are two action items:  Refreshing the System DNS resolver configuration periodically This may or may not be relevant to this issue
column11: but we should fix this. Changing the behavior of our DNS resolver so that it\'s behavior is on par with that of the host OS. This probably will fix this issue but I\'m not 100% sure if it\'s worth fixing it given the complexity and its platform-dependent nature. It\'d be natural to behave in the same way with host OS\'s behavior from Windows users\' standpoint
column12: though. Would love to listen to what other folks think about this."'
