b"b' HashedWheelTimer should support sub-ms tickDurations'"
b'b" Motivation:  waitForNextTick converts the sleep time to ms
column11: so when the HWT constructor is passed a tickDuration shorter than 1 ms
column12: waitForNextTick doesn\'t sleep. This is misleading since HWT\'s tickDuration seems to have nanosecond granularity.  Modifications:  Replace (...) with (...) and so be able to use tick durations < 1ms.  Result:  Fixes url "'

column10: b'b" @normanmaurer I\'m not sure I like this approach.  Since we can\'t actually do better than 50us on any platform
column11: why do we expose an API that lets users pretend we can?  It seems better to continue just supporting millisecondly timers and communicate it better.  this also has the benefit that we don\'t have to worry about what happens when something gets ported to windows."'

column10: b"b' @mosesn I am not strong on this... How do other feel about it ?'"
b'b" My personal preference: always use nanos everywhere.  @mosesn The JDK uses nanos consistently throughout its APIs
column11: even if the underlying system can\'t get that accurate.  For the sake of avoiding conversion bugs (which are frequent
column12: dangerous
column13: and hard to spot)
column14: I think nanos makes the most sense.  "'

column10: b'b" The HWT [docs]url  mention that the timer isn\'t meant for precision
column11: and the lower the tickDuration
column12: the less precise the scheduling will be. I suppose we can change this but I\'m curious why this was the original intent. I haven\'t run precision benchmarks myself but [this blog post]url  suggests we can do better with
column13: but maybe only to microseconds
column14: not nanoseconds."'

column10: b'b" @carl-mastrangelo for measurement
column11: but not for . The JDK only exposes millisecondly granularity for its Timers
column12: and for .  url I think the reason they do that is because they had low confidence that other operating systems could support finer granularity sleeping than millisecondly.  That\'s probably not as big a problem for netty
column13: I bet most people use linux
column14: but I think that HWT has other good reasons why we shouldn\'t support sub-millisecondly sleeping.  In particular
column15: I think there\'s a risk that we\'ll just spend all of our time going to sleep and waking up if people think they can use sub-millisecondly tick duration.  I\'d rather prevent people from shooting themselves in the foot by disallowing sub-millisecondly stuff."'

column10: b'b" @mosesn I haven\'t ever seen Timer used in code
column11: and I believe  does support nanos.  Also
column12: as far as I can tell
column13: all the APIs added 1.5 and after (i.e. the concurrency ones) all do use nanos
column14: as that\'s what park natively speaks.  Though
column15: to be honest
column16: I have never used HWT and I don\'t really know it\'s use.  Maybe people do expect it to be real time and sleep for exact amounts."'

column10: b"b' Also
column11: if a user wanted to sleep for 1.5ms
column12: using ms granularity would be wrong.  1ms would be too short
column13: and 2 ms too long.  Same for the aforementioned 50us on linux.  While 50us may not be feasible
column15: 050us might be.'"

column10: b'b" @carl-mastrangelo  only pretends to accept nanos: url And given the HWT wakes up on every tick
column11: there\'s no good way to achieve 1050us precision without using a tick duration of 50us
column12: which would effectively entail sleeping and waking every 50us.  Why does HWT need to be all things to all people?  I don\'t think providing an extremely high precision timer is part of netty\'s core competency.  I think all we need is to have a reasonably good API that\'s easy to use the right way."'

column10: b'b" If users haven\'t requested support for sub-ms tickDurations then I don\'t see the point of adding it right now. It\'s unclear to me that changing the implementation wouldn\'t impact performance for users who currently pass sub-ms tickDurations."'
b'b" I would personally be super happy if we just replaced HTW\'s constructor as following:   Although
column11: I understand this wont be easy to do as this is a breaking API change. UPDATE: Sorry for the unintentional  for a PR. "'

column10: b"b' Ensure FlowControlled data frames will be correctly removed from the \\xe2\\x80\\xa6'"

b"b' \\xe2\\x80\\xa6flow-controller when a write error happens.  Motivation:  When a write error happens during writing of flowcontrolled data frames we miss to correctly detect this in the write loop which may result in an infinite loop as we will never detect that the frame should be removed from the queue.  Modifications:  When we fail a flowcontrolled data frame we ensure that the next (...) call will signal back that the whole frame was handled and so can be removed. Add unit test.  Result:  Fixes url '"

b"b' Read the source code : The problem with waiters in DefaultPromise .'"
b"b' The waiters in DefaultPromise use synchronized(this) when they operate
column11: and use decWaiters immediately after using incWaiters. Waiters are not always between 1 and 0. What is the meaning of this?'"

column10: b"b' sorry I dont get what you are asking for... maybe link to the code and give some example what you think should be changed ?'"
b'b" There is no place to understand
column11: just don\'t understand why the author did this
column12: and it bothered me. The waiters variable in DefaultPromise has the current lock for his operation. This means that the waiters can only be 1 and 0. Is that true? Thank you very much for your answer."'

column10: b"b' @duaicxx not sure I correctly understand your question but even it has the current lock others can obtain it once it executed  . See also url '"
b'b" Well
column11: this is the case
column12: but the waiters do the subtraction before releasing the lock
column13: which means that the waiters get the lock plus 1 minus 1 when the lock is released
column14: so the waiters always switch between 1 and 0. The problem is only I don\'t borrow when I read the source code. I don\'t know if I missed the idea of the author doing this
column15: so I raised this question. Thank you very much for your answers and delay your time."'

column10: b"b' @duaicxx if you have a shared DefaultPromise multiple threads may invoke await and subsequently wait() putting the thread into WAITING state
column11: at this point waiters can increase all the way up to .. when the promise is fulfilled (success or failure) all waiting threads will be notified and finally decrement the waiters value.'"

b"b' Message aware cumulators'"
b'b\' Motivation:  Reduce the number of bytes that may need to be copied when parsing multiple messages in a class extending ByteToMessageDecoder
column11: and permit bounding the size of the ByteBuf needed to stash unread bytes for future invocations.  Modification:  Modified the semantics and usage of Cumulator so that it may be "message aware" knowing how much data is needed to be able to parse another message.  Using this information
column12: it may choose to only partially fill a cumulation with its input bytes
column13: so long as an entire message may be read.  Ideally
column14: only exactly the number of bytes necessary to read a message will be copied
column15: after which the remaining bytes will be processed from the input ByteBuf.  If any bytes remain unread at the end of channelRead
column16: the Cumulator is invoked to decide how to persist them across invocations
column17: so that a precisely sized buffer for the message may be allocated.  \''

Also I\'m curious whether you tried out with your decoder if byte copying / buffer alloc overhead is significant. column10: b'b" @njhill thanks for the suggestion; I\'ve posted above a table of some short runs of the benchmark I have pushed to the PR on my laptop; if anybody has dedicated hardware they can throw at more authoritative runs that would be great.  The benchmark writes a single byte to the channel
column11: then a large buffer of varying sizes
column12: parsing messages of varying sizes.  The first input buffer is optionally (fBHCFOM) large enough to fit a single message.  As you can see
column13: the MESSAGE_AWARE_MERGE manages to get the best of both worlds
column14: never really being appreciably slower than either the COMPOSITE or MERGE best cases.  MERGE is never faster (modulo fractions of error bars).  COMPOSITE wins only the 512 messageSize
column15: 1024 totalInputSize (i.e. an input of 1 byte
column16: input of 1023 bytes
column17: then skipping 512 bytes twice to parse).  This is weighted in favour of COMPOSITE
column18: because of the efficiency of parsing.  The test has the option of making parsing happen byte-by-byte to simulate a heavier parsing burden
column19: and with this enabled it loses handily to MESSAGE_AWARE_MERGE.  I have not included the results of this for all options
column20: as I don\'t have time to dedicate my laptop to the task.  Note in particular 16/65536 for which both COMPOSITE and MERGE lose by a significant margin
column21: no doubt because this factors in the increased indirection costs for COMPOSITE
column22: while including worst case  effects for MERGE.  This is despite MERGE having exclusive access to a pooled buffer allocator
column23: and performing only same-thread recycling.  FWIW
column24: I have also written a message aware Cumulator for lz4 that we can include in this patch if we want
column25: or I can open a separate PR for that at a later time."'

b'b\' @belliottsmith @normanmaurer I\\\'ve given this some more thought and am not sure whether opening up the as an extension point is the best way to "solve" this. The is a simple abstraction that provides a continuous "stream" of input data
column11: readable at your own pace to produce messages. The cumulation aspect imho should be considered an internal impl detail of that abstraction. I see the fact that it\\\'s currently configurable as more of a toggle between the  options
column12: which is a break in the abstraction to allow a "hint" about the kind of access pattern that will be used and have things optimized accordingly. I expect it\\\'s rare that anyone is actually using a custom impl and I wonder if we should even deprecate that capability in the next version.  Could we achieve the same thing by just adding a protected method
column13: which can optionally be called by impls to signal how many bytes they require for their next invocation? Then we can similarly minimize how much and how frequently cumulation needs to be done
column14: and avoid calling at all when there isn\\\'t sufficient data. This should make it easier to retrofit existing decoders and for new ones to exploit for example doing so for the fixed-message size case would be trivial.  Implementation-wise there would be some similarity to what you\\\'ve done i.e. in the merge case it would allocate and fill a buffer (reused if possible) based on the current required bytes
column15: only merging as much of the input buffer as required
column16: and always offering the input buffer as-is if it is large enough when there\\\'s no cumulated data. It would also benefit the composite case in that we could trim the writer index of composite cumulations down to the required number of bytes
column17: which makes it more likely that we can subsequently pass a single buffer rather than them continuing to operate "through" the composite on its final component.  This might be taking it too far but we could even have a version of the that also takes a (boolean?) flag indicating the kind of access that next batch of bytes should be optimized for
column18: which can be taken into account _if_ a cumulation is needed. This could be useful for cases where there\\\'s header-processing stages followed by larger chunks of content data.  Finally I noticed some  things: The logic to discard read bytes imho should be owned by the cumulator / cumulation logic it is already naturally discarding data and knows how much is otherwise (easily)  so could trigger it based on some absolute threshold. Passing smaller buffers to will also reduce the amount of data that retained slices hold on to. Some other minor improvements can be made to the existing logic of both types of cumulators to reduce the amount of work done in various situations. I will withhold that for now pending decisions on the wider change There are more enhancements that can be made to to reduce the cost of using it as a general alternative in places like this to avoid copying. I may open some PRs for that and it would be interesting to see how things compare with different benchmark workloads when all these things are combined I also have some comments on the benchmark but will save those for the time being!\''

column10: b'b" @njhill this tactic would prohibit modifying the behaviour of pre-existing handlers
column11: and also prevent more sophisticated use cases.  A simple example: let\'s say you have a single buffer for the entire event loop in the upstream handler
column12: that is sized to guarantee it is always sufficient; we want to ensure the downstream handler never saves the buffer it is passed
column13: and currently this is impossible.  Or another example: the upstream buffer is very large
column14: and we want to ensure for this handler that we only save small buffers if possible.  How do we configure this behaviour in the API you propose?  This is orthogonal to the number of bytes
column15: it\'s a decision about how we want to store those bytes
column16: and this seems natural to offload to the Cumulator.  IMO
column17: a networking library shouldn\'t try too hard to stay the hand of the sophisticated application developer
column18: though I guess it depends what you consider your target demographic."'

column10: b'b\'  We are in total agreement there! I\\\'m not suggesting to restrict what can be done
column11: just debating whether there may be a more appropriate way to achieve it that preserves the current separation of concerns.  I _think_ I understand what you\\\'re getting at with these examples (apologies if not) by "save" a buffer I presume you mean retain a reference to it via a retained slice. And in both cases the goal is to "protect" what could be a large input buffer from being retained
column12: so that it can be reused.  Relying on custom cumulators for this doesn\\\'t seem like the right approach since it\\\'s kind of an independent and external concern to the cumulation strategy
column13: which is more tied to the requirements of the decoder impl that it\\\'s associated with (merging vs composite
column14: etc.). It presumably would also apply to any handler operating on said buffers what if they don\\\'t happen to be decoders that extend  ?  If this approach was taken though
column15: would it suffice to define a third cumulator type for that purpose
column16: like or something? This could be used of course in combination with and would then end up behaving I think as you had planned. Is there any variation in anticipated usage beyond that which I haven\\\'t realized?  Had you considered just wrapping the input buffer (e.g. using or a equiv since it\\\'s package-private) and overriding to return a copy?\''

column10: b'b"  The benefit with the cumulator approach is that we can also modify the existing decoders supplied with Netty
column11: e.g. the SslHandler and the Lz4FrameDecoder
column12: and we can do it in a uniform way.  Of course
column13: we could instead modify all of these handlers ourselves as well
column14: providing some external method we can invoke to request this behaviour.  That would work for me
column15: as I\'m only interested in the capability
column16: not the approach.  It still feels like a weird coupling of behaviour
column17: because the other Cumulators cannot use this information.  If we were to modify the bounds of the buffer we supplied them from
column18: the existing Cumulators would behave incorrectly.  So I\'m also not entirely sure how we would implement this
column19: without completely deprecating Cumulator (which seems non-viable for a patch version)? But we don\'t retain a slice in ByteToMessageDecoder
column20: we take the whole thing
column21: since we already own it?  However
column22: even if this were an option
column23: I would not be keen introducing an unnecessary object allocation burden is something we\'d like to avoid."'

column10: b'b\' I think it would help to be precise about what exactly the goal is. 1. I can absolutely see the current inefficiency . the frequency and size of buffer combination operations being greater than necessary (whether by realloc + copying or composition)
column11: which could be substantially mitigated by the cumulation logic (wherever it may live) having some knowledge of the data size required by the decoder. This would appear to have very general applicability. 2. It sounds like the other more specialized goal (though partially related) is a general mechanism to prevent handlers in the inbound pipeline from holding references to the original upstream IO buffer (at least for longer than the scope of a single channel read operation)
column12: so that the buffer can be fully reused immediately.  Have I understood these two correctly? and is this exhaustive or are there other (even hypothetical) use cases which this is intended to address?  For (1)
column13: I agree that on the surface the existing public interface isn\\\'t sufficient. But I\\\'m not sure that matters given an assumption that existing custom cumulator impls are likely very rare. We just need to ensure that those still "work"; they don\\\'t need to be able to exploit new information provided for example by a new method. The two existing cumulator _constants_ would remain
column14: and in the (near universal) case that one of them is used
column15: we would just have special handling inside
column16: possibly not even using their method. I expect the effective logic though would be quite similar to your changes here . how the buffers are juggled.  For (2) assuming I\\\'ve understood your aim correctly
column17: I still think a wrapper which overrides sounds like the best option. I really don\\\'t think the additional single allocation involved would be significant (less than slicing a buffer)
column18: and in fact may only need to be done once up front i.e. you always send the same wrapper instance through the pipeline since it would be equivalent to the buffer it wraps. But for that reason you also don\\\'t care about  \\\'s own use
column19: right? It will always release the input buffer before returns (and can continue to do so)
column20: even if it holds onto it between successive calls to  .  Again really sorry if I\\\'ve missed
column21: misunderstood or misrepresented anything. I do still think this is a great change at its core
column22: just feel we should think carefully about how best to expose it. And of course this is just one view
column23: thoughts from others would be helpful too!\''

column10: b'b\' @belliottsmith apologies
column11: I think for (2) I did misunderstand what you meant by "saving" the input buffer. Presumably you\\\'re referring to the case after the input buffer has been used directly and isn\\\'t fully consumed i.e. where it\\\'s currently saved as the cumulation itself
column12: to be appended to on a subsequent read call if possible?  I wonder if that could also be handled in a  way using the information at hand. Specifically if we know the exact byte count required for the subsequent decode
column13: it probably makes sense to _always_ perform the preemptive copy prior to returning from if the input buffer either doesn\\\'t have sufficient writable capacity
column14: is read-only
column15: or has a ref count  I do still really like the idea of providing a method that can be called with potentially different values each time
column16: and to make it even more broadly applicable it could take separate "necessary" and "sufficient" values. Then for example it could be called with if we are expecting a var int with max length of 10.\''

column10: b"b' Because a ChannelHandler can belong to more than one ChannelPipeline
column11: it can be bound to multiple ChannelHandlerContext instances. A ChannelHandler intended for this use must be annotated with @Sharable; otherwise
column12: attempting to add it to more than one ChannelPipeline will trigger an exception. Clearly
column13: to be safe for use with multiple concurrent channels (that is
column14: connections)
column15: such a ChannelHandler must be thread-safe. This listing shows a correct implementation of this pattern.  Netty in Action
column16: Page 91.  the last sentence:Clearly
column17: to be safe for use with multiple concurrent channels (that is
column18: connections)
column19: such a ChannelHandler must be thread-safe. So I think
column20: the ChannelHandler is thread safe.'"

b"b' KQueueEventLoop might unregister active channels due to domain socket file descriptor reuse'"

b'b" ### Expected behavior The current implementation does not unregister active channels when domain socket file descriptor are reused.  ### Actual behavior The current implementation does not process concurrent domain socket channel  in the order they actual happen since unregistration are delated by an event loop task scheduling. When a domain socket is closed
column11: it\'s file descriptor might be reused quickly and therefore trigger a new channel registration using the same descriptor.  Consequently the method will overwrite the current inactive channels having the same descriptor and the delayed will remove the active channel that replaced the inactive one.  As active channels are registered
column12: events for this file descriptor won\'t be processed anymore and the channels will never be closed. The will also log such events with  ### Steps to reproduce Connect multiple channels doing a simple  and let the client close the channels when it receive the response. When there are enough channels
column13: this will happen.  ### Minimal yet complete reproducer code (or URL to code) I will provide a PR with a test and a tentative fix.  ### Netty version 4.1.34.Final and above  ### JVM version (e.g.  ) Not related  ### OS version (e.g.  ) Darwin MacBook-Pro-de17.7.0 Darwin Kernel Version 17.7.0: Fri Nov  2 20:43:16 PDT 2018; root:xnu-4570.71.17~1/RELEASE_X86_64 x86_64  "'

I don\'t know if you know the basics of quic but it is essentially a protocol that is based on UDP and acts a bit like TCP. Currently
column11: there is a QuicEncoder (Converts QuicPackets to ByteBuf) and QuicDecoder (Converts DatagramPacket to QuicPackets).  I have a few questions:  1. Are there utility methods to drain a ByteBuf to byte[] and to read a byte array of a specific size.  I made utility methods for that but I felt there must be methods for that in netty as you need it all the time. 2. We need some sort of session store for security keys and tokens but also to store InetSocketAddress for UDP. This breaks the typical netty  pattern because this store needs to be different for client and server. Maby we should add a SessionStore interface with methods like this SessionStore would then have two implementations for Client and Server and would be a Constructor Parameter for  3. I would like to use childHandlers like in TCP do we need an own channel implementation for that? 4. Should we have an own instance for VarInt or just static methods

column10: b"b' Make AbstractChannelPoolMap support concurrent access.'"
b"b' Motivation:  When multiple threads use the same key to access the get method in AbstractChannelPoolMap at the same time
column11: each thread calls the newPool method to create a new pool. Modification:  Use ReentrantLock to lock before creating a new ChannlPool. Result:  AbstractChannelPoolMap support multiple threads use the same key to access the get method at the same time.'"

b"b' Streaming large response affects other requests'"
b'b\' ### Expected behavior Hi
column11: I am using Netty as an HTTP Server. Since the last step in our pipeline may take a while
column12: we have an configured an which is used on the call to  . We are expecting any large responses (10 MBs or more) that are written as HTTP Chunks not to interfere with other requests
column13: but that is not what we are seeing.  ### Actual behavior After running for a short period of time (the below code) the script that repeatedly pings the server will hang until the large response is completed. It appears that any new channels that are directed to the same IO Thread are not handled until the large response is completed.  ### Steps to reproduce  1. Compile and run the server code below 2. Run  and the server will respond 3. Run the following cURL The ping requests will eventually hang. ### Minimal yet complete reproducer code (or URL to code)  Long running response ### Netty version 4.1.36.Final ### JVM version (e.g.  ) java version "9.0.1" Java(TM) SE Runtime Environment (build 9.0.1+11) Java HotSpot(TM) 64-Bit Server VM (build 9.0.1+11
column14: mixed mode)  ### OS version (e.g.  ) uname -a Linux dave-XPS-15-9560 4.15.0-50-generic #54~16.04.1-Ubuntu SMP Wed May 8 15:55:19 UTC 2019 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64  \''

column10: b"b' Because the for loop make CPU very busy  '"
b"b' Even if you throw a sleep in there it suffers from the same issue'"
b"b' @qeesung I put this in  and it shows the issue too.'"
b"b' Because when netty receives a request
column11: it distributes the request to the thread in the group according to the Round-Robin algorithm
column12: so if the Ping request is allocated to the thread that is processing the chunk request in the for loop
column13: the Ping request will be blocked.  You can try to send a new Ping request when the  script is blocked
column14: and the Ping request sent later will respond.  '"

column10: b"b' But I thought the addition of the should prevent the IO thread from hanging. I understand that if I were to just to an I would be pinning that one thread until it is done.'"
b"b' Because can only be executed in a group with two worker threads
column11: once the worker thread is blocked
column12: subsequent arrival requests will be blocked in the worker thread of the group. Here the IO thread is not blocked (in other words
column13: it can read and send data anyway)
column14: but the execution thread of handler is blocked
column15: that is to say
column16: when the request is received
column17: the thread is too busy to process the HTTP request
column18: so it can not respond.  If you want to write a large response
column19: maybe you can try the following ways:  '"

column10: b"b' I think it just clicked. That the worker thread group (not IO Threads) is treated the same way as the other Event groups when dispatching request: it just round robins. I was thinking that this type of event group was used more like a traditional thread pool where it uses the next available thread. Is that accurate? And if so
column11: is there an implementation that works more like a traditional thread pool for these type of tasks?'"

column10: b"b' Yes
column11: at present
column12: group only distributes tasks to worker threads in Round-Robin way. You can create a traditional thread pool outside of netty
column13: then move busy code into your own thread pool that using custom scheduling strategy.'"

column10: b"b' like @qeesung said or use  . That said you need to ensure you write stuff back in the correct order as otherwise you will get into trouble.  '"
b'b\' Thanks guys. I was thinking in a Netty 3 mindset with that "handler" event loop group
column11: and that is where that problem was. Appreciate the quick responses.\''
